I don't leave reviews normally but I had to say something about this game. While I watched my dad die of cancer in hospital, this game was literally the only thing that kept me sane. We both loved history in particular WW2 history and this allowed me to feel a connection with the man and I'm truly grateful for that fact... With mods and constant updates, it's truly a unique game and probably my favorite game now.

Overall very good game, well spent money, I have spent 100 bucks overall and enjoyed more than 1500 hours already. Cons: - steep learning curve - underlying mechanics not easy to understand - tutorial is not sufficient, extensive research has to be done in forums, youtube, reddit to fully grasp the game - AI has flaws (then again every AI has that problem) - PDX DLC policy (hate it or love it, at least they keep providing content. I'm fine with paying 10-20 bucks of a DLC that gives me 50 hours of gameplay) Pros: + very detailed gameplay, multiple aspects of production, warfare and ressource accquisation have to be dealt with + focus trees (even though locked behind DLC paywall) are getting more detailed and immersive + countless gameplay options for many countries provide immense replayability (number with DLCs increasing) + lots of achievements to grind, some fun, some very hard + Coop is fun, as is multiplayer if you have 6 consecutive hours spare

The Legendary HOI4. The game which is one of the best and one of the worst. If we look just at vanilla Hoi4, we can see that this game had so much potential, but executed poorly, even after so many DLCs its still pretty bare bones compared to another thing, which keeps alive this game for a long time. Its mods, mods and mods. There so much mods, so much different types of them, that you feel like youre a small kid in the toystore where all the games and toys are FREE, not only that, but those toys are made by regular people like you and I. Its quite impressive that pretty mediocre game could become 10/10 game just because this one thing. You can spend hours upon hours just trying different mods out. You want something like regular vanilla, but with more conten? Road to 56 got you covered. Maybe you want to play something quite different like, idk, alternative universe. You got boatload of them, one the well-known is Kaiserreich (and a Wacky Kaiserredux, which is waaaaay better and fun, then original, because more stuff the better. Change my mind.) You got also Cold war era mods, mideval  era mods, modern day mods, etc... You also got a unicorn which is sorta Visual novel in form of strategy which is called TNO ( The New Order: Last days of Europe). I mean, you got so much stuff that sometimes you dont know which mod to play. Oh, and there is a huge amout of grafical, sound mods and etc. And yeah, you need to buy some DLCs just to have ac—Åess to some cool mechanics in game. (But of course you can sometimes "Buy" them with a pretty big discount (up to 100%) if you know what I mean *wink*wink*. But I don't approve of that. And buy this game only during sales, your wallet will be thankful for that. TL;DR: Vanilla game is pretty bad, but with mods is a God-tier grand strategy game.

The amount of time I have used playing this game, truly makes me wonder was it all worth it? Two thousand hours looking at funny maps, moving troops, navies, air wings within it and managing resources. Was there nothing more entertaining in my life, back then when I bought this game? It was fun for maybe like the first thousand hours, but after that, everytime I finished a campaign, I would be extremely exhausted and underwhelmed, half a day practically wasted. Why would man impose such waste of time on oneself, even if he gets little to none happines from it? It must be simply masochism and self hate towards oneself, to repeat the cycle of picking a nation and playing for countless of hours, almost everyday. Was there no better way of using that time, developing useful skills or reading a good book? Despite everything, I still love the game and return to it once in a while. Hell, there's a chance I'm just burned out and I will expend another thousand hours into it (I hope not). Now I could in detail explain what's good and bad about the game, gameplay wise, graphically etc. but I really can't muster the energy to do it properly. So I'll just say that it's one of the better, maybe in the top 3 best grand strategy games ever. The game has also a really active and large modding community, which really keeps the game fresh and gives counter balance to the absurd DLC-policy of Paradox Interactive. But for real, if you want to buy and play the game proper, please don't use thousands of hours to it. For your own well-being and future. And make sure you stop playing when you no longer get, what you originally bought it for, which most likely is to gain enjoyment. I would probaply /not/ recommend this game, due to it in the long run taking so much of my time and for the outrageous DLCs that Paradox sells for this game. But for some reason I can't dislike the game. Thus I give it a score of 8.5/10, my favourite time-waste game ever.

I feel that the hoi4 development team has strayed away from developing mechanics, and instead being more focused on making some crazy alt history focus tree for some random minor nation. Although they have improved air and naval* systems, and even added espionage* (which feels a little lackluster to be on its own dlc), these changes took like a year each to be changed, and many other features are screwed up (especially peace treaties). Also it feels that hoi4 is more focused on making huge focus trees* that take forever to get through, and have some absolutely bonkers alt history paths (not necessarily a bad thing but they could have focused on other things). Although, the game is good at the thing that it focuses on: warfare. The war mechanic in this game is pretty good and I would only like to see only a few changes to it. But unfortunately, after you play the game for long enough, the AI becomes really easy to beat since it has no idea on what it's doing. Lastly, probably the best thing about this game and the reason why I am recommending it, the mods. I pretty much never play vanilla, thanks to the huge collection of mods that the community makes. Hoi4 is home to giant mods that no other paradox game has. Thus I recommend to get this game as long as you have the intent of using the steam workshop constantly. (*DLC content. yeah i know that the dlc policy sucks. Its Paradox, what did you expect?)

TLDR: If you love grand strategy, logistics, and encircling maneuvers, as well as a gradual buildup to an epic (albeit slow) war, then this is the best WWII strategy game you can buy. However, this is a game of strategy, not tactics, so keep that in mind. Actual Review: Hearts of Iron 4 is an amazing World War 2 grand strategy game. However, it's definitely not for everyone. There's a distinct lack of action in the early game, as you slowly build up your forces and industrial capability. Furthermore, you kind of have to set your own goals for the game, whether that is allying with one of the three major factions before the outbreak of war, or just conquering your neighbors and avoiding tangling with the big dogs. PROS: --If you love logistics, supply, troop configurations and large-scale movement of divisions, then you will have a blast playing this game. You can design division templates however you wish and there are glorious loads of numbers and interesting statistics to mess with. --The scale of the game is very epic, and you definitely feel like the master of millions of troops slowly pushing long lines of combat. --The interface, albeit a bit clunky in some areas, is efficient and streamlined for the most part. --You can do some absolutely amazing encircling maneuvers and other big strategies. Want to hold chokepoints? You can do it. Want to launch surprise naval landings in the enemy's backyard? Yep, that too. --The soundtrack is about as good as you can get for a World War 2 game. NEUTRAL POINTS: --The game is probably amazing if you play cooperatively or competitively with friends. I wouldn't know as all my friends were not big fans of this and won't play with me any more. See con #1. --There's not much you can do for small-scale tactics or individual battles. This is a game about broad strokes  of army movements and strategies, not minute details of individual battles. Less tactics, more strategy. CONS: --There's a distinct lack of action early on in the game, and the game does feel a bit dry for people who are used to more intense action and combat. This means it won't appeal to everyone, and especially not to people who don't enjoy logistics and strategy over tactics and action. The joy of the war in the game is seeing amazing strategies come to fruition or fail miserably, and, frankly, that's just not enough for some people (such as my friends). --Further elaborating on that point, the combat is very dry. It's basically watching numbers fight each other. You need a good imagination to really enjoy it. --There are long, dry stretches of the game where not a lot happens. This can be alleviated by speeding up the game, but just be prepared for that. You won't be getting constant dopamine hits from this one. --You can technically choose to play any nation in the world (at that time), but obviously there is a strong bias towards the big players of World War 2. If you play any country outside of the axis, allies, or comintern, you will find yourself at a distinct disadvantage that only the greatest level of skill and experience with the game can overcome. This can diminish the fun for many people who might want to conquer the world as the mighty (and tiny) nation of Bhutan. It's not impossible, it's just very, very difficult. --A few cosmetic and small issues that can be fixed with mods (division icons, etc). So, basically, if you are a patient, left-brained person who enjoys logistics and grand army strategies and maneuvers, then you might enjoy this game. But if you want intense action and amazing combat as well as a constant stream of stimulation, then this is probably not the game for you. P.S. - The DLC are a bit overpriced, but not necessary, so I really don't mind it. You might though.

If you plan on buying only the base game, without DLCs and don't use mods, don't bother. However, I highly recommend HOI4 if you plan on using mods or at least get the DLCs. Which are overpriced by a lot, but that is another story. Vanilla HOI4 The base game feels barebone and offers very little when it comes to different playstyles and strategies. Minor nations are designed with the bare minimum and even some major ones have very simple focus trees. Vanilla HOI4 is void of decisions, diverse playstyle options and interesting history progression. Those are the reasons why I cannot recommend the base game. It is an empty shell of a strategy game. DLCs The DLCs introduce mechanics which improve the overall gameplay by quite a bit and open a lot more strategic possibilities. Alternate history is also way more diverse and offers interesting world progression. It makes the game way more challenging and replayable. That being said, they are too expensive for what they offer. And a lot of what they introduce should have already been in the base game. Only consider getting the DLCs if they are on sale. Mods The big positive is the modding community. Mods are the lifeblood of this game. There are countless mods out there for pretty much everything you can imagine. Many of them completely overhaul the game and improve it in every aspect. They turn HOI4 into an amazing strategy game with a huge replayability factor.

The best game and the worst game. The game is great in terms of content and gameplay, but this game gets a very low score in terms of performance. This game has not been able to force the system to use all its power to play since its release. In most cases, a CPU core is used, which in the middle of the game causes the game speed to slow down sharply. . As far as I know, to play this game online, it does not have the ability to run on a virtual server. For this reason, players who do not have a good internet always slow down the game process and the game never runs at its last speed. With all these problems, this game is one of the best games I have played and I am looking forward to the continuation of this series. I hope this game can solve its problems and we will see a complete game without any problems.

The #1 piece of advice I have for new players is DON'T PLAY MODDED HOI4. Mods are overrated and really mess with your sense of game balance, game sense, and understanding of the game's mechanics. Play vanilla until you know the mechanics inside out, then move on to mods once you run out of things to do. You'll save yourself hundreds of hours learning the game by not diving into mods immediately.

This is by far the best WW2 grand strategy, and it encompasses a lot of great features for macroeconomy and war planning. Perhaps the only downside is, your generals are incompetent (do I already sound like someone you know?). Basically if I let my generals fighting battles, I lose. If I micromanage and use mobile warfare tactics, I actually stand a chance of winning. The battleplans are poorly executed and seem more like WW1 fighting on the whole front than blitzkrieg tactics. The AI does not try any pincer maneouver, they do not try to concentrate forces on surrounding enemy troops, but tries to attack on the whole front. Otherwise, a great game!

Product received for free Hearts of Iron 4 is a really great strategy game on the theme of World War 2. And if you are a fan of this genre, it and the mods from the workshop will drag you for a very long period of time. If you have played Civilization IV/V/VI - this game is bound to please you. If you have friends who love strategy, be sure to try playing together - playing in multiplayer is a completely different experience from what you have with bots in a single game. After this game, you will most likely want to try some other games from Paradox interactive and definitely should opt for Crusader Kings III, Europa Universalis IV or Victoria II. Good luck and have fun!

Your ai allies ingame will spam harass you for everything. If you say no you soon see the same request again very soon after. Imaging having 20 allies. Constantly spamming you while you try to heavily micromanage your frontline because it loves moving your troops to places that will cost you the game.  Also really fun when your ai allies just sit in their country and do nothing to assist the war. talking about YOU ROMANIA! Really the game actually is very fun when none of these problems exist, but for every game they do :( at least for me.

This game was pretty fun when I started playing.  A simple little WW2 strategy game that was fun to put on and relax.  Since then, it's grown.  This is not inherently bad- more depth is always welcome.  It's what makes games like EU4 so good.  But I swear, the people in charge of updating this game must be LITERAL monkeys.  The game is full of loopholes in the code, baffling glitches, and of course, Paradox's DLC policy.  When I say loopholes, I refer to something like this: getting an event pertaining to a country that no longer exists, having allies or puppets you've acquired flip sides because of another country's focus, and other stuff like that.  When I say glitches, I mean stuff like this: not being invited to a peace conference, and watching your allies take everything you've worked for, or your entire faction being left out of a peace conference.  Your faction will cease to be at war with your target, and you will be stuck perpetually occupying their land.  You won't own it, just occupy it.  And when I talk about Paradox's DLC policy... Well, other people have summed that up far better than I could.  This game has gone from one of my favourites, to one I always find myself clicking away from angry.  Please, stay far away from thing game.

Hearts of Iron 4, you want to play Germany and Conquer the world and show how you can invade Russia in the winter with your big cat tanks. You can do it. Want to become a Communist America and have to fight a second civil war before 1941. You bet your ass you can do it. You want to bring the British monarch back into power and have the great British Empire be the best power across the world. Yep you can do that. The point being is this game allows all Different types of play through and is honestly a blast to play. The only issue is some of the cool scenarios are locked behind sometimes overpriced DLC so thats not fun. If you want to be good at the game their are a lot of guides here on steam and Youtube, it does not need to be trial and error. However if you are not the kinda of person who likes min maxing stats on units or large scale strategies then you might not want to play. Mods are also a fantastic here plenty of overhaul mods, such as Millennium Dawn: Modern Day Mod or Hearts of Iron IV: The Great War both are great mods that change a lot and are cared for by their creators which is common on the HOI4 workshop. I hope you enjoy this game as much as i do. Good luck my friends.

In classic Paradox fashion, base game isn't the whole experience they are offering. Instead you are supposed to pay around 60-70 dollars for expansions and in total of 165 dollars for all DLC - that is if you are interested in costumes and music packs. Which I most certainly am not. Vanilla is obviously playable, but it isn't that enjoyable to play. Most expansions add (almost) needed changes/fixes and gameplay enhancing focus trees for less major countries, such as Hungary or Portugal. Seriously Man the Guns expansion tweaks naval warfare and actually makes it fun. In base game it is as shallow as it gets - even with rather recent "redone naval combat". Now. Why did I recommend this game? Because funnily enough, once you actually have these DLC's, game (un)surprisingly becomes fun. There are plenty of stuff to do. You can play historical focuses ON and play how WW2 was meant to be like (keep in mind, even with historical focuses, there are almost certainly historical inaccuracies). Or alternatively turn historical focuses OFF and enjoy the chaos that will endure. Obviously you can do this in vanilla as well, but expansions add so much flavor into the game - with extra focus trees and more things that you can do - no game is same experience. PLUS if you have rich friends or friends that devote their whole unholy soul to Paradox, you can play multiplayer with them. As every player inherits DLC's from lobby host. That being said, Hearts of Iron IV is easily easiest Paradox grand-strategy game out there. It is very easy to learn and easier to master than games like Europa Universalis IV. There is still enough depth to look forward into and most casual players will still find HOI4 difficult to play. Which makes it fun experience to play with friends. Keep in mind though, like every other Paradox game, it only operates 1 thread from your CPU, so it runs like trash. So even with beast computer, expect FPS drops with faster game speeds. There are other nitpicks I could say, such as terrible new launcher they forced last year. However IF HEARTS OF IRON IV IS ON SALE, it is definitely worth a try. Don't expect too much though, as Paradox's quality control has been in deep decline since release of Stellaris.

Well as you can see I have a good chunk of hours in this game and so I believe I can make a fairly decent or good review for HOI4, I hope if you find this review and if you want to buy HOI4 that this helps influence your opinion. :) HOI4 is a very good game (I wouldn't have 3000 hours if it wasn't) but it has some very big problems and faults. For example many of the dlcs are required to have a fun and enjoyable experience, however you can play with all if them if you a join a multiplayer game with all dlcs. For example, the newest dlc "Battle for the Bosporus" only adds focus trees, no new game mechanics, so that dlc would not be required as you could get the same experience with mods, but the dlc "Together for Victory" adds some very important game mechanics. There is a very huge and amazing modding community for hoi4, just scroll through the steam workshop and you will see some absolutely amazing mods, just to list a few there is Kaiserreich, Millenium Dawn, Old World Blues, and Road to 56. Now multiplayer, a very diverse and interesting thing in HOI4. I would recommend if you want to get into multiplayer, find a good group of people to play with that are fun and chill, because be warned, there are many multiplayer groups out their who are just nazis who just act retarded and just spam the n word and things of that nature. The majority of communities and people who play this game aren't like that, but there is definitely a good chunk of players who are like that. Singleplayer, the bane of any HOI4 player. Singleplayer can be alright early on when you don't really know how the game works or how to beat the ai, but once you know how to do those things you won't want to play singleplayer, because it becomes extremely easy, and please I warn you, don't buy this game to do achievements. I have only done a few and many of the ones I have not done are extremely difficult and just not fun. Just look up youtube videos of people attempting them and look how it long it takes them and how not enjoyable it is. So this wasn't a super in depth review but to be honest I would recommend this game for anyone who either likes Paradox games, or enjoys WW2/Strategy Games since you will probably suck thousands of hours into it just like I have. Also, if you are debating about buying this game, make sure to watch youtube videos that are reviews and tutorials just to really see if you enjoy it. But anyway I hope this review helps anybody and I hope you have a good day!

As for the base game 9/10, I think it would be nice to give the hosts of a MP game the option to have console commands if the other players approve but that's preference. I would however like to point out Italy's focus tree, I'm not going to restate what everyone else has already said but the Italian focus tree. As for the DLCs, again I wont point out the price as everyone else has and focus on the content they add. Waking the tiger, 10/10 spot on, an outstanding DLC and I think the challenge of forming the holy roman empire is elaborate, necessary, no, but then again, how likely is it that the HRE would have existed in WWII? As for together for victory, as annoying as it is that it is DLC, I'll push past and give the content a reluctant 7/10, I think that you should be able to increase puppet autonomy is one flaw. I think they did a good job with some focus trees and one of my favourites is New Zealand. This being said(my opinion), I think an option to have the focus of the puppet to be more aggressive, or if not, I think the puppet AI should be more aggressive than it is rn. What do I recommend? Countries: Germany, it's just a nice all around country where you can be incredibly overpowered given it's focus tree can get you austria, czechoslovakia, yugoslavia, and potentially some polish lands as well as puppeting greece, romania, and hungary without war.. Soviet union, need I say more? Ok I do apparently, tons of manpower, tons of resources, tons of troops, germany might blitzkrieg you but you'll still have a fun time. USA, actually no, probably one of the worst countries to play in this whole game. Italy, you don't really have much to worry about with germany as your ally and it's a great way to  learn how to use a navy. Tips: Democracy = God no, god please no. Non-Aligned = meh. Communism = Soviets or bust. Fascism = Blitzkreig. ---------------------- Tanks, good for offence, using them for defence will make you sad. Infantry, good for defence, relatively cheap. Motorised, just get mechanised. Mechanised, discount tanks. ----------------------- Mods: Road to '56, if you don't have DLC, get this it will give you lots to do and give non-major countries focus trees. Kaiserreich, perfect if you are more into a story rather than the base game(alt history WWII). No(that german symbol), perfect if you live in a country that bans that german symbol so you can still play the game. Sandbox Decisions, if you are playing on multiplayer and have trusted friends it can give you some utilities or just give you a boosted or single player experience. TL;DR Great game, Great DLC, DLC = Mostly things that should be in updates that aren't. Ok, that about wraps it up. If you plan on getting this game I strongly recommend quill18's tutorial, believe me when I say you will not be able to play this game to any extent without watching a tutorial.

HOI4 is a top-tier strategy game, and certainly the best WW2-based one. The joy you'd get from executing strategies is remarkable. On top of that, since each country has a path that can lead to a variety of results, it gives the game almost endless replayability. Moreover, it's fairly historically accurate, and you can even use your knowledge of historical events to your advantage in countless ways. Yet, the company of HOI4 decided to release a number of DLCs, which the majority of them came at the expense of the completeness and the stability of the game. Therefore, I wouldn't recommend HOI4 because of that reason alone, though if you're able to purchase HOI4 with all of the DLCs in a major discount, then it'll deliver hours upon hours of decent gameplay.

This game saved my life. I am 50. My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old. When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide. After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side. Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay. After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as. Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends. I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together. Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

As of 25/7/2021 Hoi 4 is ¬£0.72 on Humble Bundle: https://www.humblebundle.com/games/hearts-of-iron?hmb_source=humble_home&hmb_medium=product_tile&hmb_campaign=mosaic_section_4_layout_index_2_layout_type_carousel_tile_index_1_c_heartsofiron_bundle The base game is ¬£0.72 and if you pay ¬£13 you get the game and most of the important DLC (excluding La Resistance though that DLC is fairly meh anyway) Oh, and some of your purchase goes to Charity. As for the actual game, it's great. Really good fun for a WW2 nerd, or normal person. It's a steep but rewarding learning curve. Would recommend going into a Co-op game with an experienced player and they explain the basics. Don't worry about "Meta's" or anything. It's a mostly single player game so play as you want. Multiplayer is fairly alive, there is even some "e-sports" competitions set up by popular content creators such as TommyKay. However, I wouldn't recommend multiplayer AT ALL, for a new player. Unless it's a co op game with your mate. Overall, it's a great starter grand strat game to introduce you to Paradox, and maybe some of there other games. Essential DLC are Man the Guns and Waking the Tiger. Both fairly cheap on sale and included in the ¬£13 Humble Bundle. These add essential focus tree's and features. La resistance is for someone who wants to play as France, Spain, Portugal or mess about with espionage. But other than that it's a very optional DLC, and definitely not for everyone (Spy system is kinda annoying and boring imo). Recommended!

After 3,000 hours in HoI4 alone, I can reliably say: Spend your gaming dollar and time elsewhere. I've played since HoI1... the series has always had a lot of potential, combined with a slew of issues that were both unnecessary and remain unresolved years after release (or ever). With HoI4 nothing has changed and you have the benefit of paying for a new broken and bugged DLC every so often. Every time there's a bunch of new things to learn and new ways they've broken both the game balance but also bugged the core game mechanics. This is not an exaggeration. For example... Right now there is a game-breaking bug in Man the Guns (more than two years after release) where the AI literally cannot build a navy. It's probably the single most upvoted bug report on the HoI forum. It's one of the very few bugs that the mods have bothered to comment on. However, Paradox refuses to say if, or when, they'll fix it. They keep selling the DLC with no warnings at the point of sale. They make no apology to the thousands of people who've already brought a product that has never worked or lived up to promise (MtG was meant to be THE naval DLC for HoI4). It's as inexcusable and dishonest as it sounds. You can find the bug report and masses of other bugs and issues in the HoI4 bug report forum. After being a die hard fan since HoI1, having made mods in the past, having spent more hours doing bug reports than I care to count... I now near-loathe Paradox. If this sounds like great 'fun', HoI4 is the game for you. If you like a game that completely lets you down after a punishing learning curve with unresolved inexcusable bugs, constantly changing mechanics and a new slew of bugs (every time there's a new DLC)... then HoI4 (and anything from Paradox really) is for YOU!  Warm up your wallet, you've got more than 10 DLCs to buy on top of the base game.

PDX DLC policy continues to ensure that depending on what you bought, your game will be either bare-bones, with you stumbling across holes where game mechanics ought to be, or stuffed full of game mechanics that do not actually mechanically interact with each other because the game needs to work with any possible subset of the available DLCs. Same as Stellaris, EU and the other titles, its an inherent design limitation imposed by the business strategy. The business side seems to be working out, but the game design side remains disappointingly mediocre in spite of the game's overall size.

I have logged many hours playing this game, primarily because it followed HOI III which I thought was a truly enjoyable game.  For me, HOI IV is a step in the wrong direction.  I do not like having no victory conditions.  I understand that when multi-playing, you can agree on such things beforehand, but against the computer it is nice to have a built in victory condition. I also consider the interface to be a step in the wrong direction.  HOI III had a tendency to be over-notifying, for example receiving a notification after every battle in every province.  But at least you could control that.  In HOI IV, there are very few notifications and as far as I can tell, they cannot really be changed to your playing preference.  An example:  I was playing as Germany, had a somewhat stable front against the USSR and was focusing my attention at saving Italy from an invasion into the Balkans.  While focusing on this, I out of the blue receive a banner stating that Berlin has fallen (!!).  Apparently I missed the little invasion flag and the Soviets not only invaded North of Berlin, but they were so stealthy the got all the way to Berlin without my noticing.  Can I set it up so that it warns me when I lose a province??  If yes, I cannot find it.  I turned on the comments and would truly appreciate feedback, perhaps I am missing something that would help me to enjoy this game. As with HOI III, there are many wonderful features to the game, but the interface and lack of real victory conditions are ruining it for me.

Basegame Rating: 6/10 Modded Rating: 9/10 The basegame without DLC is a bit bland and gets boring at times. The achievements are definitely fun to do but otherwise it's very bare bones. Poorly optimized, Clausewitz is not a very good game engine. Political ideologies are bland as well, no nuance whatsoever. Modding community is the best thing about HOI4. TNO, Kaiserreich/KaiserRedux, New ways, etc. The mods in this game are top tier. It's great that teams of people can improve a game's mechanics so much and add so much more nuance to the base game. If you get this game for any reason, get it for the mods. + Historically accurate + Good Modding community + Fun mechanics + well designed tech trees + well designed focus trees - Poorly optimized - Gets boring at times - Lack of nuance in political ideologies - AI is dumb at times But that's just my grain of salt.

An excellent grand strategy game centered around the events of WW2. This is an excellent option if you like games like EU4 or CK, but wish it was more military oriented. The war effort is all you work on in this game, with other aspects like the civilian economy abstracted into things like Economy Laws and Consumer Goods usage. You can follow the historical paths and try to do things slightly different than reality, like playing as the US and decisively holding the Philippines and knocking Japan out early. Or, you can go entirely alt-history, and play as a Monarchist France and bring back the Bonaparte's. The DLC's generally add quite a bit, but I'd suggest waiting for a sale.

Hearts of Iron IV is a Grand Strategy Game set in the era of WW2, and it captures the essence of what makes Grand Strategy Warfare enjoyable in every essence with a sophisticated enough combat and logistics system, combined with fun combat. This game is made for anyone who enjoys making history through warfare. A lot of people get HOI4 wrong, the game is not about alternative history, nor is it about doing politics. All of the national focuses and political systems are made to support the warfare, just like in real life. It is about total war. The game is not without its flaws. However, they are largely overlooked by the fun combat. Some countries such as Germany are way too overpowered, especially in single-player. The plethora of mods in the workshop resolve the issue, though it you should understand that knowing Vanilla is essential in getting good at the game. Mods are a core part of the experience, and some mods totally transform the game works. For reference, mods such as The New Order and The Red Flood are more narrative driven; if you love history, you will enjoy this game. Overall, I would give HOI4 a 9/10 as of 2021

Hearts of Iron IV is a "Grand Strategy" game set during the turmoil of the 1930's/40's and the Second World War. You can command any nation around the world and lead it on to the world stage and on to glory. No matter which country you command, you can customize it to your liking. You can change their ideology, strengthen their economy, and lead them to dominate the earth! To start with the pros, its definitely a very enjoyable game in the early stages of any match, the feeling of evaluating what you have to work with and then building up slowly in power or starting off at a breakneck speed for some countries is spot on. The graphics, though a little rough at points are really great overall and do a wonderful job of conveying everything to the player. The menus, controls and UI, though complicated at first, are quick and efficient once you get them down. The sheer amount of variety in terms of playable countries is also a big plus. With that said, however, the game has plenty of flaws, foremost among them being the AI. It will either be the most formidable and downright unfairly impossible opponent to ever walk the Earth, or it will put up the resistance of a wet packet of spaghetti, and very rarely any level between that. And then there's the DLC. Overall, have they greatly improved the gameplay and made things more immersive? Definitely. Should these parts of the game have been cut out and then sold back to you for an added fee? Hell no. Sure, one can argue that these were aspects the devs needed extra time to implement, or that they only thought of them later on, but that does not justify that in order to play Hearts of Iron 4 in any meaningful capacity beyond a basic WW2 sim, which by this point is one of the worse aspects of the game, you need to essentially pay for the game all over again and then some, which is just not acceptable to me. So yes, overall I can say I can recommend this game for those who want a political or military wargame set in the 1930s and 40s, and who want to try interesting, unique or just plain silly alternate history options. But be very aware that the game only has so much content before you need to start relying on messing around with friends to keep it interesting, and make sure you're willing to buy at least some of the DLC, because otherwise you're not going to have much of a game to play. Overall, a fairly solid 7/10 from me.

At first, when I looked at the game-play of HOI4 in Youtube, it seemed a bit complicated for me. However, being a WWII freak sometimes, I did buy the game. I must say the training module in the base game is horrible (doesn't teach you much) but I learnt it slowly bit by bit from Youtube and my friends who had played it before me. And, boy oh boy! I started spending hours, forgetting what reality is and sometimes thinking whether it is 1936 or 1939. This game has given me hours of good warfare, knowledge of warfare and history and also helped me made some great friends (while playing multiplayer). A great game, optimised for all kinds of PCs (though, after 1945, it lags a bit everywhere) and great game-play that can keep you immersed from time to time. I first just want to say that this game is amazing and is very fun to play mods with friends but here are some of my main complaints; The navy. it's pretty bad but it can be improved by buying the Man The Guns DLC and for most people that can be annoying. Paradox releases alot of DLC's that really should just be in the vanilla version of the game (the same apply's to Cities: Skylines and alot of their other games Paradox just wants money lol) I want to move onto skill trees specifically Italy's skill tree... It's not complex enough compared to the other skill trees, in other words; it's short and bad and Paradox still haven't even released a DLC for it. Now I want to move onto some pros/good things about the game; The immersion and realism. You have a choice if you want to play the game historically accurate but you also have a choice if you don't, for an example; I was once allied with Soviet Union as Poland, I was once allied with the Soviet Union as Finland, and Mexico went to war with the USA. To digest this entire review: I definitely recommend hoi4 (Hearts of Iron IV) the game is very fun. If you don't have the money for it I would wait for a sale even thought its kinda rare it still goes on sale for 10 USD once in a blue moon. Lastly I just want to say that my grammar isn't the best and I don't write reviews often but regardless thank you for reading this and I hope you have a good day/night. :)

World War II or the Second World War, often abbreviated as WWII or WW2, was a global war that lasted from 1939 to 1945. It involved the vast majority of the world's countries‚Äîincluding all of the great powers‚Äîforming two opposing military alliances: the Allies and the Axis powers. In a total war directly involving more than 100 million personnel from more than 30 countries, the major participants threw their entire economic, industrial, and scientific capabilities behind the war effort, blurring the distinction between civilian and military resources. Aircraft played a major role in the conflict, enabling the strategic bombing of population centres, and, with the development of nuclear weapons, the only two uses of such in war. World War II was by far the deadliest conflict in human history, and resulted in 70 to 85 million fatalities, a majority being civilians. Tens of millions of people died due to genocides (including the Holocaust), starvation, massacres, and disease. In the wake of the Axis defeat, Germany and Japan were occupied, and war crimes tribunals were conducted against German and Japanese leaders. World War II is generally considered to have begun on 1 September 1939, when Nazi Germany, under Adolf Hitler, invaded Poland. The United Kingdom and France subsequently declared war on the 3rd. Under the Molotov‚ÄìRibbentrop Pact of August 1939, Germany and the Soviet Union had partitioned Poland and marked out their "spheres of influence" across Finland, Romania and the Baltic states. From late 1939 to early 1941, in a series of campaigns and treaties, Germany conquered or controlled much of continental Europe, and formed the Axis alliance with Italy and Japan (along with other countries later on). Following the onset of campaigns in North Africa and East Africa, and the fall of France in mid-1940, the war continued primarily between the European Axis powers and the British Empire, with war in the Balkans, the aerial Battle of Britain, the Blitz of the UK, and the Battle of the Atlantic. On 22 June 1941, Germany led the European Axis powers in an invasion of the Soviet Union, opening the Eastern Front, the largest land theatre of war in history and trapping the Axis powers, crucially the German Wehrmacht, in a war of attrition. Japan, which aimed to dominate Asia and the Pacific, was at war with the Republic of China by 1937. In December 1941, Japan attacked American and British territories with near-simultaneous offensives against Southeast Asia and the Central Pacific, including an attack on the US fleet at Pearl Harbor which forced the US to declare war against Japan; the European Axis powers declared war on the US in solidarity. Japan soon captured much of the western Pacific, but its advances were halted in 1942 after losing the critical Battle of Midway; later, Germany and Italy were defeated in North Africa and at Stalingrad in the Soviet Union. Key setbacks in 1943‚Äîincluding a series of German defeats on the Eastern Front, the Allied invasions of Sicily and the Italian mainland, and Allied offensives in the Pacific‚Äîcost the Axis powers their initiative and forced it into strategic retreat on all fronts. In 1944, the Western Allies invaded German-occupied France, while the Soviet Union regained its territorial losses and turned towards Germany and its allies. During 1944 and 1945, Japan suffered reversals in mainland Asia, while the Allies crippled the Japanese Navy and captured key western Pacific islands. The war in Europe concluded with the liberation of German-occupied territories, and the invasion of Germany by the Western Allies and the Soviet Union, culminating in the fall of Berlin to Soviet troops, Hitler's suicide and the German unconditional surrender on 8 May 1945. Following the Potsdam Declaration by the Allies on 26 July 1945 and the refusal of Japan to surrender on its terms, the United States dropped the first atomic bombs on the Japanese cities of Hiroshima, on 6 August, and Nagasaki, on 9 August. Faced with an imminent invasion of the Japanese archipelago, the possibility of additional atomic bombings, and the Soviet entry into the war against Japan and its invasion of Manchuria, Japan announced its intention to surrender on 15 August, then signed the surrender document on 2 September 1945, cementing total victory in Asia for the Allies. World War II changed the political alignment and social structure of the globe. The United Nations (UN) was established to foster international co-operation and prevent future conflicts, and the victorious great powers‚ÄîChina, France, the Soviet Union, the United Kingdom, and the United States‚Äîbecame the permanent members of its Security Council. The Soviet Union and the United States emerged as rival superpowers, setting the stage for the nearly half-century-long Cold War. In the wake of European devastation, the influence of its great powers waned, triggering the decolonisation of Africa and Asia. Most countries whose industries had been damaged moved towards economic recovery and expansion. Political integration, especially in Europe, began as an effort to forestall future hostilities, end pre-war enmities and forge a sense of common identity.

Hearts of Iron IV is a very entertaining, well-made simulation of the circumstances leading up to and including World War II, which allows you to play as a myriad of countries with unique choices and options. Overall I found it to be a very, very good game. Pros - HoI is beautifully and carefully made and it shows. The warfare mechanic is the best I've ever seen, functioning by managing front lines and target points rather than micromanaging unit by unit like in other Paradox games. It makes warfare truly fun in a way that most other games of this type do not manage. Additionally, while it is based on WWII, you don't have to play a fully historical route. Want to oppose Hitler and restore the Kaiser? You can! Want to defeat Imperial Japan as China and become the preeminent Asian power? Go for it! And to accompany the choices that you can make, a historical/ahistorical mode allows for AI opponents who will either try their best to stick to real-world decisions or who will choose their own wild historical narratives that might pit you against Communist France and Fascist Britain. The addition of a great many decisions and random events based on historical context--for example reforming the Holy Roman Empire or Byzantium--keep each game fresh and new. And that's nothing to speak of the myriad of amazing mods, such as Kaiserreich (a mod based on a world where Germany won WWI), which make it into a brand new game, furthering the content available. Cons - HoI is beautiful, but it is also, at times, clunky. The game will run on lower-end PC's but the real-time clock's max speed will be dependant on your PC, and despite the wars themselves being delightful, the buildup to them, if your PC can't support the fastest speed, will take forever. Likewise, despite being very fun, HoI IV is not an easy game to jump into, and is needlessly overcomplicated at times. You can customize your units to a frightening degree, which is enjoyable for some, but unfortunately the uncustomized variants are quite weak so even if the customization isn't fun you are forced to slog through pages of internet guides to understand things like combat width and piercing to understand why you are losing instead of being fine with the premade ones. Additionally, the tutorial isn't very helpful, so you will once again require the internet's help to understand naval or air battles. Lastly, though big powers like Germany or France have exciting custom choices, secondary powers like Austria or Ireland do not, and if there even IS an exciting tree it often requires the DLC. All-in-all I would highly recommend HoI IV to anyone who loves historical strategy games, warfare simulators, or just Paradox in general. However, I will add the word of caution: Be prepared to spend your first 2-3 games utterly confused and scouring the internet for help, as well as a good bit of money on the expansions needed to make the game more fun for you (depending on the countries you are more interested in).

It's quite complex and you need many hours of playtime to even start playing. I find it rephrensible, that you need the Waking the Tiger DLC to get more manpower fast, otherwise you'd have to wait multiple years between wars, so you can get some manpower back. I really enjoyed the experience and still do. There are some critical flaws like the one I mentioned, if you just have the base game. It's actually really surprising, but you need at least a mediocore device to play, since if multiple wars are going on, the performance managment is so bad that it starts to have large performance drops even on gaming PC's. You can kind of prevent that, if you turn like 3D Buildings etc. off, but the impact is small. Apart from the locked content and the performance drops, you can propably say that it is definetly in the top 10 strategy games of all time. It's very oversimplified, with frontlines and less micromanagment than in HOI1-3 and different in many other ways. What you could also point out, is that if you have a decent amount of playtime (like I do), you know many tricks and stuff like that, which makes some aspects of the game very easy. For example, if you have the Waking the Tiger DLC you have the option to annex a puppet state. For that, you need a set amount of points (which might differ in many occasions). What my point is, is that you can get those points by giving your puppet all your army equipment. And if you annex your puppet then, you get all your equipment back, since that's how it works. I don't think this was intentional, since there are many other options to get these points, but noone uses them because the named method overshadows them by a lot and there's no reason for you to do them. I personally find that a good thing, since you obviously don't have to take that option and you could just do it the harder way, if you don't want to abuse game mechanics. SO, If you like strategy games like EU4 or Victoria (for whatever reason), it's definetly something for you. Some game mechanics are badly thought out and some important content might be locked behing a DLC pay-wall (Not nearly as bad as EU4 tho), but I'd definetly recommed you to buy it. I might have exclusively listed negative points, but that's just because there are too many positive ones and I'm lazy. So don't get me wrong, I think HOI4 is absolutely amazing and it's worth your money.

This will be my first ever review on steam, so I might as well make it spicy. Hearts of Iron IV in my opinion is a great game, it is easier to understand imo than other Paradox games like Europa Universalis IV and so on. Does that mean those other games are better? No, does that mean HOI4 is better? Not at all. Gaming can often be subjective in terms of if a game is good or not and we often overlook that when we come to a conclusion about a video game. Hearts of Iron IV is one of those games where you can fall in love with all it's mechanics, or the fact that you can restore a monarchist Germany in 1936. The game has options in terms of alternative history that I can appreciate quite a lot. There are also a lot of things that Paradox needs to do that is quite obviously missing from their games. The Focus Trees. Some are good, most are ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, and it's up to random people who enjoy the game to come up with better ones than the devs for this game. Oh, Road to 56 has focuses that don't take 70 days? Steal that! Oh, all these other mods for our game have Focus trees that are way more in depth for even minor countries? Steal that! The best focus trees in the game are mainly with the major powers, EXCEPT ITALY WHY TF ARE THEY NOT GIVING ITALY A NEW TREE THEY COULD OF HAD A PERFECT DLC BUT NO. POLAND. Poland is the country that gets a rework to the focus tree instead of Italy, a major country in WW2. Yes, makes perfect sense Paradox. Continue to disappoint us. Please. On this topic, why tf does Spain have an autobiography for a focus tree before major powers get good ones? Also who tf gives a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• about Portugal in this game? The only good thing about any of these two countries in HOI4 is to form Iberia with a MOD. Mechanics. Just gonna skip this part because they're confusing but simple at the same time. Figure it out noobs. Time. This is probably the most important part of it. The time. You sit there for what feels like 10 hours trying to build up your country for the world war then you figure out that you just get steamrolled anyway. Is what I would say if I had 5 minutes in this game. But seriously, this game feels like it takes 20 years to get 1937 and that's one of my main pet peeves with Paradox games in general. You practically have to have some patience with this game just to do anything. Actually, I think that's it? Can't remember what else to complain about other than this game has the worst multiplayer capabilities since Fallout 76. Oh have all your settings to the lowest possible? Yeah your computer is just not gonna give the game enough memory to run so you're gonna be lagging behind the entire time and get kicked from multiplayer games you try to play. Have fun with that. Hope you all enjoy my ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• post of a review. Might do more for other games. Don't know. Anyhow, lick my balls, get good, stay positive #cancelcancelculture uh mr. mustache man did nothing wrong, what other cringe ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• can I say? Ok bye.

The frontline AI will decide to shuffle provinces randomly due to one single change and cause the entire thing to collapse Unit AI will retreat inwards toward the enemy for no reason and annihilate themselves. AI will retreat from fortified positions for no reason despite having organization and strength still remaining. The AI NEVER runs out of manpower. EVER. It's a mechanic that purely affects the player and does not affect the AI AT ALL. Experience, both for units and for generals is completely broken and hasn't been fixed in years; Units will fight from 1939 to 1945 and not achieve veterancy - oftentimes regressing back to merely being "trained", while your generals will achieve many crushing Naval victories over and over again and never gain enough experience to train a single positive trait. The game was released early as a not-early-access thing, was incomplete and has been given $20 expansion packs that add features that should have been included in the base game. You can't stop enemy units from retreating from ports by parking your fleet outside-- their transports simply go through unimpeded; The only way to have a chance of stopping them is to order your fleets on an abstracted "raid convoy" mission, which is unreliable and only catches a few ships at a time. To the inverse, when you're moving your army across an ocean with a direct escort of ships, enemy submarines will attack your convoy and your fleet won't be able to intervene because you're not using the stupid abstracted mission order -- but if you DO use the order, your ships spread out across the entire sea sector and will sail from wherever the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• they are to intervene whenever submarines appear, instead of escorting convoys directly. There's a good game under all these issues, but by god you have to fight tooth and nail against your own ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• AI or they will ruin everything. It's just so stressful that it sucks the fun out of the game. Oopsie your 50,000 manpower armored division of elite tanks and mechanised just retreated for no ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• reason into the enemy front line and annihilated itself XDDDD. It's so tiresome.

This game is phenomenal. It is such an incredible game that includes heartbreak, headache, joy, lust, friendship and maliciousness. This game is a roller coaster of a game that takes you through the main meaning behind why God put us on this Earth many years ago. I bought this game when I felt the lowest of lows in my life, and I came out feeling like a man. It taught me how to love, how to laugh and how to cry. You start the game as a cowardly, young, insufficient child that is just trying to find their way in life. They have to overcome various difficult obstacles that define who they are as a person and what they look for. Some of these obstacles include bear traps, wolves, bears, bear traps and most importantly, Bigfoot. Bigfoot is the polar opposite of the protagonist in this game. He is out for blood, he does not care for humanity but simply for his own survival. This to me defines how us a society struggle to appreciate the simple and beautiful things in life, and frankly the biggest obstacle the protagonist has to climb, is humanity. Bigfoot can teach all of us a lesson of how we should live our lives, he cares about himself and loves the feeling of nature's breeze through his precious hair. What is that feeling overall? Freedom. I feel that by the end of the game, you as the protagonist will come to a junction that will define whether you have changed morally as a human. Throughout this game, you are attempting to hunt Bigfoot because that is what you believe will make you fit in with the public, clearly overcome with peer pressure. Finally, after many hours of tearing through his health bar, it all comes to a stop. You are finally presented with the option to capture Bigfoot, become like every other ungrateful human in this Earth, or you can let him go. This moment is beautiful in the game. The sun shines onto Bigfoot's face as you see a tear trickle down his soft cheeks. It makes him look human. This is the moment that defines the weak boys, to strong and independent men. Free Bigfoot and you yourself have been freed from the experience and pressure of social norms. This is a fantastic game, I wish for everyone on this Earth to spend their money and buy it. It taught me such an important lesson in life, and if there is anything I have learnt from Bigfoot, it is that you should appreciate the beauty of life and live it to the fullest. Thank you, Fernandes

After over 1200 hours playing this game, I should probably review it lol Hoi4 is a grand strategy game that takes place during WW2. You can play as basically any nation that existed back then, and even as some that didn't. Hoi4 can seem complicated at first, but it doesn't take too long to get used to it. The basic game mechanics of Hoi4 work quite well. The actions you take are mainly guided by your focus tree. Important nations have custom focus trees, while more irrelevant ones have a basic focus tree. The focus tree includes stuff like getting more factories, demanding land, getting war goals (which allow you to start wars), starting a civil war etc. Custom focus trees have both a historical route, and one or many non-historical routes. You can restore the Kaiserreich as Germany, create the EU, restore Austria Hungary or the Ottoman Empire and so on. Many of the things done through focuses can also be done without them, such as by manually justifying war goals, building more factories etc but the focus trees (usually) give you the things for free. The focus trees are generally speaking good, although Italy and the USSR suffer from having quite poor focus trees, although that will probably be fixed in the future. The USSR is already getting a new focus tree in the next DLC. The political aspect of the game is quite simple. Ideologies are divided into four distinct ones, being democracy, fascism, communism and non-alignment. This allows the political aspect to be simple and intuitive. Countries accumulate a thing called political power over time. Different nations get it at different rates, depending on different modifiers. Pp can be used for many things such as decisions, justifying wars, getting military high command (which give modifiers to your military), design companies which give boosts to research and the stats of specific equipment, and political advisors which boost different things such as political power gain, construction speed etc. The pp system is simple and effective. There are also spy agencies, but I won't go over that here. It's relatively simple and I personally like it. You also must manage your construction (constructing civilian or military factories, infrastructure, naval dockyards, airfields, forts, you name it) and your production (producing your equipment such as guns, artillery, tanks, planes, boats etc). This system is extremely simple, although managing your naval construction can be a nuissance at times. Now, let's get into the part that actually matters: gameplay. When at war, there are a lot of things to keep track of if you want to do well, but you can also let the AI do everything for you, which is less effective but saves you time. Training new troops is simple and you can modify their division template (which essentially dictates what the division has in it and in turn affects what equipment they need and also their stats) or create new ones. Actually managing troops is also quite simple. Divisions go under generals, who go under field marshals. With base traits a general can control 24 divisions without getting any debuffs, and a field marshal can control 5 generals. These can be upgraded to 30 and 7 respectively. Your field marshals and generals gain experience as they fight, which improves their passive modifiers (damage, defense, planning and supply consumption) and also gives you points to use on giving them different traits which give more specific buffs. You can give different orders to generals and field marshals and then either let them execute the orders by themselves, or micromanage your troops to, for example, encircle enemy divisions much more effectively. You also have air and naval combat. Air combat is relatively simple. You manufacture planes, which you then send on different missions. The map is divided into air zones, and you assign your planes on specific air zones for a specific task (or tasks) such as air superiority, ground support, interception, bombing etc. Naval combat is the least important of the three, but by far the most annoying. The naval combat was almost entirely redone in the Man the Guns DLC, and while it is better, it still isn't good. Managing your ships is annoying and confusing, sometimes your ships just don't want to do what you want to tell them to etc. The game doesn't have too many bugs, but it does have some minor and some more major ones, although many of them are the exploity type and won't affect you as a player negatively. This was quite a surface level overview of Hoi4 and it is much deeper than this, but this should be a decent basic overview. I really enjoy Hoi4 as should be obvious from my hours. It has its good and bad sides of course, but in general it's a very good game if you like grand strategy and history.

Paradox masterpiece! After playing HOI4 for over a thousand hours by now it still doesn't get boring. It's one of Paradoxs best games released and should continue being fun for a long time. For newcomers to the strategy genre it's probably the easiest game to pick up amongst all Paradox titles. While still being very in-depth it offers an easy basic mechanics system that's understandable after playing with it for a few hours. Mastering it provides a real challenge and even I don't know about every little aspect with more to come with a usual DLC or major update once or twice a year. What makes the game so special is it's complexity, the interesting and to a certain level very diverse battle and warfare methods (the best in any strategy game by far), and the freedom you enjoy when it comes to how you want your games to turn out. This freedom is supported by the biggest strength Paradox games enjoy: Their compatibility with mods and the integration within the small but dedicated community. Mods are fairly easy to create compared to most other games but provide a decent amount of flexibility and creativity with a very wide range of possibilities. You can create your very personal games based on what the player wants focus on. To sum it up: Pros: - "Easy" to learn for newcomers, a real challenge to master - Freedom of play, alternative history (focus trees, decisions, events)... - Awesome community, surprisingly good youtubers/streamers - large variety of mods, active support and modding scene, easily moddable - Regularly updated - Bug free (If you don't care about some exploits and meta strategies) - Interesting warfare mechanics - Competitive on less speed/reflex focused basis Negatives: - Not as politically challenging as f.ex. EUIV or CK3 (if you need it) - Some harder to understand mechanics - Pricey DLCs (always wait for holidays/sale's before you buy) - Games are sometimes unplayable after around 8 years (Division spam, no new Focuses,... = Mods are your friend and a good PC too) - Multiplayer servers are usually unstable when playing with a lot of players

A solid game and my personal favorite when it comes to PDX grand strategy titles. It's got a steep learning curve and the very short tutorial won't be enough to teach you how to win a campaign.However once you get over that initial hurdle, it's a one of a kind game with no direct competitor. So if you want to steer a nation to victory during the greatest conflict in human history then this is it. It has massively improved over previous iterations to make it more approachable to new players and every major update brings solid improvements to its mechanics. While the AI struggles to play the game and can fail spectacularly at times, it does an acceptable job and deserve more credit than it gets. Yet, after a hundred hours or so it should no longer really challenge you once you figure out building up and optimizing your units. Multiplayer has its share of issues as you will no longer be able to play at your own pace and you have to find people who can play for hours on end without rage quitting. The MP meta is rather strange but the game has competitive potential and a high experience ceiling. Many mechanics such as intelligence, occupation management, ship designer, general traits and certain tactics are gated behind Paradox's DLC scheme sadly; at their full price they are very much overpriced given the persisting bugs and unsolved balancing issues that PDX is well aware of but ignores. Playing without some of these mechanics is doable but can become tedious and frustrating. Same as the base title, I would recommend you avoid buying any of these DLCs at full price as it's completely unreasonable to pay over 150‚Ç¨ for the full package imo, especially considering the quality of some DLCs. It's not as bad as EU4 in that respect but in time it may catch up to it as DLC locked features are added in, with the base game straying further and further from what the current version is actually balanced for. The modding community is absolutely amazing with big names such as RT56 or Kaiserreich which completely overhaul the game, definitely worth checking out. However, at 50% off or better this game is a steal and hours of fun if you like managing large fronts, industrial production and waging war across continents: 8/10 Best of its kind but suffers from poor play-testing and flawed DLC model.

So many hours in this game but I'm not quite sure what to say. I have a good group of friends to play with and thats where most of my hours come from. Don't get me wrong it's been tons of fun, but I can't overlook the rather lackluster content that has been put out. A DLC for an espionage system thats meh? A DLC that adds 2 focuses for 2 minor nations? The vanilla game becomes very boring after not very long. Thats where mods come in. If this game didn't have the modding community it did I wouldn't even recommend this game or have nearly the same hours. There are so many different mods that one review couldn't do them justice. Playing multiplayer with friends and mods is what has kept me playing. I hope in the future the base game has more content, but as it stands it really doesn't. Despite the issues with the game I've had too much fun to not recommend. If you can find a group of people to play multiplayer with then I highly recommend.

I decided to try this game after having over 275+ hours in Crusader Kings 3, I know this game would be more challenging while keeping some of the same paradox mechanics. Boy was I wrong. This game has little in common with both Crusader Kings and EU4. to get into this game you must spend hours watching tutorial videos just to understand the basics of the game. the in game tutorial is terrible, especially to new players. It throws you into the fire with little to no help on how to use the UI, or any of the control buttons. With all this being said, the game is very fun once you understand how to play. If you are new to grand strategy games, I strongly recommend to NOT start with this game, Playing all three major games by paradox I think Crusader Kings is by far the easiest to understand.

I am a HOI 1, 2, & 3 player. I was initially turned off by the steep learning curve  on HOI4 and no really go beginners scenario to learn the game. When my previous laptop died I was forced to try HOI4 (which I bought several years ago) because HOI3 would not run on my new laptop.  I have over 300 hours of HOI4 under my belt now.  I do like the game.  I feel I am getting my money's worth now.  I REALLY wish there was a downloadable PDF manual. I REALLY wish there was a MUCH BETTER learner's scenario.  If you buy it get everything. If you buy it BE PERSISTENT.  But buy it.

If you love grand strategy and Alternate history then Hoi4 is the perfect game for you. This game starts in 1936 where you can choose from many different countries and guide them through the war. What I especially love about this game is that you don't have to play your country historically, for example you can restore the Kaiser as Germany or install Edward VIII as your ruler when playing Britain. I've had over 1,000 hours of fun with this game and I hope that the person reading this can also have as much fun with this game.

Great game, I highly recommend it if you are into history and grand strategy games. Heads up though this game will appear very complicated at first but don't lose interest because this is a great game.

First, a disclaimer: this game is COMPLICATED. I had never really played something like it before (spare Plague Inc., which is kind of similar), and it was a source of frustration for the many hours I tried to understand how to play. Please watch some playthroughs on YouTube first, as it can get incredibly overwhelming fast if you don't know what you're doing. With that being said, this game is awesome. I bought it specifically for the Old World Blues mod, as I'm a massive Fallout fan. However, playing it in "vanilla" is amazing as well. I'm a bit of a World War II nut, and this delivered, 100%. The skill and focus trees, the weapons, the events, I love it all. The only complaint that I really have is that the music is awfully repetitive, at least for my tastes. I usually turn the volume all the way down on my computer and just listen to my own tunes with my headphones, connected to my phone. I hope this review was decent, as the only other review I've put on this site (at least, to my knowledge) was for Skyrim when I was ten. Luckily I can spell better now.

Honestly, after playing around 2 years of this game, I can easily say this is perfect for strategy gamers out there. I love the fact you can invade nations and take over the world in WW2. It's pretty easy to learn and is extremely fun when you know what to do. What I find not so good about this is that the downloadable content (dlcs) is way overpriced. Another thing I don't like about the game is the lack of content for some nations, especially in Central America and South America. Other than that, the game is fun and engaging. You could spend all day immersed in everything in it. Just get the game and content on a sale, like I did.

The base game is pretty dull in my opinion, BUT the modding community (in particular the Kaiserreich and Old World Blues mod teams) are absolutely amazing, and make the game worth playing even with no DLC. As with all Paradox games, the gameplay is drastically improved by the incredibly overpriced DLC, but unlike many of them it's not half as necessary to buy *all* of them to feel like you have a complete game. I've spent a hideous amount of my life on this game, and you can too!

The base game is alright and has steadily improved since release but the lack of content takes its toll on vanilla after a couple playthroughs. The real selling point of this game is the incredible work being done by the modding community. Kaiserreich - for alternate history fans Old World Blues - for Fallout or post-apocalyptic fans Road to 56 - for people who want an improved base game experience The New Order - for people who enjoy suffering Equestria at War - for people who enjoy psychological horror The list goes on for major overhaul mods with a staggering amount of content. For context a lot of what makes each nation special is their focus tree which they use to shape and evolve the country. As today, May 28th, 2021, if you own *all* of the DLC then there are 33 countries with unique focus trees in the base game, some being much worse than others (looking at you, Italy). Meanwhile Kaiserreich has over 90 unique focus trees for the starting date and many more from countries spawning via events as the game progresses. You can spend hundreds of hours playing through different countries on many of these overhaul mods and still have only experienced a fraction of what they have to offer. If you do buy HoI4 there's almost certainly at least one overhaul mod that appeals to you that will draw you in more than just sticking with vanilla would. tl;dr - HoI4 is a decent game but it's a better framework for modders to build on than anything else.
