This is a splendid game - I have hundreds and hundreds of hours playing at this point. I'm essentially reviewing this game with all of the available content DLCs (and none of the nonsensical sprite packs, which just aren't worth money to me), so be aware of that (and know that my recommendation is to wait and buy on heavy discount for the base game and the DLCs!) Let me put it this way... I was determined in my latest game that I would play a Mexico that would choose a "middle path," side with the United States after demanding oil concessions, and essentially be a good ancillary power in the war against the threats to world peace. Well, I'd turned off "historical settings" (but had ironman on), so things can go fairly ahistorically - they did! The Balkans formed a "Balkan Entente" under Romania, while the German Wehrmacht overthrew Adolf Hitler, re-establishing the Kaiserreich in Germany, the authority of the Habsburgs in Austria, Hungary, and the Czech-Slovak lands, and Victor Immanuel in Italy. The Japanese, meanwhile, were victorious in a swift war against China that concluded with a bid to invade the Soviet Union after the Soviets invaded (and took) the Baltic States and Poland. Japan's deep thrust into Soviet territory paid off in a declaration of war from the German Empire - the Kaiser's troops victoriously conquered Moscow and Leningrad in mid-1942 and the Germans divided the Soviet Union with Japan. Meanwhile, however, the French Republic under Leon Blum had failed in its effort to achieve rapprochement with the Communists, who overthrew Blum and installed Maurice Thorez as leader - apparently the geostrategic threat of Germany and Japan leading the British to maintain good relations with the new Communist regime. The Americans, however, would have none of this - despite the dramatic expansion of Japan in East Asia, and German aggression in Soviet Russia, the Americans declared war on none other than the Communists in France! Mexico? My Mexico saw reconciliation with Plutarcho Calles and the continuation of the revolutionary land reform efforts so central to Zapata's revolution - this meant that the Caudillos were bound to revolt, which happened in due time. The revolt of the Caudillos was suppressed with some effort while Mexico continued its slow climb toward economic and military relevancy on the global scale. The American declaration of war gave the Mexican government its opportunity to side with the Yanks against their enemies, but in the meantime, the Mexican people had requested that President Lazaro Cardenas fulfill his promises to the people of Mexico; he obliged: the Mexican Socialist Republic, a would-be staunch ally of the USA, emerged as a powerful promise for freedom in the world - all for naught! The US had joined the Balkan Entente after its declaration of war - and faction leader Romania apparently had no tolerance for socialist allies! The Mexicans were duly booted from the alliance, but not because we'd declared war on Japan, dragging the entire alliance into a worldwide war that would force the Americans to defend the peoples of the Pacific - or to gave way to those that would. On our own, we were swiftly faced with the consequences of our increasing isolation as the resources that had poured into Mexico from democratic America now went preferentially to democratic-capitalist regimes in the Balkans, leaving Mexican factories starved of the inputs necessary to build a modern economy. As per usual, the capitalists were aligning themselves such as to exclude a democratically-elected people's government from surviving without the political and economic dominance of imperialist powers - only one alternative lay open to the democratic Socialist Republic of Mexico - a preemptive strike south supported by years of slow and patient investment in fortresses along the northern border. Unsurprisingly, this strike left the Americans in a position of obligation that led to war between our two nations, despite the peaceful initial intentions of the Mexican government. Sadly, the Yanks had already committed the bulk of their land forces to a life-or-death struggle against the French and British that now raged across Central Europe and the Balkans as the Germans and Italians suffered casualties reaching into the multiple tens of millions before falling before the forces of the combined British, French, Belgian, and Dutch forces. This left the southern border vulnerable at a time when the Americans had not anticipated aggression from the previously conciliatory Mexicans, whose careful palliation of the Church despite the socialist government had done much to mint a hardline revanchist mentality among the Mexican people, reminded now of the crimes of the war of 1848. Sensing opportunity, the Mexican military under command of Field Marshal Calles shattered the American lines; first in California, then Arizona, and finally blasting through the thin line of defending divisions remaining on American soil in Texas to send swift-moving cavalry and armored car divisons rampaging through an American countryside that had been thoroughly infiltrated by Mexican agents preparing a collaboratory regime. The campaign against America stretched for the better part of 12 months, but resulted in the complete capitulation of the government in Washington; remaining Americans forces under Patton are bottled up in Alaska, where local conditions have rendered an offensive difficult at this time. North America is largely secured and the prep work of Mexican agents has led to a quiescent and compliant populace, much which feels relieved at the sudden dramatic increases in infrastructure improvement and living standards, and which is fully prepared to contribute to a glorious future for the Mexican cause: for the the capitulation of the German-led Central Powers did not resolve conflict in the world, or even Europe. The Japanese invaded from their ever-more hardened strongholds in Asia and conquered the French and British alike and now have targeted North America for invasion. It is 1950, and this war has consumed countless lives, although relatively few of them Mexican. Can the Socialist Republic of Mexico survive? If you enjoy imagining and playing through these kinds of scenarios in a game, you'll love HOI4.

One of my favorite strategy games in my library. Hearts of Iron IV is a real time battle strategy game taking place in WWII in which you get to choose which nation you wish to play as  and then  you play starting from either 1936 or 1939 up to 1950 at which point the game ends. During this time you will have to manage everything a nation will need to fund a military and be succesful in a world war with such an army. This includes RnD, Managing internal politics through a focus tree and decisions, Constructing Civilian factorys and Military ones to get your the resources and supplys to both produce your army equipment as well as manufacture it, As well as designing your army from the ground up and then activily leading it both on the micro and macro.  The game has a steep learning curve and is very fun I am 1000 hours in and still learning. The base game has solid historical paths for all majors and some even have some good alternative roots. If you don't like mods the DLCS are quite nice as well as they can give you many ahistorical routes. (Kaiserreich Germany any one ?). However, what takes this game above and beyond and inspired me to write this review is the modding scene. The Mod community for this game is ridicoulous. If you ever wanted to role play a world through the lense of a strategy game then just buy this as their is a mod to scratch your itch. For example one of the greatest mods in the Oldworld blues mod in which you get to take control of one of hundreds of nations in and around the mojave. Most of these nations even have better focus trees then the ingame ones which is amazing. TLDR great real strat game would highly recommend.

No other game has ever let me both lead an Imperial Britain to reclaim the lost 13 colonies to the tune of the British Grenadiers, fulfilling my fantasies of a world where the USA doesn't exist - and lead a democratic United Kingdom to form the peaceful Commonwealth of Nations to bring unity and shared identity across a world to filled with division and strife, bringing it just a little bit more peace. The gameplay is full grand strategy. Very macro-oriented planning and thinking, which appeals to me. The historic setting only adds to my investment. The backbone of gameplay is incredibly competent and moddable, which is a backbone to the thing that really keeps bringing me back; the flavour of history, alt-history, and controlling grand flows of events from the perspective nations in both fictional and real conflicts. Try Old World Blues and The New Order, if ya like mods. What a silly game.

I love this game. For starters it is extremely fun to play both single player and multiplayer (although I would suggest to play with friends as it brightens the experience) and I love the depth and complexity to this game. I know that many people don‚Äôt like the dlc policy of paradox but I personally don‚Äôt mind dropping 10$ when a sale is going on for a new dlc which spices up the game. I also know that many people can‚Äôt afford these dlc‚Äôs even with the sale but the game is still fun without them! (But the experience is best with them.) If you are not sure if you want to buy the game you can always watch a YouTube video and see if it is worth your time and money. The game is very complicated and I personally have spent around 2 hours just watching tutorials about certain aspects of the game, but when you plow through your enemies lines with your armor spear head it is almost always worth your time. All in all I would personally give this game a 10/10 and is my favorite game!

This game saved my life. I am 27. My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old. When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide. After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side. Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay. After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as. Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends. I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together. Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that. Thank you Paradox Interactive

I didn't see myself writing a negative review to one of paradox's grand strategies... and yet, here we are. - I can kinda look past being ridiculously easy to trick AI and exploit its behaviors. - I am annoyed by AI generally leaving huge swaths of territory completely undefended, but that's why it can amass twice as many troops on your border. - I am irritated by AI completely ignoring supply and airfield caps, i build myself a small air field, for 400 planes, and here come 500 brits and 150 canadians to the rescue, dropping my mission efficiency to one third. - There is much more of a limit to what you can play in Europe and still have an interesting game then it seems. As long as you show any sign of hostility towards Italy or Germany their troops will be pretty much all on your border when the scripted path to fall of France begins. And by the time Germans haul their butts back to their west border UK will land 100 divisions in Belgium. But all this was expected, even if to nowhere near as bad of a degree. Writing good AI is hard. Now the unforgivable part, the scoring, war contributions and the peace treaty. Which makes any game completely ****** after the first peace is signed. Arbitrary game score doesn't bother me much, it just looks stupid that air force takes 80+% of it. 200 for 200 industrial capacity and then 1200 for 12000 air superiority score. In comparison your 150 divisions are worth 22. Doesn't really affect the game, but it looks stupid. And its indicative of a larger problem. War contribution score... the game killer. There are 4 categories : Occupation: Makes sense, except Soviets get score for taking eastern Poland in a war score against Germans. Strategic Bombing: Sure, why not, it has a cap so it doesn't break anything Sunk Enemy Ships: It has some effect, nowhere near as it should, and also sinking a carrier or a battleship is worth exactly as much as sinking a destroyer or a submarine. Tonnage anyone? And last and most atrocious - Casualties: Basically if you're warring against Japan's faction, you can't beat Chinese war score, because they lost 10 million troops and whatever you did can't come nowhere near that score. Same with Soviets wasting 7M+ troops against Germans. Then comes peace, the German Reich is done for... except, its still on the map, its still at war with everyone, usually accompanied by Slovakia. Soviets will take some beaches in southern France, maybe a Mediterranean island or 2, and Madagascar also seems popular. Italy for some reason, never having switched sides can make demands. As can Austria. I get an option as 4th highest score (lost only 250k troops) to liberate Czechoslovakia, only Slovakia still exists and i can just liberate a single core province leaving everything else squarely in German Reich. France fell, so it doesn't have much of a score, so it will lose half its territory to Soviets, UK and the likes + all colonial holdings... Enough of an example, looks like someone made a failed random map mod and implemented it as a peace treaty tool. I can't understand how you even gave a system in this bad of a state to your QA for preliminary testing, let alone released it. 5 Expansions and 12 DLCs later, its still completely broken. And in the state its in now, there is no way it worked as intended even once, so you were fully aware it is broken. And you just did not care. Had to make those DLCs, hey? Rant over, Former Fan

I absolutely recommend this game to anyone who is interested, it is a masterpiece in the arts of Nation Building and rising up the ranks in world powers which I find to be very interesting as well as this game has a huge collection of mods that are insanely easy to download to where a 4 year old could download any mod for HOI4, the mods for HOI4 range from alternate history scenarios where the game takes place in a different setting like World War 1, Modern Day, The Cold War and also ther is a mod called Kaiserreich and it is a WW2 scenario like the vanilla version of the game but it is a WW2 scenario where Germany and the rest of the Central Powers won WW1 which they didn't historically for the people who aren't history lovers which I'm pretty sure you will become one if you want this game. A fantastic game all around with a lot of things to do, I highly recommend watching a few videos of people playing HOI4 to see if you are truly interested in buying this game. But from me I'll tell you that I have nothing but good things to say about this game and the community it possesses . . . A great game of grand strategy, also the greatest scam I could witness by myself, and I did work for an insurance company. If you never played any games like this one, don‚Äôt expect to see tanks shooting at each other, you will mostly stare at maps filled with small symbols for hours that represent your frontlines clashing against other units. Heart of iron is mostly a game about logistics and calculation, but you will probably get overwhelmed by the daunting amount of things to think about, and forget about most of them. I, for example, didn‚Äôt know I had a navy to manage until at least 100 of hours in. But I still had fun making sure that Fascist Tibet would backstab China and be the true Asian overlord. There‚Äôs two fun parts in that game, micro managing units, and doing unexpected things, like preventing that German moustache-wearing guy to invade half of Europe by invading him first in 1936, in the name of whatever nowadays-irrelevant ideology they used to believe in back then. Once you did win WW2 as intended, or did rewrite history once or two, the game could get stale, do not worry, because the base game is hard to understand, but quite lacking, and there‚Äôs a big pile of dlc for you to buy to fill the void and unlock the (overpriced) content (that should have been in the base game). And then once you clear that content, do not worry! Because the modding community got your back. Utopia, Dystopia, Historical, Star Wars, Post-apocalyptic, Anime, Ponies, whatever you want, a modding team or a basement living made it, and most of the time, they do a better job at it than the base game devs. You will certainly feel bad for buying those overpriced dlcs, but it‚Äôs fine, because every mechanics added are put to a good use in most mods. Also, buy the base game first, see if you can understand it before buying the dlcs, and buy them on sales. Don‚Äôt be an idiot with your money. Or give it to me so I can also be an idiot with your money.

The first review was after 24 hours of play.  It was full of frustration and disappointment.  There is still a fair bit of that left in the game. The principle argument I have against it still stands.  Too many of the critical game concepts are too opaque.  In particular, the way the AI fights your battles is how I would expect someone on LSD would fight it.  I am orders of magnitude more effective directing forces myself.  For example, An automated battle on the Malaysian peninsula  had the AI endlessly shuffling divisions, creeping up the peninsula despite a vast quantitative and qualitative advantage.  After letting it do its thing for a month, it made it 1/3 of the way up.  I took over and in 3 weeks went all the way up the peninsula to Bankok and up to Rangoon. Additionally, Front line fighting units (other than capital ships) never seem to gain experience beyond their training.  Either  the experience gain from winning is too low or the experience loss for even very minor casualties is too high, but it should be fixed.  A unit that has been fighting and winning for 3 years should achieve at least one more level of experience. There is a fair number of things to like about the game.  Division building is interesting and you can customize in more ways than you will ever want.  Organizing armies and fleets is very easy as well. But again, the opacity of game concepts makes for a learning curve that borders on not worth it.  You will become reliant on non-developer information to make any headway in this regard, which is really not a very good way to develop a game. I eliminated the DLC for espionage.  Not worth the added trouble.  The naval game is still uncooperative at times.  Much like the automated armies, fleets do some unpredictable and weird things on occasion.  Not sure if the is connected to the Man The Guns DLC as I have not played without that yet. The research, development and upgrade system is quite good along with how factories work.  They work hand in hand quite well, although production penalties for upgrading to a new model are a bit stiff.  It's still a good system that lets you chart an industrial plan. Some issues with the way the UI works; it's easy to make horrible mistakes. Overall,  if it goes on a big sale again, you might want to give it a shot.  At full price, this is a pass as while it has some really nice features, it isn't the total game HOI2 was. EDIT: I am changing this from a not recommended to recommended.  I am still playing it after all these hours so there must be something there.  I would still wait for it to go on sale and my other comments still stand, so if you are a grand wargame grognard, you will probably enjoy this, eventually, if you don't set your hair on fire first.

No ressources, no big army, not an important strategic location. and there aren't really any Diplomatic options all the "Diplomatic options" are either forced thrue focus trees , or its simple improve relations/non aggression treaty etc and then theres also the fact that you can be on the max amount of relation with a nation and they still will join a war against u if some bum‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• nation declares war on you and they are in the same faction. It's really a shame this game would be great if you were not forced to fight the entire world everytime and it simply makes this a global domination game. HOI game play is 99% preparation. Create a logistical supply line and design units that min max against the AI's script. The plus for HOI is that unlike a lot of "historical" games the AI players have been given a historical script so that Botswana doesn't randomly conquer the British isles ensuring a game that follows the proper historical beats. In addition you can endlessly tweak and adjust various units and plan complex operations. But that's where it's merits end. The AI doesn't have any reason for doing what it's doing beyond following the script. If the US doesn't block steel sales to Japan they still attack Pearl Harbor on schedule. If that were HOI's only problem it would still be recommendable. Vapid modern political propaganda makes this game un-recommendable. Socialism is presented as an opposing position to fascism when socialism/fascism/communism are ideologically identical in any meaningful way. The Devs paint WWII as a great socialist victory against fascism. To further this false opposition everything the Devs woke agenda opposes gets lumped into fascism. Deregulation? That's fascist. Gold standard? That's fascist. Privatized industry? That's fascist. Ending the Great Depression through means other than socialism? That's fascist. Religion? That's fascist. Most bizarrely the Confederacy from the US Civil war gets branded as fascist. HOI is childishly arrogant in its mindless assertions. If you can ignore this you are left with lots of surface area grind and busy work leading up to brief bouts of very shallow gameplay.

1:1. In the beginning God created heaven, and earth. 1:2. And the earth was void and empty, and darkness was upon the face of the deep; and the spirit of God moved over the waters. 1:3. And God said: Be light made. And light was made. 1:4. And God saw the light that it was good; and he divided the light from the darkness. 1:5. And he called the light Day, and the darkness Night; and there was evening and morning one day. 1:6. And God said: Let there be a firmament made amidst the waters: and let it divide the waters from the waters. A firmament... By this name is here understood the whole space between the earth, and the highest stars. The lower part of which divideth the waters that are upon the earth, from those that are above in the clouds. 1:7. And God made a firmament, and divided the waters that were under the firmament, from those that were above the firmament, and it was so. 1:8. And God called the firmament, Heaven; and the evening and morning were the second day. 1:9. God also said; Let the waters that are under the heaven, be gathered together into one place: and let the dry land appear. And it was so done. 1:10. And God called the dry land, Earth; and the gathering together of the waters, he called Seas. And God saw that it was good. 1:11. And he said: let the earth bring forth green herb, and such as may seed, and the fruit tree yielding fruit after its kind, which may have seed in itself upon the earth. And it was so done. 1:12. And the earth brought forth the green herb, and such as yieldeth seed according to its kind, and the tree that beareth fruit, having seed each one according to its kind. And God saw that it was good. 1:13. And the evening and the morning were the third day. 1:14. And God said: Let there be lights made in the firmament of heaven, to divide the day and the night, and let them be for signs, and for seasons, and for days and years: 1:15. To shine in the firmament of heaven, and to give light upon the earth, and it was so done. 1:16. And God made two great lights: a greater light to rule the day; and a lesser light to rule the night: and the stars. Two great lights... God created on the first day, light, which being moved from east to west, by its rising and setting, made morning and evening. But on the fourth day he ordered and distributed this light, and made the sun, moon, and stars. The moon, though much less than the stars, is here called a great light, from its giving a far greater light to the earth than any of them. 1:17. And he set them in the firmament of heaven to shine upon the earth. 1:18. And to rule the day and the night, and to divide the light and the darkness. And God saw that it was good. 1:19. And the evening and morning were the fourth day. 1:20. God also said: let the waters bring forth the creeping creature having life, and the fowl that may fly over the earth under the firmament of heaven. 1:21. And God created the great whales, and every living and moving creature, which the waters brought forth, according to their kinds, and every winged fowl according to its kind. And God saw that it was good. 1:22. And he blessed them, saying: Increase and multiply, and fill the waters of the sea: and let the birds be multiplied upon the earth. 1:23. And the evening and morning were the fifth day. 1:24. And God said: Let the earth bring forth the living creature in its kind, cattle and creeping things, and beasts of the earth, according to their kinds. And it was so done. 1:25. And God made the beasts of the earth according to their kinds, and cattle, and every thing that creepeth on the earth after its kind. And God saw that it was good. 1:26. And he said: Let us make man to our image and likeness: and let him have dominion over the fishes of the sea, and the fowls of the air, and the beasts, and the whole earth, and every creeping creature that moveth upon the earth. Let us make man to our image... This image of God in man, is not in the body, but in the soul; which is a spiritual substance, endued with understanding and free will. God speaketh here in the plural number, to insinuate the plurality of persons in the Deity. 1:27. And God created man to his own image: to the image of God he created him: male and female he created them. 1:28. And God blessed them, saying: Increase and multiply, and fill the earth, and subdue it, and rule over the fishes of the sea, and the fowls of the air, and all living creatures that move upon the earth. Increase and multiply... This is not a precept, as some Protestant controvertists would have it, but a blessing, rendering them fruitful; for God had said the same words to the fishes, and birds, (ver. 22) who were incapable of receiving a precept. 1:29. And God said: Behold I have given you every herb bearing seed upon the earth, and all trees that have in themselves seed of their own kind, to be your meat: 1:30. And to all beasts of the earth, and to every fowl of the air, and to all that move upon the earth, and wherein there is life, that they may have to feed upon. And it was so done. 1:31. And God saw all the things that he had made, and they were very good. And the evening and morning were the sixth day. Genesis Chapter 2 God resteth on the seventh day and blesseth it. The earthly paradise, in which God placeth man. He commandeth him not to eat of the tree of knowledge. And formeth a woman of his rib. 2:1. So the heavens and the earth were finished, and all the furniture of them. 2:2. And on the seventh day God ended his work which he had made: and he rested on the seventh day from all his work which he had done. He rested, etc... And he blessed the seventh day, and sanctified it: because in it he had rested from all his work which God created and made. 2:4. If you've never played a paradox game before, Hearts of Iron 4 might be a little tedious to get the hang of but it is by no means a very hard game. It's very micro-intensive probably more so than the previous game Hearts of Iron 3. It is by far my favorite grand strategy WW2 game (and other scenarios with mods) and is definitely a better game than the first. Pros: -More user-friendly UI than HOI3 -More user-friendly trading system and resource management -Better industrial system than the previous game allowing you to build specific factories in certain states -Revamped construction mechanics that feel more natural. -Fuel and oil management doesn't feel too hard but adds a challenge -Nice supply system that is incorporated with tiles and infrastructure that allow for devastating encirclement maneuvers -Smaller unit of distance called a tile that allows for more precise troop movement and smaller encirclements -Newer game with more modern code and engine, more stability. -Better decisions mechanic -Amazing modding community with diverse and high-quality mods that can add some freshness to the game Cons: -No money mechanic like in the previous game, everything is based upon industry, trade, and equipment. -AI can be very stupid at times which is bad because your allies will be at a disadvantage and your enemy will feel too stupid and easy -Some small nations or minors do not have fully customized focus trees and makes players lean towards more major powers to get a better gameplay experience -Game gets extremely laggy as time progresses about 5-10 years. -Some mechanics or bugs allow some players to claim the game is too easy and not realistic enough and other players to claim it is too hard and too realisitic -AI peace deals can make your world look like somebody threw up on a canvas (can be fixed with mods) -Extremely expensive if you buy the major expansion DLC which is basically required to have a great experience with this game. (over 120$) and in my opinion the base-game is very overpriced.

This game is can be very fun at times but also very buggy at times. It is highly recommended that DLCs are installed. Mods also are recommended, they can really spice up gameplay (especially mods like Endsieg, Thousand Week Reich, Kaiserreich, and overhaul mods such as WW2 Rebalanced, World War Bruh, and Total War). The game most definitely has a learning curve and will take time to have a good grasp on its content/ mechanics. Some things that I don't like are how often the game tends to crash in the late game, and also how the late game (1942 and onwards) gets extremely slow, but this is a personally issue. This game is very CPU heavy, RAM, SSD and GPU do not matter much. FPS can get below 30 sometimes but it is not a deal breaker for me. All in all, it is a very fun game and is even better with the right people, specs, and mods. It is worth the buy.

I didn't think I would enjoy this game - but this game has quickly become one of my favorite strategy games - most of the DLC is overpriced, but the DLC expansion packs are more than worth it when the game and its DLC go on sale. (and it goes on sale often as well) Its a difficult game to learn, but once you understand how to play the game it's a joy to play and see all of the different paths you can take for a large number of nations. If you like History and grand strategy, this game is for you. Some of the things you can do in this game are: - Restore the Kaiser as Germany - Restore the Ottoman Empire as Turkey - Communist America - Fascist England - Restore the Roman Empire as Italy - Restore the Holy Roman Empire as Germany - The Second American Civil War - Restore the Byzantine Empire OR the Macedonian Empire as Greece - Restore the Austro-Hungarian Empire - Restore the Shogunate - Pretend to hate Jews ironically. - play as Luxembourg and try not to die. - Restore the United Kingdom of Portugal and Brazil - Be the Soviet Union and do communist things - Make Communist Netherlands - Genocide the Kurds - Turn Mexico into a Catholic Crusade in the Americas - etc. etc. There are TONS of great ways to play this game, even if the game is vanilla. There are also a whole bunch of awesome mods on the workshop that add so much value to this game, such as a Fallout mod and a World War 1 mod. I would recommend this game (Especially its DLC) when it goes on sale however, the sales come often and it makes the DLC for the game much more fairly priced. DLC I would recommend you get (ON SALE) first if you enjoy the vanilla experience: - Waking the Tiger: Adds TONS of fun to Germany, China, Japan and some other things. - Death or Dishonor: Lots of play value for England, Aussies, New Zealand, South Africa, India and others. - Together for Victory: Adds lots of options to the Balkan countries like Yugoslavia, Romania, Czechoslovakia, Hungary etc.

Hearts of Iron IV kind of breaks your brain. On its own as a base game, taken purely as face value, its an acceptable and interesting WW2 strategy game that you can get a good 100 hours of playing out of. The thing is, I'm really not so sure if HOI4's main draw *is* its vanilla experience. The core elements have been polished in DLC since the beginning launch and some new countries have gotten reworked focus tress but we all know the reason why this game is such a success, particularly on steam; the modding community and the workshop. The workshop produces content far superior to the base game and is the Kraby Patty Secret Forumuler to this game's longevity and the cult that surrounds it. I don't think thats unfair to say in 2021, where the game's core development seems to constantly be trailing the mod community and where the majority of players that haven't played Hoi4 are coming in to play a high profile mod. Okay, so, a strong mod community that creates great content for this game for free *should* be a draw right? And if you're just a run of the mill player it totally its. You're spoiled for choices even when using just the vanilla game sans DLC with thousands of hours ahead of you. But from the *modding* side itself, I can honestly say that HOI4 has the most hostile, obtuse, and unfriendly customization system compared to any other modern Paradox game. Its almost toxic with how inaccessible it is, which in itself contributes to a lot of the more aweful aspects of the mod community that's kept hidden from your base player. I've been on many a dev team thats abide literal, unironic nazis living out their Waffen-SS power fantasies for no other reason than because they understand the esoteric art of "how to make a focus tree and event chain that doesn't crash." And before I get accused of just not being good enough at learning, I've contributed to several mod teams in my time; this is a matter of how after five years of development we are no closer to having easily accessible customization options baked into the game. My point here is buyer beware; you've probably heard of this title from the amazing mods behind it, but actually creating these mods is a soul crushingly obtuse process compared to other Paradox Games, and a lot of the teams left that *are* able to produce content for this hell-ware are often of questionable morale fiber.

First forget about realism and intuitive approach. You need to watch several guides on land, air and naval warfare in order to play, the way game designers want you to play, as there is no other way to do things. Another issue is the lack of clear intuitive interface. I like to know what's going on when playing such a grand strategy but there seem to be a lack of proper reporting and overview on what's going on where. Sometimes you need to look for small indicators across the map (naval accidents), sometimes you will find report next to a theater window (land battle result). I wish there was a message system and settings similar to what was in EU3 in order to filter all the information you want to see and have it in one place. At the same time there's bunch of unnecessary game-pausing flavour pop-up screens giving useless info on events that do not have impact on gameplay whatsoever (Hindenbourg crash etc.) NAVY 1/10 - Forget historical composition and organization of your fleets! First thing you need to do, is to gather your fleet in one port in order to reorganize it (!) The way it work is that you need to have one fleet per task (riding fleet, escort fleet etc.) Historical organization of the fleet is not working even though at the start of the game you will have them neatly orgnized this way. Why? Because task forces in a fleet can't be assigned various missions to various regions. One fleet consisting of many task forces can operate on same set of regions - no point having versalite fleets as it is in real life. AIR FORCE 5/10 - the way air warfare work is better than navy - definitely more intuitive and simple. However! How are planes delivered across the globe when transitioning between airbases regardless their range, enemy controlled airspace, possible land and sea transport routes is beyond my comprehension. They simply go in a straight line across all enemy territories across continents and oceans. Seriously? LAND WARFARE - 7/10 Battle plans are nice idea but they're broken. The idea behind it was to enable you to give orders to your generals to prepare and execute battle plans so you don't have to manually micromanage every single division. In reality micromanage is what you will be doing most of the time anyway. Want your generals to perform spearhead maneuver? Forget it and do it yourself. ESPIONAGE 10/10 - Well executed feature - the best so far. Le Resistance is a must have DLC. DESIGNING DIVISIONS AND EQUIPMENT VARIANTS IN ORDER TO SEE HOW THEY PERFORM IN BATTLE - 10/10 I love and hate this game at the same time. Preparing for war is so cool - division designing, planning your strategies, assigning generals, admirals and political figures, making important political decisions, managing equipment production, research etc. However there are serious issues with this game.

Pretty cool game.   Takes a serious investment in time and effort to learn all the complex aspects of the game.  Takes even longer to master them. As your country's military strength begins to grow  and your sphere of influence expands you are inevitably drawn into diplomatic disputes with other aspiring nations. Today marks my 2000th hour of playing Hearts of Iron 4, and well, I figured I should write a review. But where do I begin? I got this game in late 2016 at the advice of my best friend, because he knew how much I loved WW2. It was my freshman year of high school and HOI4 was one of my first steam games. I can still remember launching it for the first time and starting my very first game as little Belgium (after a short and confusing tutorial of course) , and feeling absolutely overwhelmed by all the different things in the game. I was just beginning to learn a few things and BAM! I get totally steamrolled by the classic German Blitzkrieg. So ended my first game. As I played more and more, I loved this game all the more. Each and every nation on Earth is playable and each have their own unique opportunities every play through. As the player may pick one of four ideologies (Democracy, Fascism, Communism, and Non-Aligned) and lead their nation as its respective leader. Starting in 1936, (or 1939) the player builds up the economic and military might of their nation and prepares for the inevitable world war. Once the nation goes to war, the player uses combined air, naval, and land forces to defeat the enemy. You can also appoint famous WW2 generals and admirals to lead your men to victory. But don't go thinking that historical WW2 happens every single game, as there are a bunch of alternative what-if scenarios that the player may take their nation down, leading to a thousand different possibilities. Some of my favorites include: the Kaiser returns to Germany, Spain joins the war, Imperialist Britain, Aggressive America, or just making a random nation fascist and attempting world conquest, to name a few. I love thinking up various scenarios before I play and then attempting to complete them. Also a great game to play with friends as you can play different nations and team up or fight, or even play as the same nation. I've enjoyed this game all these years, and I look forward to many more enjoyable hours of Hearts of Iron 4. Now let me wrap up this review real quick as I'm about to go play it right now. :)

It's buggy, it's complex, and the frontline system is a step backwards from the theatre system of HOI 3, but it is shockingly addictive. From the perspective of a HOI3 player, everything except the frontline system is a major step up. As an RTS player, it delegates a great deal of micromanagement and plays a lot like a management game, or a wargame with a super high emphasis on production management. Of course, if you assault too aggressively or otherwise take too many losses, your divisions aren't going to keep their combat effectiveness. It's really quite well done, but it is buggy, especially the front line system when dealing with Crimea and the Netherlands, in that it ends at certain land crossings that are mostly water. It also can't be set across multiple countries' borders unless you're at war with them... which makes attacking the lowlands and defending initially as china hard. Perhaps its strongest point is the modding scene. There are so many mods it's insane! It is so easy to mod too!

GAME WITH THE MOST TERRIBLE DESIGN AND A.I. THAT I HAVE EVER PLAYED: Cons: - you can make hot dogs or eggs on your CPU while playing this game - terrible A.I. (your army is stupid and your allies too) - unless you want to play as Germany, USSR or USA (or Britain), do not even bother! - playing for other nations is for masochists (imagine banging your head against the wall) - stupid mana system design similar to the one of EUIV - is it so difficult to develop a strategy with detailed budget and monetary system?! - design of battles and army strength is ambiguous. No chance to reveal the formulas for damage/defense - Paradox DLC politics: forces you to pay for content that SHOULD be part of the original game (no comment!) - the only reason I bought/played this game is because I like alternate history and wanted to see if defense of Czechoslovakia against Germany is possible. It is not! Unless you follow some precise cookie cutter build.

After this much "development" and "content", you would have thought somewhere along the line key issues would be worked on. Example: In my last Japan playthrough I took all of my initial US pacific island objectives in the opening stage of the war, because the US AI decided not to garrison them.  Guam, Wake, and Midway. Bearing in mind I'm running the Expert AI mod and even then the AI fails basic tasks like garrisoning critical strategic locations. The AI will attack with tank divisions through mountains, and with mountain divisions through open plains. It never follows any kind of plan, and constantly makes bad decisions, which are so extreme that if you exploit them its gamebreaking. You have to literally hold yourself back otherwise its too easy, and vs. the AI is already easy. Despite the game's constant "development" and the addition of so much premium priced "content", none of the really core gamebreaking problems have been fixed. It just echoes through Paradox's games. They make half a half baked mess, sell it to you at new game price 5 years after release. They've released the other half of the half baked mess as paid content. It's never going to be properly cooked no matter how much love modders give it.

I enjoyed HoI3, but HoI4 made me sad. HoI3 was dense, but interesting. It allowed you to play any nation in WW2, even if it wasn't fully supported in terms of story. HoI4 allows only a small slice of nations, but it does provide them with story. Some are phased in through DLCs. It is a trade off I could appreciate but for HoI3 setting the standard and if it wasn't such a blatant cash grab. Also when your tutorial is literally "open the wiki and try to make sense of all this dense text", it is absolute ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. Seriously, you guys should know better. Even after sifting through the wiki and getting a better understanding of things, like "why my army won't attack" and "how to manage the multistep process that is building units", none of which are explained in the tutorial beyond maybe "read our wiki", there are still a lot of holes in my understanding. You know what? The game wasn't fun enough to play for me to overlook that frustration.

Um, well, sorry but all of their troops have full org, full supply, and won't being taking attrition. AND don't forget their 20ish width infantry who are "technically" cut off from supply will still beat out your 40 width infantry who are on the defensive. This game is an absolute joke.

Hearts of Iron IV is currently the best global RTS World War 2 game around at this moment in time. That does not mean this is a good game though. The only reason I said this first sentence is because there are no other good games that take a similar format that I have found. Even though I have played this game for a 1,000 hours and I plan on another 300 more I can not say I "enjoy" this game. My only real way to describe my relationship with this game would be to compare it to an abusive relationship. The moment you begin to enjoy or love the game you are in some sort of screw up will occur that either makes no sense, you couldn't predict, you have no way of countering, or fixing reasonably. In my opinion this further pushes players to constantly cheat or play the latest meta only so that they are less likely to lose due to some random screw up. This is can be difficult to see in multiplayer but is EXTREMELY prevelant in singleplayer.  The same thing also leaves the game empty of creativity unless players are doing a meme invasion or strategy. Occasionally I see a strategy that makes me think "hey good idea, that was pretty creative" but these are few and far between due to what I mentioned above and also the "just get better numbers" combat system. Another point is that the games base features have been built and thrown on one at a time by Paradox Interactive's DLC policy which causes large amounts of harm towards the playerbase and game design. Paradox Interactive engages in a policy of building a product with a incomplete foundation and then throwing on additional content to the incomplete foundation. Players who initially get HOI4 (Hearts of Iron IV) without the DLC will see this issue as the game is devoid of large amounts of content. In reality though I believe that while the game is extremely bare in content without DLC the main issue of the game comes from the game mechanics being poorly designed in broken in a rush to make a sellable game (made in 2 and 1/2 years and was extremely buggy on launch). Those players typically will then move on to buy the ridiculously overpriced DLC in a hope to fix their perceived major issue in the game which is there being almost no content outside of the major powers which only had one main option. The main issue of game mechanics has never fixed though and these DLCs simply serve as a content band-aid to distract people from the issue. Paradox continues to take advantage of this crippling issue to further exploit their players into buying further band-aids for this product as people believe that this new DLC along with the others will eventually fix the game. The individual features in the game are not horrible but are not well tied together or are incomplete. Examples with this are the commonly forgot about factory deletion options, certain spy operations, specific naval ships, lack of game options / settings, and a complete lack of any thought towards late game power snowballing. These are more of the easy to spot issues. Majority of the features and mechanics take much longer to uncover the issues from though. So to wrap things up HOI4 can be a fun game at times, I have played this game for over 1,000 hours. BUT HOI4 is a fractured game from perspective of game mechanics and design, Paradox also continues to engage in a major anti-consumer policy of HEAVILY overpriced DLCs. If you disagree with me on the DLC point I recommend looking at DLC prices compared to content and then look at other games DLC policy such as Arma 3 and Fallout New Vegas. There is a major difference in the DLC pricing and policy. In games like New Vegas there was far more content for a lower price (Yes I know New Vegas is an older game but it still released with better pricing) and other games like Arma where there is roughly the same amount of content but it is slightly cheaper and you have a full sandbox and thousands of ways to use that content. If you are looking for a World War 2 global RTS game then I will recommend this BUT only when it is all on a HUGE sale. If you are willing to wait a few years, don't want to spend hours on a save to potentially get a random F U from the game and make you restart, or simply don't want to spend $60+ on a sale then don't play this game. Even though HOI4 is a MAJOR improvement on HOI3 it isn't hard to improve on a $!*% game. (Edited for grammatical purposes.)

You like blatant cheating AI? You like getting beaten, because anyone you declare war upon gets 200% more troops just to make your life miserable? Like having no chance at getting air superiority, even if you have 50 or more factories producing fighters while they have 20? If you are masochistic this game will be your dream. But if you want a game where you can plan military campaigns without using tricks or exploits, then i have to disappoint you. Oh and btw, if you plan on playing one of the axis powers: Don't you ever start in the year 1936. The Allies will have so much troops until the war starts that you can't even get into Belgium or conquer the netherlands. Starting in 1939 it is a piece of cake to beat Belgium, the Netherlands and France. But when you start in 1936. Oh my. Don't even think about it. The only possibility to win when you start this early is to trick the AI by invading the Netherlands and Belgium early on, before the Allies are formed. So a historical approach is out of the question. To summarize: The game lost a lot of it's potential by increasing the cheating AI to ridiculous levels. What a shame.

Unfortunately not able to recommend this one due to poor UI and controls for land combat. I did not see this in many other reviews. So I thought it would be worth writing it down in a couple of points, as it's a core mechanic of the game, at least for me. I like many other Paradox grand strategy games (EU4, Stellaris, CK), and usually prepare well (reading up on the wiki, tutorials etc) so the complexity was not an issue for me. I bough the game on sale together with one DLC to get the focus tree for the minor nation I wanted to play. The UI is poor at showing useful army information. Like most games of its kind here's a few dozen variables involved in combat. No problem. Unlike other games, however, HOI4 doesn't summarise this in a useful overall "strength" indicator (ideally) or really provide any useful information. Armies show a list of divisions with a "green bar" and a "brown bar" that don't actually tell you anything. The most prominent bit of information on your army is the number of divisions, but sheer numbers matter much less than in other games. As a result most of the game is spent tediously mouse-overing individual divisions to get any real information on combat stats and inputs such as equipment. You cannot directly move your units, you're forced to use AI-assisted "battle plans". Without it you miss the large "planning bonus" that you need to match defensive entrenchment bonuses. And, following up from the above, the battle plan is the only place that summarises the dozens of variables involved in land combat in a single "advantage" or "disadvantage" indicator. Battle plan UI is terrible. Battle plans consist of "front lines", "offensive lines" and "arrows" in between. Good luck trying to draw these exactly where you want them. The tools to "edit" plans don't work well at all, so you end up hitting the "delete all orders" and trying again. This is not helped by the ridiculous complexity of the UI, with "click", "right click", "shift click" and "control click" (and even control alt right click!) each having individually essential functions that are different depending on which type of "line" you draw or what kind of unit is selected. AI execution of battle plans is uncontrollable. The AI is dumb in executing battle plans. It doesn't coordinate with allied units. It hardly seems to know the composition of your own army (which divisions have better air support, or better attack vs better defence). I don't have an issue with "dumb" AI on my own side in games, as long as I can manually override it. But HOI4 has no controls to do so. It only makes things worse: units go back to their AI-assigned positions as soon as they reach the player-assigned spot. In summary I want to point out there's a bunch of negative reviews here that lament the loss of a battles they expected to win ("20 vs 5 divisions!! But I lost!!"). In my view those are symptoms of the UI and controls problems described above. Unit count is just one of many variables, and if you try to just click-and-move to attack on the basis that it's "20 v 5" outside of a battle plan you will run into trouble. However that's the intuitive way these games should work - you take the big shiny number the game gives you as an indicator of "strength" and try and point-and-click to move your units. That the game chooses to present the wrong number to you, and hides all the others, and that the point-and-click has been wickedly transformed into control alt shift right click whatever, that's a flaw and not a feature, in my view. So what are the redeeming qualities of the game? Why did it get such great professional reviews? For single player, the alternative history flair could be interesting to just watch unfold. For me watching a documentary would be less frustrating than trying to actually play this as a war game where, you know, you actually want to move units in the direction you choose as a player in a way that makes somewhat sense? But perhaps if you treat the game more like a documentary and just sit back and watch it unfold with limited player intervention is entertaining to some. Set difficulty on "easy" (or play as a very big easy country / with a big fat AI ally). Just selecting focus, research, and construction, basically, then assign all units to a single big fat front line and click "go" and watch it go. I strongly suspect this is how the professional reviewers played it. And if that's your thing, well great for you I don't judge but that's not my cup of tea. I played single player only. I can imagine the above is better in multiplayer, when the coordination with allies is not dependent on the AI, and probably combined with a lot of experience, when you control shift alt right click your battle plans to victory with ease.

Probably the most vicious, toxic, and mean community of any game if you play with strangers. Full of "ironic" nazi bros repeating stale memes from 2016, hackers, exploit users, backstabbers and all around ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•-talkers who prefer to denigrate new players or anyone else who plays the game "wrong" then to be helpful, or cooperative. Single player is awful, stale, and uninteresting. the DLCs do not help this game and just make it more broken and unmanageable. Do you like scrolling through different, irrelevant tabs? Do you like expansions that break previous core mechanics? Do you like boring, stale rinse and repeat ways to win a game because there's no other way except by stacking bombers, fighters, and artillery heavy divisions? Do you like just W A I T I N G for things to happen? then this is the game for you, because you are probably a very passive aggressive person, an all around loser in life, and deserve nothing good to happen to you. It's hurry up and wait in multiplayer lobbies for an hour to start, 2 hours of waiting around doing nothing for something interesting to happen since time is so slow in large multiplayer lobbies. If one thing goes wrong, there's no recovering in a timely fashion and you're stuck waiting several more hours IRL to correct something someone did wrong. Never mind the disconnects, the bad lag from poor optimization the community is forced to fix with their own mods. If you are stupid enough to play this game, instead of doing something productive with your time like going for a walk, doing some calisthenics, learning to code to make a better game than this sorry excuse, or just playing a better game, then I recommend you only play with IRL friends. There's no stranger in multiplayer that you will enjoy meeting that will make this game bearable. Trust me. I've played this game since it released and this latest expansion is the straw that broke the camel's back. Not that it matters, because 4/5th of this game's fanbase is afraid of using any of the content included (no spies, no strategic bombers, no mixed template divisions, no boosting allies' industry if you are a major player, no subs beyond rinky dinky 1936 models, no rockets, and that's on top of the hugbox MP lobbies set up to coddle Axis players because heaven forbid the Allies don't let Italy gobble Yugoslavia in 1938). I can't emphasize how bad this game is. It's a literal waste of time. There's nothing high-brow or intelligent about waiting for production efficiency to be increased by 5.00% in 176 in-game days (that actually takes 1h30 IRL time in MP or 10 minutes at max speed in single) or a naval invasion to take 88 days (40 minutes IRL) to just... PREPARE. Stop being a masochist. Go play a real strategy game instead of an excel sheet with some moving pixels. If you don't believe this review, go browse the youtube commentary section for any popular vid about this game. It's full of cringy, "heh, this guy only has 83 civilian factories in 1937? Cringe bro. MY build is is much better and grants 0.304% more production on fighters II by Dec 1936". Jesus ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• christ.

Anyways here's how to make spaghetti Bolognese: ->Ingredients -olive oil -400g beef mince -400g Italian pork sausages, skinned and crumbled -200g smoked pancetta -1 onion, finely chopped -1 carrot, finely chopped -2 celery sticks, finely chopped -4 garlic cloves, chopped -1 sprig thyme -small bunch fresh basil, small leaves picked and reserved -2 bay leaves -2 tsp dried oregano -handful dried porcini mushrooms -1 tsp golden caster sugar -1 tbsp tomato pur√©e -¬Ω tsp Thai fish sauce -1 tbsp red wine vinegar -100ml whole milk -4 x 400g cans chopped tomatoes -200ml white wine -100g parmesan, grated, rind removed and kept -spaghetti, to serve ->Method STEP 1: Heat a drizzle of olive oil in a large non-stick frying pan and crumble in the mince and sausagemeat. Spend a good 30 mins cooking the mince ‚Äì it will release lots of liquid, which you want to evaporate, and then eventually it will end up sizzling in its own fat. If the pan becomes too dry, drizzle in a little more olive oil. Towards the end, continue stirring the mince until it becomes speckled with crisp brown bits. STEP 2 Heat oven to 140C/120C fan/gas 2. While the mince is browning, heat a drizzle more oil in a casserole dish and sizzle the pancetta for 5 mins until it starts to brown and release its fat, then throw in the vegetables and herbs, and finely crumble over the dried porcini. Cook gently for 5 mins until soft and starting to brown. Sprinkle over the sugar, then stir in the tomato pur√©e and splash in the fish sauce and vinegar. Simmer down until gloopy, then stir through the meat and pour in the milk and tomatoes. Rinse out the tomato tins with the wine and stir into the pan. Season, then nestle in the parmesan rind. Bring to a simmer, then cover and cook in the oven for 3 hrs. STEP 3 When cooked, tip as many portions of Bolognese as you need into a saut√© pan. Cook the pasta until very al dente, then tong into the pan with a bit of the water and finish cooking with the sauce for 2 mins. Stir through the parmesan and a drizzle more olive oil. Twirl the pasta and Bolognese into bowls, scatter with basil and serve with more parmesan. Enjoy!

Played Collie v1.10.7 (02cc) In one sentence: I prefer older titles, like HoI II. About HoI IV: - Primitive, unbalanced and senseless economic/trade system (few exchange options, import affect building power, no raw resource stock, no money, no real buy and selling...); - Division layout in theory is a nice idea, but badly implemented; even with big countries like Japan it is necessary to divide the production capacity on an infinite series of equipment which makes real planning impractical; - Battles decided from scripted event based on time and political decisions; - Too low number of generals; - They ask to use automatic planning for the army, but it works badly and the only reason to use it is because it gives advantages as statistics; but honestly it takes away the pleasure of playing; - Primitive control on puppet/allies; - You cannot take control of the allied forces and are forced to borrow divisions, on which you must use your already few generals; - War justification force the game to follow decision trees; no flexibility; - Micro management instead of Grand Strategy; - Confusing map; - Really bad and obtuse game forum; I was thinking to take also other DLCs, but after having played this, I will not and I will be a lot skeptical about other Paradox games. Not recommended at all. Next time, better trying before buying.

Game was great. For some reason they felt the need to change the launcher. The new launcher adds no useful features compared to the old one. What it does add is the ability to ram ads into your face. Between ghost files preventing you from re-downloading, to mods not appearing after 3 re-installs of the game, to installed and activated mods not working; the launcher as killed the best part of the game. Enjoy playing identical games with your friends because you can't install extra focus trees or overhauls. I have an unhealthy amount of time in this game and enjoyed a lot of it. I can't recommend it to others knowing such a big part of it is utterly ruined by greed. A classic launcher option is overdue.

I really took my time to like it but overall I can't recommend it. First of all the game doesn't explain ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• to you so you better flip out internet and youtube guides if you event want to play it. Then my most major problem is that several systems are extremely overdesigned, like naval combat, while other things like economics, supply, diplomacy are a hollow shell of a feature. War and related diplomacy is as bad as in any Paradox game with unreasonable design choices, incomprehensible mechanics and a promise of a sandbox that it never delivers. The whole claims mechanics is just as bad as in all their games, even diplomacy where it would make tremendous sense to actually allow player to negotiate territorial claims give and take territories or promise certain lands to allies in exchange for help is non-existent. The only settlement you can make is locked in a research tree instead of actual diplomacy, you can't demand certain territories you'd like to demand just because f. u. it is locked in another subsystem. The brutal oversimplification of all economics and logistics is just a crime IMO, the whole war was decided by those factors leaving them out is borderline retarded. Trade also has almost nothing to do with diplomacy where it was totally interconnected. Trade and resource availability practically doesn't matter, it's just another subsystem that is extremely underdesigned and poorly integrated. You can't pressure minor powers into doing something if it's not on the national focus tech tree. Another miss on the diplomacy part, whereas you should be able to pressure minor powers to for example open up their ports or give you the oil instead of someone else... with an "or else" statement! Having war support without the actual possibility and/or need to balance civilian needs with military doesn't make any sense. Your people won't starve, won't die, won't be overworked, they don't suffer if they aren't bombed, they just exist to fill the manpower bar. Honestly I hoped that this game was more than a fancy "frontline colors simulator" but it is not.

Just as most Paradox games, once I bought it, it became my favourite game ever. For players unfamiliar with the game series, I recommend buying the game on a sale with all the DLCs, to get the full experience! If you`re into WW2 (also WW1, Cold War and so on with mods) this is the game for you! The game focuses on the military aspect of wars, letting you command divisions of tanks, infantry, airplanes and ships, while also letting you decide the division composition, the modernisation of equipment and so on.
l

Victory is at your fingertips! Your ability to lead your nation is your supreme weapon, the strategy game Hearts of Iron IV lets you take command of any nation in World War II; the most engaging conflict in world history. From the heart of the battlefield to the command center, you will guide your nation to glory and wage war, negotiate or invade. You hold the power to tip the very balance of WWII. It is time to show your ability as the greatest military leader in the world. Will you relive or change history? Will you change the fate of the world by achieving victory at all costs?

This game has a ton of potential.  The devs won't fix issues.  Same issues that have been there since beginning. Naval combat has been revamped, but AI or computer decision making is still broken.  The AI decides to make outdated or old ships late game when it should be making newer ships to make the game more challenging.  Even with community mods the game still does not function like it could be designed to. The army ai is also broken.  The army system works by creating a line of troops around the front of the battle between you and your enemy.  The computer or ai does not make lines properly to even be a little challenging.  The ai pulls troops from the line constantly to make it so easy to just conquer territory through the opening or the ai does not put anything other than infantry on the line against your heavy tanks that destroy the enemy infantry. The game really has all the pieces to be a good challenging game, but paradox interactive will not fix the ai or computer.  This has not just happened recently either.  Paradox Interactive knows about these issues through customer complaints since this game came out and they do not make changes.  They just continue to sell an incomplete, broken game that has potential.  Typical corporate good enough B.S.

Fun and rewarding but grindy game. If you enjoy strategy games, or like games where you work hard but feel rewarded after, this might be the game for you, however at first it is EXTREMELY intimidating, when i first played i almost face planted my keyboard because it was so complicated, now with over 600 hours on the game, and growing, the game's basics are very easy, and it never really gets boring because there are always new challenges and new mods. Just be aware the game is prone to game breaking bugs for certain countries, and crashes... lots of crashes... Moving on the multiplayer is always really laggy and slow. Also the game is really hard to play without dlcs, in the base game there is no in-depth things, and all countries have a minimal focus trees (unique paths for each country, eg you cant go monarchist/democratic Germany without dlcs, also there are no spies in the base game). Overall a fun game for me, but i know many people wouldn't like it. (Beware the game isn't completely historically accurate, although it is a ww2 strategy game)

Basic Start to the HoI4 Experience I may not have played much, but speaking of the first experience i had, and the experiences from other paradox games. This is definitely one of the most enjoyable ( and simpler) games paradox has made. [hl] Good things[/hl] Some good things about the game is that it is not too hard to get the hang of.  Yes, at first glance it does look complicated, but most of it is pretty easy to get the hang of and can be really fun. The controls are pretty simple, like most other RTS and Grand Strategy Games. The wars are really enjoyable, and especially satisfying to win.  The different types of warfare to have, not to mention the different types of games to play. The fact is no matter what, your choices affect the game.  Shaping it.  One annexed nation here could stop a whole historical event from happening or just make it happen sooner.  The open ability to change the course of the game is very nice and really opens up some interesting game paths. The units are really nice as well, they are easy to have a more automated push into enemy territory than in other games, where you have to physically move each unity or group to attack a certain objective.  In here, you can set a battle plan, giving your troops a more open way to attack and conquer. The infrastructure in the game are very important when playing.  Always make sure to balance the civilian with the military factories. This game is always enjoyable with friends, and can be really wacky when you all are forging your own paths. The game itself is relatively small on size, so it can be played on many devices without a worry of taking all of the storage space. Downsides Unfortunately, like any game it has some downsides. 1. The price is way to high, I get that with this game you don't have to have a DLC to make it fun, but the fact that its 40 dollars just seems like too much.   I would say lower it by 25-50% of the price.  To at least make it more affordable.  Especially since there are quite a few DLC. 2. The path finding rules might need to be updated a bit, sometimes your units don't take a route over water when you want them to.  It might have just been me, but I feel that if there was an easier time clicking on the other dock you want them to go to, they could take a sea route instead of land. 3. The graphic requirements are a little on the high side, but can be turned down 4.  Same with the RAM requirements, while it may not seem like a lot, it does use quite a bit of RAM to run smoothly on multiplayer. 5. Need a good internet connection.  From what I can tell to do multiplayer well without the game slowing down you need at least around 50mbps.  This is from what I found out on my experiences.  It could vary by player. I recommend you and your friends get LogMeIn Hamachi.  It helps with the connection issues a bit by giving a more direct connection to your friends game. I recommend this for all games, not just HoI4 I'm sure there are more downsides to some people, but these are the few I found annoying. Overall It's a good game, a little pricey, but just wait for it to go on sale and you can enjoy the thrill of war too.

Don't be fooled by my extended playtime. This game is a time sink, and not in a good way. See, the idea of WW2 as a day-by-day RTS sounds really good. However, for the first 4 years of the game, you'll only do something every 70 days. The focus tree. Which barely does anything most of the time. Mods understand this is stupid because most mods have focus trees with less time in between focuses. However, the other biggest problem is the combat. Gods above, is the combat in this game atrocious. Numbers is how every single combat is decided. Which is fine, but it's not engaging. You draw a line and press go. If you have better tech and a better set up, you win. What's the problem? That's the most engaging part of the game. I kid you not. Don't expect the country building or """Diplomacy""" to be more engaging. Both are a joke and if you never did either, depending on the country, you could win if you never even found the button to do either. I've played a lot of this game, mostly with conversion mods, but I can honestly say that's because you can play this game minimized while doing homework or reading. And don't get me started on the multiplayer, which is the most egregious part of this game. Want to waste an entire afternoon? Play as America in a friendly multiplayer game and watch Russia and the UK lose to Germany before you even enter the war. This game is terrible and I'll never understand how it got more popular than a few hundred people who have the tempermant of those people who memorize the mm thickness of each turret in WW2

I played this on vanilla, I understand the DLCs change alot. However, I'm not going to spend an additional 20 bucks or so on DLCs. The game is fun but, theres alot of things about this game that ruins it for me. Here positives and the negatives. For those who dont know this game is based on the 2nd World War, you get to basically relive the events of it as a leader of a nation rather than a field commander commanding an army or a fleet. Positives: 1. Graphics are very nice and the game does seem to be very detailed to the point where they add weather affects in different parts of the world that would affect your forces. 2. Game is very realistic to the point of where you have to equip your troops and train them like produce the necessary equipment for them and transports for them. 3. Having the ability to play as a smaller country is kind of nice. 4. In the settings you can certainly have countries behave to where you can reenact a "what if" scenario. 5. Some tech that can be researched wont be available until a later year. This is nice because it means that the player wont come out with Iowa class battleship in 1937  at the beginning of the game (though I've done this before, lol) 6. Units in this game are actual units not just like a single soldier. So, what I mean is that in most Strategy games the troops are called units. In reality units are actually regiments, brigades, companies, platoons, divisions, corps', etc. In this game all troops are organized into divisions. ( which a single division typically has about roughly 15k troops, that's according to NATO standards) Negatives: 1. This game is incredibly complicated, and the tutorial explains nothing. 2. National focus and research trees are very overwhelming, (I played a few games with a no air force mod which, really helps condenses it and make it less overwhelming.) 3. combat in this game sucks, (now bear in mind this is vanilla gameplay so, DLCs might change a few things). Combat is so bad that I've had 45 armor divisons up against 1 Japanese infantry division. organization is all good and equipment is good. Dispite all this all 45 divisions fail to break through  a single infantry division. I don't care how much fortifications that 1 division has there is no way in hell a single infantry division can stand up against 45! 4. The AI  is just absolutly garbage and the historical settings doesn't work! I played 2 games with historical AI setting on. Dispite this, France goes Communist in the first game I was like WTF? I quit the game start a new one. During the new game; France, once again, goes Communist. Then Britain also goes Communist and hell even Canada goes communist. 5. This game likes to pride itself on historical realism, but they kind fail in this regard. Heavy cruisers in this game are classified as capital ships. In reality Heavy Cruisers were NOT classified as capital ships the only ships that were classified as capital ships were: Battleships, battle cruisers and Carriers. Another thing was the fake ships they have for research. Like Illinois class. This is completely fictional there were no class of ships that were named Illinois to be better armed or armored than the Iowa class. Also Virginia class? why would the game name it that way when in the description they said its the South Dakota 1920s design. Why not just call it the South Dakota then? 6. Troops don't seem to not want to move when told to do so. When the game's on play sometimes I find my divisions just, for some reason refuse to move. Or move to a completely different place when I didn't tell them to move to, their organization is completely fine. So, because of this really weird thing, the divisions that did move do their job; but. Without reinforcements they get completely wiped out. So, there were times when I lost 24 divisions because I had back up units refused to actually move to the designated area and instead go somewhere totally random. ( again bear in mind this is the vanilla game so this might've been fixed with the DLCs) So, what do I think of this game overall? Well it was fun at first. However: divisions not doing their dam jobs, AI doing some really crazy things, extremely complicated and overwhelming game play with a useless tutorial. Really turns me off, which I'm extremely disappointed. I love historical strategy games, but this one just turns me away. So, I feel like I waisted my $10 on this game that's an uninstall for me. Note: This is my first time playing a Hearts of Iron game. So, I've never played any of the other previous games. Also again, understand I played the vanilla game so no DLCs.
