After ~130 hours in the game, I feel like I have enough experience to speak a little on it. While the core concept of HOI4 is fun, it faces several gameplay issues that make it not only unreasonably difficult to play, but also heavy on the micro-managing end. In concept, it's fun. The idea of playing as any nation during the era of WW2 and rewriting history is incredibly tantalizing. Steering any nation down an alternate path - whether it be Communist America, Fascist UK, or any number of kings and queens as well as democracies - is fun as hell. The problem, though, comes with war. Without going into excessive detail, there are many gameplay mechanics that make war extremely frustrating to deal with. Having to micro-manage your armies due to big orders that simply don't work is very annoying. Not to mention, many of the national focus trees (the political path you take your nation down) often fall flat, due to most of the interesting ones putting your nation at odds or war with superpowers and overwhelming odds. To many players, this challenge makes the game that much more fun. Which is why I can't really recommend you buy or don't buy as a general rule. It depends on your playstyle and what type of sandbox you want to play. To me, I like a moderate challenge but for the most part, the RP and immersive experience is much more important. Long story short, you'll love the game if you're the type of strategy player that likes to micro-manage and find the best possible meta to completely dominate with. If you're like me, though, where you just like creating your own nation and getting into the experience of it all, you'll find the game very frustrating. It will feel like you can't see your plans come to fruition due to the heavy difficulty barrier the game has.

After spending several hours watching tutorials and youtubers as well as several hours in-game trying hopelessly to figure when a country was actually ready to go to war and win, I realized I just wasn't having any fun. What's the use of having a game with a lot of systems offering thousands of choices if basically every way to use them is wrong? The learning curve for this game is the worst I've ever seen. Even Crusader Kings 2 was more playable than this.

I tried liking this game - it's a beautiful game and the concept is engaging. However, I just couldn't. The gameplay is laden with mindless research and resource clicking and it distracts from the focus of the game - warfare. The battles, when they do eventually come, are long, drawn out, and haphazard at best. The battle units must be assigned to a commander and given battle orders and then the AI will execute it. This hands off approach is rather frustrating since the AI will behave in mysterious ways - units being pulled from battles and reassigned to the rear leaving in-battle units to be slaughtered. Further adding salt to the wound is that units are given bonus points for being assigned a commander, meaning, if you detach from the AI commander and fight the battle yourself, you'll get penalized and find yourself losing by a landslide. Overall, it's beautiful game with lovely graphics. However, the hands-off approach cripples the game's strategic element and instead leaves you with a lot to be desired while you're mindlessly clicking away.

All though I do like to play Stellaris and I enjoy several games made by paradox, this game however isn't exactly my type of tea. The combat in this game is just absurdly complex, sure I get that it is that way to allow for in-depth tactics but it is just mind straining to even attempt to do a singular attack. It should also be mentioned that it took me my entire current play time to properly learn how to create a proper army force, I had no idea how the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• you recruited an army general, how to add troops into it and so on. The way resourse harvesting and constructing works is also really retarted, instead of just it steadily producing a resource, this game gives you the option to prioritize and do other things that I still to this day have no idea what it does. This game looked fun to play but is just a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• mess for people who havent searched up videos and tutorials.

I learned I can switch countries by saving and loading, so I decided to end all wars forever. Unfortunately, the only military equipment I could destroy permamently was ships, meaning I can't fully demilitarize the entirety of the world, because the ai of the country I played before switching keeps retraining troops as I'm destroying another country's military. I think that if I destroyed all factories in the world, then at least no new equipment could ever be built by anyone, which would be something. There is also a bug/issue, where choosing "decolonized americas" does not remove USA and Canada from existence. I also couldn't release US territories to their lawful, true owners, the indigenous americans. Another bug: Releasing occupied territories as russia doesn't give crimea back to ukraine. Crimea was, is, and always will be Ukrainian territory. Fix this.
they crossed the line with bulgaria focus tree UPDATE: they added lithuania

Out of all the games I've played recently this has to be the worst one.  Or at least close to the worst.  Before I get into the biggest point on why this game just isn't good I'll explain a few gripes I personally don't like.  Mainly the tutorial.  It's horrible.  One of the worst tutorials I've ever done.  It basically only shows you how to fight a war with units and that's it.  They show you only how to do a small section of the game.  Many many times when you need to do something in a regular game it'll show you a tool tip if you don't know how or what to do.  But the tool tip will either be a link to the wiki, or a video on how to do it.  That's even worse than the actual tutorial.  The game very clearly expects people to either do so much research into external sources on how to play the game, or expects people who played the earlier games to just know. Now to the actual game.  It's fine.  Not great, but not very good either.  It feels like a weird mix of Civ games but RTS.  I personally find it weird, but many people probably won't.  The main issue I have with the actual gameplay when you're done reading 500 pages of the wiki or 40 hours of the video tutorials is that not a whole lot happens.  Regardless of when an actual war starts, not much is really going on.  You do some research every so often, you upgrade the political path to get bonuses and unlock more things, you train units for army, you trade with other countries, make political decisions, work on your factories needed, among many other small things.  There's a lot of small things that aren't particularly "fun" to do between the actual fun part which is doing the actual strategy part with wars and political tension.  So I'd say about 10% of the game for me is fun.  Other people may like these other aspects but I personally don't. Lastly I do want to mention the horrible design choice by the developers.  Currently as of me writing this, this game is $18 on Humble Bundle for base game and all dlc, it's $1 for just base game.  The problem with whichever version you get is that even with the great value of all the dlc's, without the dlc's this game is very very bare bones.  There's barely any polish on it and lacks a lot of features present in previous games.  So the $1 version is cheap and probably worth it tbh, you will always be playing an inferior game since the devs decided features should be locked behind a paywall.  I don't care how good the game is with or without the dlc.  That's scummy.  No one should support that, even if it's a good price.  If I didn't have a key I used for this I would refund it. TL;DR It's an alright but very flawed game and the part with the scummy dlc is just horrendous. 4/10 if you paid full price. 5/10 if you got a discount.

This is the perfect combined arms strategy game. If you like being able to relive events as they happened, or even change them to create your own history this is the game for you. Use national focuses to guide your nation in the direction you want, but be prepared for the consequences of changing history. Theres nothing like opening a can of whoop ass by creating deadly army groups with the proper equipment and width to achieve the most unlikely of victories. Naval actions and Air Combat prove to be satisfying every single time. When they accompany your conquests you can feel the support to your armies, and therefore when comes the lack of support you will also feel the hurt (especially if you have no air force or navy to speak of from the start). This game for me was easy to learn and hard to master, at 260 hours, i just got to a point where im comfortable going to war with Germany, the Soviets, and the British (not all at once obviously). Each require a massive effort of manpower and equipment. 10/10 Game highly recommend.

Hearts of Iron IV is a dumbed down successor to Hears of Iron III. A game for inbred brain dead casuals, that are incapable of thinking, and when asked what is 2+2 they say it's racism, turtle, and a potato! Playing both games, and having XXX hours in them, maybe even XXXX I know what I'm talking about. HoI3 wasn't perfect, it had it's flaws, and everyone knows it, but it had depth, it had climate, authenticity, and a lot of content, features that HoI4 doesn't, still 5 years after the release, and will never have. It's quite similar to Crusader Kings 2, and the dumbed down Crusader Kings 3. Paradox does it every single time. Skip this garbage, and get Hearts of Iron 3, you'll enjoy it much more, unless you are a casual, then get Hearts of Iron 4. I don't really know where to start, as those games are so different in many aspects. First of all the Order of Battle creation... gone. The best, and most important feature of the game. Researching certain parts of the vehicles. In Hoi3 you had 4 parts they consisted of which were armor/engine/gun/reliabilty... gone*. In HoI4 you research whole vehicles at once, and just that. It kills a lot of authenticity, in fact it removes it, HoI4 is just so poorly done, there's no authenticity, or any world war climate, it feels more like a board game, so simplified even a chimpansee would be able to conquer Europe, or China. It felt great how you built your vehicles to your liking, how every part had a correct name, how your initial builds were being upgraded with better cannons, armor etc. Now in HoI4, it looks like, research > Panzer 3 > research completed, research > Panzer 4 > research completed... it's so awfull. I expected Hearts of Iron 4 to be bigger, better, even more expanded, realistic, and complicated, as that what I enjoyed the most, the way it was made, and how it worked. They just scrapped the best parts of their game, and remade it... for who I don't know. The research itself is gone as we know it, now all you do is follow some ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• linear trees, and doctrines with decisions, which for me is just so ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• stupid I can't even, I just can't. In HoI3 beside some decisions on a national level, pretty much every country could be built the same way, had pretty much access to the same things, the only difference were levels of research, and that was fine by me, it was realistic, and just nicely done, while HoI4 has gone full ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, trees are full of ahistorical, fantasy crap, because that's what this game become, "what if", some sort of ahistorical blasphemy. You can of course select historical AI to play, but still, what has Paradox done to this game is just beyond me. At least there are modders, and if I was ever to buy Hearts of Iron 4, I would only buy it for the Black Ice mod, I loved it in the Hearts of Iron 3, and loved it in HoI4, but I won't be buying the game, because it's quite ridiculous to buy a game that I have no interest in, just to play an amazing masterpiece mod. I'd rather wish those guy/girls whoever made it, made their own game, and I would gladly pay them, as Black Ice is what Hears of Iron should have always been. We can't forget about the Paradox DLC madness, how HoI4 at a release was just a sandbox game, though with no sand at all, and every DLC [cut out content of the base game] is in fact a bit of sand that gets added to the sandbox itself. Too long didn't read? Get Hearts of Iron 3 with all expansions + try Black Ice mod. Get Hears of Iron 4 with whatever is required to run Black Ice mod. Otherwise don't bother. * I forgot you can build variants, which are similar to how it worked in HoI3, but it's all about numbers, add +1 number to certain type of upgrade. After building variants, you can't even delete them in the game, but hide... 2021 and you can't even remove a mod.

HOI4, decent game for a Strategy Nut. Paradox may be a little lack luster in providing content, I would recommend looking into the Modding community immediately. Initial purchase of the Cadet Edition, around Forty Dollars is worth for the standard, bare bone experience. Unless you find the prepackaged Content additions, which may often be over priced,modding may be much easier, reliable and cheaper than Paradox's Products. Modding may make the Game run slower, more choppy,it may be wise to invest in a better Gaming PC/Laptop for a smooth, clean play-through. It would be more Cheaper this way, as Mods are free, many may be combined,and a better PC would run many other applications smoothly.

I said most of what I wanted to say about Paradox games in my EU4 review. The games themselves are completely unfocused, and suffer from feature-creep. The DLCs are secretly paid updates, and the community engagement is the real prize. Hearts of Iron specifically deals with the WW2 era, obviously. As a result, it features greater emphasis on frontline warfare and integrated war-goods production than the other games, and a diminished emphasis on internal politics, or meaningful change over time. It is often humorously described as applying the "microsoft paint fill tool to the world map."

Quite complex, once you know the basics, it's essentially a 1936>1945 sandbox, the limiting factor being that the tech tree stops at 1945, not the game. Strongly recommend the game, does require the DLC to be playable however. If you're going to buy the DLC, I recommend the following, ignore the rest. -Battle for the Bosporus -La Resistance -Man the Guns -Waking the Tiger -Death or Dishonor -Together for Victory General Info 4 Main ideologies Democracy - Op occupation laws - Can't attack a nation without a dedicated focus, requires the nation to create world tension to attack them. Non Aligned - Similar to Democracy, less restrictive. Fascist - Can attack create a casus belli at will, few restrictions, unique occupation options, when at war with a major, they can justify against another country extremely fast. Communist - Can justify similar to Fascist, has a unique occupation type too, also can puppet nations for cheaper cost in the peace deals. Aspects you should be aware of - bare these in mind and it will pay you dividends later You have several resources Political Power - Use to change aspects of your cabinet and economic laws, also used to justify and for certain decisions Stability - Increases production and political power when over 50%, decreases it when below. War Support - Quicker mobilization and is required to change certain laws - Just more industry basically Manpower - The amount of raw manpower you have, based on your population and current laws, you get it from occupation too, however with a 98% penalty Equipment - Made via factories - ranging from weapons to support equipment to artillery to planes to tanks ect, it's generally quite simple, however appears complex when you're new. Factory output = 4.5 * efficiency (This increases the longer it's producing the same item) "Can also be increased via tech" If an item requires 4.5 to make 1, at 100% efficiency one factory would produce 1 per day. Actual resources - Oil - Aluminum - Rubber - Tungsten - Steel - Chromium - They're naturally located around the globe, can be increase up to *2 via 10 infrastructure, can also be increased again by 1.5* via excavation tech. Required to produce basically everything Focus trees - basically what makes most countries unique, gives them a few major options and goals, this is a focal point of the game Combat types Land - Using front-lines via generals, you create a front line order and attack plan, then command the general to commence the order. They have stats which increase based on their actions, they also increase with a higher likelihood if you give them traits that are relevant to that stat. Soft Attack - how many attack they can make Breakthrough - how many attack they can avoid when attacking Defence - how many attacks they can avoid when defending Hardness - Soft attacks do damage to soft - Hard attacks do damage to hard - If you have a unit that's 90% hard, and it's against a division that only have soft attacks, it will negate 90% of their damage, this is how tanks wreck infantry, they also have very high breakthrough. Air - Air superiority allows you to drastically reduce the enemies defence and breakthrough, it also allows you to bomb their industry unmolested, it's also required to drop nukes. Paratroopers - air superiority also allows you to drop paratroopers in a given country, allowing you to quickly force them to surrender, or divert troops to counter. Naval - If you wish to attack via sea and or destroy their supply and resource chains, you need naval supremancy, or you can spam subs, it's your choice, many even after thousands of hours don't understand it, and don't care to. The only thing you do need to understand is naval invasions, you require naval supremacy for only a brief moment to naval invade "hint". Essentially required to invade nationals via sea, and allows you to control the worlds resources via harassing convoys. These are just some basic things to note, when you start, you'll likely have no clue what you're doing, just play and have fun, don't expect to win when you start, and don't be afraid to play as the major nations, you'll learn the most and have the most fun playing them. Experiment and learn the basics, also don't bother with achievements until you understand the game at a basic level, turn ironman mode off, or you'll be constantly restarting and ruin the game for yourself. Additional Trade laws - Increases or decreases resources to market, can be accepted by players and ai, they'll give you a civilian factory for every 8 of the resource you give, as soon as they stop trading it you lose the factory. It's possible to export lots but no country buys due to having low trade relations with them, this is impacted by ideology, relations and literal distance. Mods - this game has some of the best mods I've ever experienced in any game, and really works well with them. Recommend music mods too (Just examples) German March Collection Wolfenstein Music Classical Music Kaisserreich Music Old World Blues Radio Axis Speeches Some full game changing mods that I recommend - "Kaisserreich + Old World Blues" (Try both on their own) Recommend trying after around a 100h or so of the base game, they're really good. Just some basics, you've done well if you've read this far, i'll update this at a later date and correct any errors ect... I've much more to learn myself too.

An awesome and engaging strategy game that gives you so many choices on what you want to play as, do, and become. What makes this game so spectacular is the amount of mods you can play with that changes the gameplay and mechanics to the game. If you ever play this game please play with mods later on. This game is the absolute best game I've ever played on PC/Windows. Any number of players can fully immerse themselves into any country they choose. You can play one, two, three or more people on one country if you wish to do so. Why would anyone want to share the glory you ask! Simple, At times, there is so much going on that you need to focus your attention on production, politics, war, research, you army, airforce, navy, generals, trade goods, construction, infrastructure that you may need 2 or 3 more people to help you keep up during a heavy engagement. Watch some YouTube or Twitch videos and see for yourself. This game is never the same game twice. You can choose the difficulty levels and have the AI focus on historical or non-historical progression. This game is a challenge. My only concern is that some of the DLC's should come "FREE" in an update because their content is mostly cosmetic. Paradox has a winner here. Once you pick up this game and start playing, you wont want to go to work or school or even to bed. I strongly advise you try this game. You will enjoy for the rest of your life.

i wish i could give a neutral review on this game, because while i do think it is a great game, i think paradox is a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• company. they overcharge for dlc that has content that should've been in the base game, which is something they do in every single game they make. i only recommend this game at all on sale, because you're gonna have to cough up over $100 otherwise. paradox also has a ridiculously simple tutorial for a ridiculously complicated game. you're gonna need to watch a few hours worth of guides before you can even start playing. i have 16 hours in this game and i still barely know how to play. if you can't tolerate massive, frustrating learning curves, don't even think about playing this game. but if you can look past all these major flaws, this game is an incredibly detailed war simulator that can easily give you hundreds of hours of content. a must have for history fans and strategy game veterans.

First! This game is very complicated and keeps getting more complex with each update. But, if you like grand strategy, history, world war 2, alternate history theories, co-op, or generally playing something however you'd like, give this game time, and I suspect you will love it. I was completely bamboozled by the game for so long and even with my 850+ hours, I still get confused with how things work and continue to learn the game. Trust me anyone reading this, this game is really good. The dlc is expensive, but it does add a lot of flavor to it and I'd say significantly increases the fun and creativity within it. Incredible depth, strategy and immersion. I've never played a game quite like it. I have purchased several add-ons and have enjoyed each one thoroughly, too. I found Hearts of Iron frustrating, at first - there are simply SO many mechanics and concepts to learn that it can be daunting. There's something about Hoi4 that I've never seen before in other games- it is how it is so replayable. Most games you buy, you can play it once or twice, and then it just gets boring. Hoi is different. Any player Hoi learns something new every day, no matter their experience. Whether it is how acclimization affects combat, or what is the optimal weather to attack in, this game's so complex that I dare-say that the 60$ and DLC **** is worth it. -Beware- Although this game is very enjoyable once mastered (to a certain degree), there is a verrrryyyy steep learning curve. Also, the tutorial is useless.

A wonderfully indepth grand strategy. This sets itsself apart from other grant strats because it not only forces you to create well thought out battle plans, but it also forces you to play politics so you can't just steamroll everyone early on. Its very fun to also take the alternate history routes like reforming the ottoman empire or having the democratic chinese defeat the communists to make their democratic government. Its tough to get into but is by far the best grand strategy on the market right now!

Although bugs and glitches occur, the overall play-ability of Hearts of Iron 4 is phenomenal. It runs well on almost all systems, including my potato of a laptop. The features are easy to learn and easy to handle. Even though some may be complicated or need DLCs to flesh out. The Focus Trees for some nations are dated and need updates (Italy) but with DLCs and other content coming out to revive these trees, I think the enjoy-ability of this game will carry players for years. Would definitely recommend this game to all of my friends, no matter their interests.

It will take you 200 hours to learn the game. And you still won't know everything. That doesn't sound great but believe me it's digital crack. You will mess up, uninstall, then feel the itch, reinstall, do slightly better, mess up, uninstall, and repeat until it all just clicks. This is not an action strategy game. This is a game about the management of a military industrial complex. Oh and while certain scenarios are fun to play out with historical AI on and are good for training, the real fun happens when you switch them off and adapt to the chaos. This game is work but damn if it isn't rewarding.

Can't even be compared with previous games. Game was so streamlined and simplified that it ruined all fun. You used to micromanage all your units, now it's just click on the border and stare at the screen for the rest of your game. It's also railroaded, so you don't actually do anything, you just click a button and suddenly you annex Austria, restore German Empire, magically gain claim on some territories etc. Economy and tech management was stripped to bare bones. Spying system is useless and provides little to no benefits. Combat is basically make 7 infantry 2 artillery 20 width template (later upgrade to 40) - win. If you want ww2 alternate history simulator - play it, if you want strategy game - don't.

If you are willing to apply a complete overhaul mod, this can be an interesting game. Unfortunately still one deeply broken by AI. The initial setting is WW2, but once you start the clock it progresses with no more plausibility than Civilization. If Ghandi was here, he'd be waging a war of annihilation against...the Bahamas. The AI makes strategic level decisions worse than random chance would offer, most of them utterly implausible. You do not feel you're playing historical WW2-themed war game but a game starting at a point around WW2 and progressing in totally random directions. Tactical AI (division or "counter" level) is hit or miss, with the AI occasionally making sound choices, but more often letting its units/divisions be destroyed for no purpose or grinding them to nothing in laughably unwinnable attacks on completely unimportant areas. If you're used to Paradox's disastrous user interface design, you'll still be surprised at how unfriendly and difficult to use this title's interface is.

Vanilla game is fantastic and so much better with mods to improve on the vanilla version. Very simplified compared to other HOI games but it can be a challenge nonetheless. The graphics are good however the game will get slower and slower when you're into at least the 40s. The Germans are a good way to start off and get used to the game they're the easiest country to play as. Managing your army is fairly easy and I've found few problems with them. Industry is devoted to construction of factories (Civilian, Military and Dockyards), Forts, Naval Bases (for storing Ships) Industry (For increasing supplies and resources), Handling consumer goods and others. To give the run down on Laws and Government you can choose Conscription laws. Mobilisation laws, trade laws and People you want to add to your cabinet E.G Silent Workhorse. You can also choose Research companies to decrease research times on a specific thing E.G Weapons and Artillery. Military staff will give you buffs for specific things. E.G Infantry National Focuses can give you territory political power increase the popularity of political ideologies and much more. Generic Focus Trees will often do the same but you won't have any Territorial Expansion one's. This is more of a guide than review but I really enjoyed the game overall and I'd recommend it if you haven't already got it. 8.5/10

Don't want to read? I'll shorten it down for you: I'd give Hearts of Iron IV 4/5 stars. Do want to read more? Okay here we go: There is a downside in that Hearts of Iron IV has got a steep learning curve. It isn't exactly the easiest game to get into or learn - and the tutorials suck. It's so much easier learning through continued play or watching 3rd party tutorials on something like YouTube. Then again, all Hearts of Iron games have been complex, as are the majority of strategy games nowadays anyway, so it's not anything new. The other downside is the DLCs. The DLCs tend to add content which should've been in the game to begin with. Worse off, they overcharge for the DLC - you basically pay full price for a game in just one or two DLCs. Now the positives. Firstly, some of the DLC content is good. Particularly, I like Man the Guns DLC best, La Resistance the least - although others will disagree. From what I've gathered talking to many HOI players is that there is always that one DLC someone likes the most. It'll depend entirely on you and your tastes though. Second positive is replayability. Each game can go somewhat differently, even playing the same nation. If that doesn't tickle your interest, there is quite a few nations you can play, some easy and some hard. If that still wasn't enough base game replayability for you, you can make things even more random by turning historical AI off completely. And let's not even get started on mods - more to come on those below. Third positive is the great workshop contents, i.e mods, for the game. There is literally a mod out there for everyone: from the First World War to My Little Pony, Alternate History to Meme Mods. The top mods are The Great War [WWI], Kaiserreich & Kaiserredux [both "What Ifs"], RoadTo56 [Expanded WWII], and Millenium Dawn [Modern Day], although there is mods for Cold War, Napoleonic Wars and more. The mods are almost endless, I have no doubt you'll find something you like there. These mods make the game infinitely replayable, as you can have something different each time. The third postive is graphics. Game looks good. Looks much better than Hearts of Iron III in terms of map design. The UIs are nice, as are the settings - particularly the option to disable NATO unit symbols if you are more casual and don't know what those mean. Overall, I would rate this game 87/100. Many great things about it - if you can learn to play it.

All right. Time for an honest review of this game! 350hrs into this piece would not be possible if I hated it since the beginning, at least not for me. Gameplay; You will manage resources a lot in the beginning, dismantle ineffective troops, prepare your economy for the war machine, build factories etc - you won't have "money" as we know it in this game, it is all about ore and oil. To make sure your future vehicles, boats and airforce is even able to perform you have to make sure there is enough fuel to carry them into victory and beyond. You will be clicking a lot in this game, manage units, add suitable generals and admirals to lead them, perpare your navy for patrols or whatever you need for the moment and keep an eye on diplomatic matters between your neighbours. Those who has read history about ww2 will obviously know in general what to expect - but there is an option to deviate from history if you so wish for it, in the menu. Beginner friendly? No. You will need to invest time in order to get what you can do to make the mechanics tick in your favour. Great lategame? To be honest, the endgame is sometimes quite boring or a chore depending on what you want to do. If you want to paint the map in your colours, prepare for extremely long-winded sessions. If you want to make sure you survive with a decent nation after ww2 has passed - then in my opinion, it is fun and lasts long enough. Summary; This game will suck hours of your life, make you plan your approach in your sleep or think how to make sure the fuel will last the war while you are in bed with your wife. You know... Important matters. Hrm *cough* Anyways. I say this game is great but at the same time has serious flaws. The problems; 1; Drawing the frontline can be "problematic", sometimes your army will behave truly strange, units are running back and forth like ants everytime any frontline has been pushed, wasting fuel and ppl running back and forth in enemy territory doesn't seem to have happened in the real war, you want to save the fuel as much as possible, only using it to take objectives. This running back and forth in the frontline without any real goal annoys me, especially when it sometimes leave the frontline wide open for enemy engagements without any units to stop them from your side. Problem number 2; Diplomacy.... what diplomacy? No talks are even possible at any point in the game, there is only total war, either you win over them all or the war never ends. It is stupid in my honest opinion how impossible any peacetalks are in this game. Diplomacy in ww2 did in fact exist. So why not in this game? Either way, you can simply see it this way; win the war completely or you will never have an end to it. 3; All units are the same. No matter which nation you play, your army will perform the same as the germans or the americans, even if you play the japanese. The game will provide identical numbers for your guns performance. Which is odd, looking at history how the weaponry of the nations during ww2 did perform very differently. While the americans and the germans could trust their guns, the japanese and chinese did not have the same quality at all. So when you play the japanese or the chinese, and research small arms - you will notice how your units will perform just the same as the germans or american divisions. The same for the Russians - meaning if you play Russia, you will easily find ways to make sure your army will perform just as well as the germans before the war breaks out. You can have your elite soldiers, removing the trash and holding the lines fine against the germans if you made sure your divisions have the supplies you need. 4; Some dlc's makes the game worse. From what I understand, the La resistance will make the game prolong unnecessarily long. This dlc also makes it unbalanced - just check the discussions on this topic, ppl were quite upset with this content being added into the game. I never bought this for that reason, thus I can't mention any strong points, I can only suggest you check a DLC guide to navigate your wallet's future. Waking the Tiger is a dlc I can strongly recommend if you are curious of the asian theater. I still recommend this game despite the frustrations it will give you. The hours I've put into this game for my entertainment is far cheaper and more fun than most games in the long run. Will you make it into the new world after ww2? I did and I did it as the chinese Emperor! that was fun.

So I've nearly sank 600 hours into Hearts of Iron IV. The reason being is that the game is simply too much fun. With all DLCs added to the base game, all major nations and many of the minors during the WWII era (1936-1948) has a unique and specific focus tree for their nation. And with the DLCs, you can choose to remain historical or have fun with the world and go crazy. Make the Confederate States of America return? Sure, why not. Restore the German Empire under Kaiser Wilhelm II? Absolutely! Turn the Empire of Japan into a communist power and dominate East Asia with China? What could go wrong?! There's an almost endless amount of possibilities in Hearts of Iron IV and that's why this game deserves to be in the library of any WWII fan.

Honestly, even with almost 170 hours on this game, I still don't know how to play. As a player who couldn't really afford DLC's, I still recommend HOI4 for its vast and amazing modding community. If you like grand-strategy games, HOI4 is definitely up there. The base game holds up in my experience, although I do know that some DLC's do help in improving one's experience, so if you do have a couple of bucks to spare, and you do love it, I'd say it's worth it. (but bear in mind, the lack of DLCs don't really matter that much for me, maybe it'd apply to you as well) And hey, if you're not interested in the base game, you could look towards the aforementioned modding community for even more stuff to do, want to play in alternate timelines? Modern Day? Or conquer all of Equestria in one sitting? HoI4 is just the game for you. Beware, if you do love it, it's hard to let go (as with most things ;) )

Hearts of Iron IV is an absolute masterpiece. Its a mixture of diplomacy, war, politics, and nation building all wrapped into one. The graphics are decent, the UI is clean and easy to understand with a few hours of game play. Research and development is a little time consuming but definitely adds a level of risk and strategy to the games atmosphere. You can play world superpowers such as Germany or the USA, you can even play nations as small as Haiti and Iraq. make armies with dozens to hundreds of divisions and steamroll your adversaries. Conquer the world or unite the nations under one banner. Recreate historical events and repeat the outcomes of various wars. OR take alternate paths. Dont like fascist Germany? well why not stage a coup and bring back the kaiser?! dont like Stalin leading Russia? bring back Trotsky!  Want to make britain a monarchical superpower once more?! restore the crown to its rightful place! the possibilities are plentiful and will leave you coming back for more. I rate this game an 8/10 and recommend it to both noobs and experienced players alike. I love this game and Im sure you will as well.

Glad you asked. Overall I love the game, however, here are my issues. When playing Germany historically one must conduct an "offensive war" and this lowers their "war support" number for each country they overrun. Every country German attacks they progressively lose war support and then this starts obstructing policy things they can do. This is unrealistic. I, therefore, suggest adding into the gaming algorithm "war support" gain every-time  Germany or someone else successfully conquers a country to reflect Hitler's growing popularity. For example, he achieved one of his popularity peaks when France fell in 1940 and returned to Berlin a conquering hero. Conquering the Balkans in April 1941 also further boosted it. There was also shock among the German populous when they attacked the USSR in 1941, but with the initial sweeping military successes morale dramatically increased until the setbacks in December 1941. Of course, as the Allies capture occupied territory their "war support" should equally rise. The second issue I have with the game in Great Britain'a ability to rapidly rebuild their army after France gets overrun in 1940 and literally launch large scale counter invasions by early 1941 against occupies France. I've literally destroyed the BEF (meaning no Dunkirk) and within six months they're invading France with dozens of divisions. - in addition to fighting in North Africa and Abyssinia. Large scale amphibious invasions are complicated things not easily done by divisions just created one week earlier. This is unrealistic. Their ability to rebuild a battle effective army needs to be toned-down some. They didn't have that historic capability. Otherwise, I think you people have a hit on your hands and I love the game.

Take control of any country starting either in 1936 or 1939 (nobody seems to play this second starting date) Build the nation for war, in the defensive or ready to attack your neighbours. Your industrial capacity is the major resource of the game, measured in factories. Whoever has played the tabletop Axies and Allies will get this. Along with this, the "focus" system is a really nice implement, as it allows to take certain political paths that will make easier certain aspects during the mid and late game (for example, being a totalitarian fascist or communist makes faster the process of going and fighting wars while democracies are better at other things, as long as the so-called non-aligned system) It is well worth getting DLCs in order to play certain countries, such as Spain, Turkey or the Chinese warlords as it makes them more deep and interesting. The vanilla versions of most countries are very lame sometimes. The major problem of this game is that is way too focused on the military aspect. Is not a usual Paradox Grand Strategy in the sense that you are, in this case, way too attached to a very specific historic event, the 2WW, making almost all your decision about participating in it, or avoiding it, and fighting the actual war can be really difficult, with a lot of small mechanics hard to grasp And here is where we come to another major problem. This has a very pronounced learning curve. It requires constant replays in order to just grasps the basics, and good part of getting good at it is getting yourself familiarized with the different mechanics and processes of all the major countries in Historic mode, so it's quite time consuming. You maybe start to truly enjoy it after your first 100 hours, so be aware of this. That level of difficulty, as it happens with other Paradox Titles, is related to the fact that is complex, deep, and therefore enjoyable for those that actually like these aspects in a game. Is still being worked on, with new content released regularly, the developers seem to be very obsessed with resurrecting past monarchies for some reason, and too focused in alt-history scenarios that are too far from the main historic plot. In my opinion, is fun trying to win as republican Spain or conquer India with Japan, but some other scenarios are way too divergent, specially considering that the average campaign is 5 to 10 years. Hope this is useful if you are thinking of buying the game. Better go for a bundle.

One of the greates WW2 strategy games, especially if you are a history buff like me. It can be quite intimidating to start without prior knowledge about how the game works so i reccomend watching tutorials on YouTube. Also there are quite a few DLC's so just play the base game first, see if you like it and then start investing in the DLC's. Most DLC's add interesting new alternate history path for nations and add new mechanics to the game. So look what each DLC has to offer and make a choice from there. This game also has a amazing modding community so it's worth checking that out as well. This game might not be for everyone but either way it's a great game and i can't recommend it enough.

TLDR: No game which essentially costs $100+ should still be lacking basic flavour for the 5 major nations of WW2. __ Despite owning all of the Expansions I find this game still lacking. For instance, the USSR is a a major player in WW2. One of the 5 majors actually (Germany, Japan, UK, USA, USSR), yet it's focus tree is so lacking that basically nothing happens if "Trotsky Returns" to power. He doesn't have his own tree. There are no special mechanics attached. Pretty much just a picture change. I would think that having Trotsky as a leader vs. Stalin during WW2 would have been some sort of difference. Basically the same goes for all of the 5 majors. Lazy work by the devs. I want to love HOI4, but this is just unacceptable when focus trees are easy manipulations to make to the game and they can add very good immersion/flavour.
People who like strategy games will enjoy this.

Yes and No, Great and Terrible... To be honest it's a great game, but the problem lies in its repetitiveness. Every play is very similar and as the game is built around "National focuses" there is not much to be done here. The time period and mechanics make playing nations other than "mains''(Bigger and stronger countries like Germany, France, Japan) or few interesting "minors"(like austria, yugoslavia, ect.) totally senseless as you won't ever have power to fight bigger and stronger countries and have a really slow, possibly boring game. It can be great for the first 100-200 hours, after that not much to be done the game becomes boring, once great mods extending content now has a lot of bugs due to changes in code implementation during game development and (understandable)laziness of moders not wanting to change whole mods, because of paradox changing vision. Additionally a lot of new mechanics or DLC's seem forced, too big and steal ideas from mods existing before their release. On top of that the problem of late game lag, when the game slows down dramatically late game. Overall you can just be playing a version of "Waking of the Tiger" release and have the same experience if not better, because of less calculations = better performance, less buggy mods and no forced content. Solid production, repetitive, but allowing for 100-200 hours of fun, which can be extended by playing multiplayer games if you have intention and time to or installing yet not broken mods. Personally i preferred older versions, but it‚Äôs not bad...

Product received for free Very fun game, has a large modding community that keep making the game fresh to play and vast amount of decision making in the 'Decisions' tab, knowing what you need at what point in the 'Research' tab, and knowing where you want to end at in the 'Focus' tree of any nation. Nearly every country has a unique focus tree, but to get the best out of this game is to buy the content DLC (non-cosmetic ones) for the base/vanilla gameplay with some needed for some mod packs. Also, when playing with mods, some may be outdated for the current version of the game or some mods are discontinued altogether, so be wary of that. It is a hard game to play at first, but after a while of playing, you will either still be a dingus with what you want to do or be a unstoppable force. I recommend watching some YouTube videos and play for a day or two to get the hang of things for any new players.

The mechanics of this game are great. It focuses heavily on the strategic and tactical aspects of Grand Strategy, with a smaller side of Management. Most of the management is, at the end, military. Even when choosing to become a new nation through a focus, or making a decision, it is about military. This heavily military-based gameplay implies that being a neutral nation is not a viable option. That being said, the game doesn't pretend it is; but it does render the game's management aspect considerably simpler than other paradox games. It also means that the battle mechanics are much deeper and complex than other paradox games. The game receives a variety of DLCs, addons, and updates; and has an incredible community for both online game and modding. It is overall a great game, and a good starting point for incredibly complicated grand strategy titles such as the rest from Paradox.

This Game is great as the player has the choice to keep history accurate or create his/her alternate timeline. The Player has a lot of free choice and can us custom options to allow or disallow certain this from happening or limiting them. Can also choose a set path nations in the game which is something that i like. Although there are a lot of things about the game i like as i am a history buff but also have a thing for alternate, i think there are some improvements and changes a swell as future DLCs i would like to see. The thing i don't like in this game is that peace treaty's are often horrible as they are either not very historically accurate or do things that does not make any sense. I would like it if in single-player the peace treaty should be player led as it can give the player more choice to make an alternate peace treaty to wars or keeping them historically accurate. A thing i would like to see is a DLC to where you can sign ceasefires or armistices to bring a temporally halt to a war in both single-player and multiplayer which would have a set period of time to last when it is up the player or in multiplayer other player could be given the option to continue there wars or sign peace treaty's. Overall the game is great and always tries to remain historically accurate and the players have a lot of freedom to create their own alternate history's or try to keep things historically accurate.

Hearts of Iron 4 has truly revolutionized the modern grand strategy game. As a fan of most things Paradox releases, HOI4 has to be one of my favorite games of all time. Paradox masterfully takes one of the most brutal conflicts in history, and they created a game that allows you to follow or create history at your very command. You could micromanage to the nearest division and factory, or draw battle lines for the AI generals to follow when in combat. I have had this game since almost the very beginning and it has drastically improved with every DLC / update that has been released. However, that has to be the downside for me, and for most people that ever want to get into a Paradox game. Without the DLC, HOI4 is nearly unplayable, as the DLC adds very important mechanics that make the game 10 times better. They have done a good job of releasing free content updates as these DLC have been released, but the base game feels extremely bland and almost unfinished in hindsight. I recommend getting this game during a sale, so most of the money spent could go towards the purchasing of DLC. Additional note : for those who aren't big fans of this game, due to its simplification from HOI3 to HOI4, I understand the dislike. However, I believe simplification has only helped more people enter the community, as I remember getting into HOI3 and it had the steepest learning curve known to man. This games ease of access and understanding allows for more and more people to immerse themselves into this world of constant conflict. Additional Additional Note : The mod support and workshop for this game is absolutely amazing. There are so many mods and communities of modders that spend their days toiling away to create fresh new experiences and flavors for this game, and to them I say, well done!

I'm a huge sucker for Paradox games, so take this with a grain of salt: this is one of their best 4X games. I've put a couple hundred hours into Stellaris and thought that was the end-all be-all of grand strategy games, but there's nothing quite like Hearts of Iron 4. If you're a big fan of World War II, and especially if you're a big fan of alt-history "what-if's" regarding World War II, you'll love this game and end up buying every piece of DLC for it. Over 350 hours into this game and I've "won" maybe 3 times - that's not to say I haven't gotten what I wanted out of it, but this game is extremely challenging. I've just began playing this game and I absolutely love it. The only MAJOR flaw with this game is the learning curve. The tutorial is not that helpful, leaving crucial functions out which would be crucial to learn, and the UI makes it hard to learn functions which could change the outcome of whole game. I'm being serious here. 1. It took me 50 hours to learn, where I constantly googled why certain things happened, what things would do, how to do things. I did this all the while playing the Soviet Union which if I had to tell myself when starting the game, I would tell them to try Germany. 2. On the UI, I saw another player mention the same problem, saying they missed you could attach air planes to armies to help them and he had an astounding 100 or 1000 hours in the game(I memory is fuzzy on what number it exactly was) So what should you play this game for? To relive WW2? Or live a new war, or no war at all. Or just command an army of whatever nation as you combat the, unique challenges each one faces with different tactics to geography and different equipment, and internal problems whether it be ideological or economic. the game is incredible with it's scale and freedom.

Product received for free Quite frankly, I've played this game too much. I love it to bits, and I've literally kicked the Germans asses in so many ways that I couldn't count them all on 10 pairs of hands and feet squared. It's the only game where a Communist Luxembourg can conquer the world by 1943, or a Fascist Bhutan can nuke Hiroshima before the Americans. Wanna be Ireland and send paratroopers onto Buckingham Palace? You can do that. Wanna be El Salvador and Send a massive army of unequipped peasants to Washington DC and take over America? You can do that Wanna be Bomber Harris and fly not just, 1000 bomber raids, not just, 2000 bomber raids, but 10,000 bomber raids over Berlin.............................every night?????? You can do that. Its an amazing game, with so many possibilities and one that I have so many memories in, such as hotjoining a game as Bulgaria where my friends who had reformed the central powers, yet declared war in 1938 so we were literally dead by 1940. Or in my first Soviet Game ever (Singleplayer, I had had the game for 4 hours at this points) and doing a mega chad Operation Uranus and surrounding 70 German divisions and then trucking onto Berlin. Yet its soul destroying, you sell your soul to the overlords at paradox. So many DLCS, and none of them updating any of the countries that actually need the updates the most. Paradox: "Hey communitaaayyy, its time for another DLC. Horrayyy" HOI4 Players: "Does this one finally update the Italian focus tree??" Paradox: "No, but it does give you some brand spanking new music, and minor updates to Hungary (:" I've spent more money on HOI4, than all the other games in my steam library combined, and while the devs are great, they do purposely make it impossible for new players to join as once you buy the base game, you have to pay triple the price again just for the DLCS to even catch up to everyone else. Yet its arguably worth it. This game has brought me rage and joy, but given me 'mostly' amazing memories, so I do believe that every penny has been worth it. But maybe, if you do end up buying the game, just wait a month or so to see if you like it before buying allllll the DLCS.... and then maybe wait just a little bit longer for a sale to actually buy them. So my final opinion, buy it. You'll love it and hate it, but its so worth it in the end.

A review in waiting for a bit of time, but when you start measuring up games to one another, that is when you know you got a real gem (and when you know when it is time to write a review).  And that is what we have here:  I had recently purchased another WWII game, Panzer Corps 2, and I couldn't help but measure it up to HoI4.  (It was lacking, in case you were curious).  Indeed, HoI4 has to be probably one of the best WWII RTS 4X games that I have ever played.  I absolutely love this game.  It ranks up there as one of my most favorite RTS 4X games of all time.  However, this does not mean that the game does not come without its faults, because, believe you me, it does, such as persistent bugs, to name the most prevalent one.  On a scale of 1 to 10, 8-9.5/10, overall. With the TL;DR out of the way, what makes this game so awesome? ‚Ä¢ The sheer complexity of it!  It is by far the most expansive, in-depth WWII strategy games which plays right into the fact that ‚Ä¢ You can really explore the what-ifs of history, creating alternative histories (this is really where HoI4 shines); and ‚Ä¢ Since you can play any country of the world, including Nazi Germany, you can experiment with historical decisions to even change the very course of history, including to where Nazi German wins the war. ‚Ä¢ Modding!  The base game is already pretty good, but the large, active modding community propels the game into an epic quality that makes HoI4 unrivaled, made possible by Paradox's support of it.  The modding community of this game will likely keep it active and relevant years after Paradox, like Bethesda's Skryim. ‚Ä¢ Paradox seems to legitimately care for their game.  The zeal, love, and passion the devs have for HoI4 clearly shows. But, as I mentioned earlier, the game doesn't come without its faults, and there some big ones: ‚Ä¢ The complexity of game does mean there is a significant learning curve.  Unlike the in-game tutorial, YouTube is your friend.  (Although, last I heard, Paradox did state that they are working on the in-game tutorial.  Perhaps sometime in the future this bullet will be removed); ‚Ä¢ Bug, bugs, and more bugs.  Fortunately, nothing game-breaking (at least at the time of this review), but this game has a lot of bugs, including and up to where the AI does things that not only are a-historical, but even things that leave you confounded and frustrated; ‚Ä¢ The devs seem to emphasize PvP, quick to fix bugs there; but with PvE the bugs keep amassing, bugs that had been reported sometimes several expansions previous; ‚Ä¢ The lack of dev support of the Steam community.  If you have an issue or problem or a suggestion, you best post in the official Paradox forums.  Posting it to Steam, it will be ignored (I don't think I've ever seen a dev respond once on Steam); ‚Ä¢ The pay-walling content content that should be in the base game in the name of a DLC is not cool; ‚Ä¢ Similarly, and the last con I would give the game, giving the community texture packs as of a manner to say thank you for years of playing and yet making the community pay for it, it is not really much of a thank you -- it is more of an insult. In conclusion, if you are someone who grew up playing let's say the Total War franchise, then HoI4 would be right your alley.  There is not as much micromanagement as there is with Total War, but HoI4 falls right in line with it in terms of complexity and epicness.  This game, HoI4 is pure awesomeness, well worth a purchase and play.  The base game, on a scale of 1 to 10, I would give an 8/10.  With modding, 9.5/10.

I once almost burst my blood vessel playing HOI4, when its advanced AI and logistical system forced me to retreat from the Soviet soil. Then they marched into Germany, and I was trying to micromanage and reorder my own front, giving different orders to the battle AI in a futile attempt to fix the situation. I imagined myself having moved to a bunker at that point, giving orders to my generals, and when they failed to carry them out, I would call my generals to the war room and give them a dressing down. This game provides immense RP capabilities, so excellent, that I was red-faced by the time I was done screaming at the wall. I almost shot myself when Soviet troops had entered Berlin.

I haven't played the Hearts of Iron series since 2009 and I wasn't really much of a fan. I picked up HOI4 on the summer sale and let me tell you all. It is one of the most complicated RTS games out there. As a newcomer who only has 15 hours in the game so far, you would have to delve deep inside your soul to find the time to learn the game and not give up on it. Once you understand the general knowledge of the game it can be so STATISFYING. I would recommend though to play a couple of trial runs and tutorials on Youtube because the in-game tutorial on it stinks. It Is a Paradox made game. the same company that gave us Supreme Ruler and Stellaris. Although so far, the drawbacks i see so far is your HUD will be cluttered with information  and especially when you get ready to organize your divisions and armies, there is no easy way to organize your troops in one shortcut key so be prepared. HOI4 is not for the faint of heart and impatient people but if you are a big fan of history and RTS I would strongly recommend HOI4. It has become my second favorite RTS next to Civilization 5.  Don't say I didn't warn you about the commitment to it.

OK, I've played this game for over 400 hours.  And parts of it are just wonderful.  BUT!  Once you start actually fighting, the game is nearly unplayable.  Two repeated examples:  1)  The AI shoves 40 divisions into Norway.  It then allows a few German units to recapture the ports and the 40 divisions just die.  2)  In New Guinea, the AI manages to land invasions all around the island no matter how much Navy you stack up to prevent it. I am also stunned that despite all the updates, there seems to be no way to really coordinate with allies.  Australia won't cede even a little island to me, even though they were getting shredded. Considering you have to play through the "peace" game for years as the US, the payoff is just awful.  Maybe I'm missing something, but I've watched hours of tutorial video, so there's that.  You have to get a master's degree to play the game.  Now, ordinarily, that would be a GOOD thing for me.  But seriously, stop putting up DLC and fix some of the basic issues with the AI.

The game premise is interesting and there's an active and vibrant community that's a real plus. But the AI and path finding is inexcusably bad for a game that has received as many patched, DCL and updates as this. The problems have existed since its very beginning At the very least give us the option to truly disable automatic path finding. The button to do so does exist, but is purely cosmetic. Troops will move entirely on random, without any way to stop them and will get themselves killed or stuck.

Some of the DLC is absolutely a cash grab, I wouldn't suggest any of the audio unless it's on sale. I'd also skip battle for bosporus and man the guns entirely. But the rest of the game is magnificent. Wonderful music, engaging gameplay with depth. Many strategies will work, and this game will punish you for those that don't.

pretty in-depth strategy that requires a dive into the deep end of the learning curve pool, but once you figure out how all the logistical systems work from production and research to division templates, it's pretty engrossing.  Even when playing with Historical Focuses, no two games are alike.  The bigger DLC mainly adds additional country focuses which I recommend along with the music packs.  The other cosmetic DLC really isn't essential, and you only notice when zoomed in, which you rarely are when playing.  Paradox continues to update and patch post-launch, which is always nice for complex strategy games like this. Overall, like a lot of strategy games, it's easy to sink many hours into HOI4, which IMO gives it a lot of value for strategy gamers willing to take the plunge

An awesome WWII strategy game that has a lot of detail and many possibilities. You can choose to play historically or you can create your own alternative history. There is singleplayer and multiplayer as well. Also, you are not just limited to the vanilla game, there are tons of mods that add entirely new scenarios, focus trees, and more if you get bored of playing in the same time period. I would only recommend buying the dlc's if they are on sale. The dlc's add a good amount of new content and focus trees but in my opinion only worth buying if its on sale. It can be hard to learn at first but once you get the hang of it it's really fun. I've enjoyed many hours in this game and fully recommend this game if your into strategy games, or even if you haven't played one or enjoyed one before, i'm pretty sure you will find Hearts of Iron IV enjoyable either way.

It's a great game if you are willing to at accept that your fun is going to primarily come from playing Germany for many hours. The systems are incredibly deep, that of which in your first couple hundred hours of game-play/watching how-to's will probably only finally get you your first win after many MANY attempts (exclusively playing a major power that can carry your inexperience). That being said, it is a blast to play if you enjoy games of the same type. Don't buy it if you're thinking it'll be just like a video you saw, or it'll only take a couple hours to get down the basics and that'll be enough. In the event you want to seamlessly win, every choice matters, and learning what choices to make takes a long time just to get down for a country that isn't Tanna Tuva. That being said, the options for game-play are endless within a massive modding community and a very extensive base game. But one should also beware the DLC, like an Paradox game, locks behind it an array of very interesting game-play features, so if a good sale hits and you've got the cash, spring for full price and just buy the DLC too if you want to really commit to playing this game. --

The game is in depth relying on careful allocation of factories, resources and units. If you enjoy careful strategy and diplomatic action this is the game for you. With multiple different countries and strategies each game varies depending on the country you pick, it's geographical location, it's ideology and manpower. There is total freedom and can be as easy or challenging as you choose. Communist USA totally possible, Mongolia against the world and so many other scenarios are possible. Personally I have also purchased two DLCs which totally rework and expand the game but do not feel you need to. HOI4 is a great game, with or without DLCs.

This is a very addicting game. For me there was a steep learning curve and I still use mods/cheats to get by but it's a lot of fun. 50 hours in and I enjoy the game very much. If you've ever wanted to try your hand at controlling a world power during WWII, this is the game for you. You don't have to have the DLC but I have found that it adds an additional layer of immersion, plus there is just more to do at that point when researching different naval armaments or building your intelligence network. Picking it up on sale is what I did and I would recommend that for others too. 7/10

If this were ever addressed, then HOI4 would be truly awesome.

I recommend this game. But beware, if you buy this game you will age twice as fast and you will suddenly have a full beard after one night. - It's a great game and by far my most played one. Took me around 80 hours to learn the game, even though I still learn something new every now and then. In my case I play mostly SP 'cause I can play at my own speed. Played around 60 hours MP and I can tell you it's great. If you got a bunch of friends try it. Between the historical and altenative history ways a game can go you will find a wide variety of different mods that can make the game even better. Modding is one of the best things if you're done with the base game. If you're interested in the achievements, I hope you bring some steel nerves with you. It takes a whole lot of time. Well now go and enjoy a bit of World War 2 at it's finest.

I've played all of the HoI games since the beginning, and HoI 4 is the absolute worst one of the lot. They took a great game, HoI 3, and added a right click, alt-click, control-click and shift click-fest to all of the orders. The army command menu is the absolute worst that I have ever played in any game. It's almost impossible to navigate or understand what your divisions are going to do along the front now. I don't know about you, but I actually like to micro-manage all of my divisions and control which ones are going to support what attack. Well, you can't do that anymore in this game. The game decides that for you. Don't buy it. The so called "planning" feature is something that you cannot control, nor decide how long to do it. Divisions randomly walk in unknown directions for unknown reasons. Ridiculous for a World War 2 game.

The game has a steep learning curve, but with the ample help of YouTube tutorials, and *lots* of patience, it is incredibly satisfying to control your own nation. Positives aside, it can be incredibly difficult to learn the game at first, and can be quite disheartening to have the nation that you have been building up for hours to be crushed in a matter of moments. The game is incredibly high quality, and aside from a few annoyances, I would certainly recommend it to anyone who enjoys grand strategy games, and has time to kill. PS: I would recommend a number of DLC's. Namely, Death or Dishonour, and Together for Victory. They really enrich the experience, and make the game even better to play.

Er... apparently I've racked up 100 hours (and that's just since I stopped sailing the high seas with this game...) I think this is one of the best Paradox games. The diversity of units, officers, traits, and multi-layers of combat really helps where other Paradox titles basically just have "men" which you send at "other men". Historical element is also really fun and the modding scene is fantastic. I think where it falls down is in the late-game; much like pretty much every grand strategy game; and also a lack of closure at the end (I want historical replay of the map with decisions and graphs which move over time... not just a screen with 'scores' on it saying 'well done, game over'.)

I will still play this every once in a while, but for the most part I will be sticking with the Total War games or the Civilization franchise.

Captain of Direct Review at your service GENERAL Immerse yourself in the world stirred by politics and wars. Command the nation of your choice, emerge victorious. Manage your country, turn it into unstoppable war machine. Shape your country into anything you desire using any political means. Form a coalition with any country you like and crush the opposing faction. Lead your people in the land wasted by turmoil of wars and bring them victory they deserve. PROS - [+] + Different game play compared to another RTS games + Detailed unit controls + Different focus tree for every major nations + Control the battlefield on the land, sea, and air CONS - [x] x Challenging for new RTS players x Base game only has one map x Additional purchases needed CONCLUSION - [8/10] The game itself is really good, especially if you're a RTS genre fan. The game play may not appealing to some players as this game is really different from the others. But if you want to experience an in-depth RTS game you may buy this game. The freedom of controls given to the players over the units are astonishing as you can control the size and the movement of each of your battalion. You can create an alternate history where the Americans are communist, topple Hitler from the leadership of nazi, etc. Control of the battlefield using the prowess of your soldiers, conquer the seas with a powerful navy, dominate the sky with valiant air force.

This game is currently my favorite game to play right now. The achievements can be a grind to get (especially since many require good rng), and going really far into a game requires a good pc or the game is too slow to play, however those are probably my only two complaints in the game. This game has so many different branches for tons of countries that I am sure you could have 1,000 hours in-game and still be able to have branches to explore. The workshop is also incredible, and adds thousands more potential hours to the game. Also, the DLCs are very much worth getting as they add most of the replayability in the game, and most of the interesting paths to take.

Wish there was a neutral thumb button cause there is fun to be had here but holy cheese balls is it a difficult nut to crack. First obstacle is the woefully insufficient tutorial, in a game that contains a nearly endless possibilities for setting up battlefronts, fall back lines, coordinating logistics and supplies, having the user mount one offensive in Ethiopia with minimal autonomy or complexity is woefully inadequate. It's like dropping someone in the middle of Rainbow Six Siege, telling them that left stick is to move, right trigger is to shoot, then throwing them into the full game. The second thing you have to contend with is the SINGLE WORST UI I have ever experience in a game of this type. CKIII, the old Total War games, Command & Conquer, I have played most of the ones of the block, if not for life altering amounts hours at least long enough to hang around for the vibe. Good freaking lord it's not even close HOI4 has the worst user interface I have ever experienced in game of this type. Since I am not one to complaint without receipts; "WASD" is not used to pan since so many of the keyboard buttons open the in game menus which would be fine except for the facts that "ASD" are unused while "W" was reserved to open of the top menus in the game (the 1-0 buttons do nothing fyi) and that the user can pan without clicking the wheel on the mouse and several important buttons are on the bottom of the screen. The game has no problem telling you that you are short materials for your war effort, then will proceed to open the production page - not the trade one, where you know, would import materials for tanks and guns - where it is up to the user to go through the produced items line by line to see if you even are short any materials or if you are even producing the godforsaken item that it's telling you don't have enough material for. Maybe there's any easier to check this, but the tutorial sure didn't cover it. The UI is constantly throwing a 'decisions available' button with a bright red exclamation point at you when you accrue the slightest bit of political clout - this is WWII, the most devastating war in the history of mankind - do you have decide whether the motherland will invade Poland to put a few more hundred KM between the German war machine and Moscow? Do you have decide if Japan attacking a U.S. civilian ship is enough to escalate world tensions and go to war in pacific? Must you answer the call of your most hated historical rival and go across the channel to help the French fight back the blitzkrieg? Nah, you simply have enough political power to enact small bluffs on your population that are significantly less useful early game than the ability to appoint major government officials and making sweeping economy and military policy changes which you used the same bank of political power to do. If you enjoy these kind of top down war simulators that are a different take on the RTS genre and enjoy learning about the history of WWII and the era of politics around it, you should pick it up cause the game is genuinely fun, it just between the dreadful tutorial and awful UI, the devs would've had to actively try to make it less inviting to new players.

I first discovered HOI years ago with the 3rd installment. Once HOI4 released, it was a done deal. This is grand strategy with a focus on the military side of things. Armies need to be organised from the battalion level. Everything can be rearranged and renamed. Want the US Marines? Done. Besides military, you must worry about production of arms as well as maintaining factories for consumer goods. Way more manageable than it may sound. Politics is also a factor, you may put ministers in your cabinet which favor democracy or fascism or yes even communism. Want to play alt history? Make the US go fascist? Maybe kill hitler and bring back the kaiser as Germany? Have Japan embrace democratic rule, peacefully? Full steam ahead. HOI4 is your sandbox. Spy mechanics are implemented in a non game breaking way, which is to say you can get up to mischief but its not going to bring down the USSR by its lonesome. Naval mechanics are wonderful and diverse. You research technologies for better weapons, planes and ships. Once you unlock a design, you are free to put what armaments you like on the "Class" of ship. I personally make carriers with maximum airplane capacity. Since, if you're using the carriers right, you will sink fleets without your fleet ever engaging in battle. The planes will do the job. Finally, I will say terrain and supply chains are crucial to playing HOI4. Dont send your beefed up huge infantry army into south america! Unless you like seeing entire armies ground into the jungle. The terrain wont allow you to resupply or move properly. On top of that, your guys are dropping like flies to the climate etc. HOI4 forces you to create marines or light infantry units to campaign in certain regions. There is an endless amount of entertainment here, well executed and when ya get bored of vanilla? Paradox games have some of the most talented, long running modding communities ive ever seen. "Old World Blues" "Millenium Dawn" "Kaiserreich" to name a few popular total conversions. Cheers!

The ultimate World War 2 strategy game. You can play historically and try to defend France from the German Reich, or play as the Soviet Union and prepare for the coming storm, or even play as Germany and try and conquer the world. This game goes beyond that with alternate history that lets you take command of any nation and play out World War 2 as it. The controls can be a bit daunting at first, but once you have them down, you have a game with near unlimited replay value. It is so easy to see why so many people have sunk hundreds and thousands of hours into this game.

Extremely difficult, but even more rewarding when you get the grasp of it. Perhaps the best historically accurate strategy game ever made. If you enjoy ww2 in your personal life, not just in gaming, but the kinda person that gets excited when you learn something new about the war, you'l appreciate this game for both its authenticity, and ability to play out different scenarios such as Germany allying with soviet union ...etc. Don't worry about the DLC content, play the base game, or add some free mods later. Take time to learn it, give it a chance, and expect to lose a few times before you really understand how to play.  For me, its a enjoyable game to play occasionally when thinking about ww2, not a everyday, or every weekend kinda game, but a good respectable game to have in my library. It goes on sale several times a year, grab it, or some DLC when its 50% off.

Personally, this is one of my favorite games of all time. The way that the grand strategy genre mixes with WW2 is fantastic, and there are many layers of depth to this game that can hold you over for hundreds, if not thousands of hours. Due to the game complexity, there will be times in the beginning that you may not know what is going on or have difficulties understanding game mechanics. Experimenting, using the tutorial and watching players on Youtube and Twitch helped me learn to play this game, although it did take a couple hundred hours of gametime before I felt like I really understood the game mechanics. The nations you play as in the base game and DLCs also have their fair share of alternate historical paths, such as Communist United States or Fascist United Kingdom, etc. In addition, this game has one of the best mod scenes of any game, with some mods such as Kaiserreich, Equestria at War and Road to '56, among others, providing even more content and playtime to the player. Overall, Hearts of Iron IV is a fantastic grand strategy game that will hold you for many hours if you become invested in the gameplay and mechanics.

HOI4 is literally my most played game on Steam.  A game that offers an amazing level of depth and truely makes you feel like a general when you start to master all of the different aspects that you need to manage. It immerses you in history and offers great insights in to certain alternate histories as well. It's relatively easy to pick up but there's always something new to learn and you'll certainly learn a lot faster by watching videos or finding someone who can teach you. The developers constantly keep this game up-to-date and making free improvements for all to enjoy as well as releasing new paid DLC. Not to mention the litany of free mods that are available some of which have so much content they may as well be a whole other game. I can honestly say if there was one studio that represented a model for how to engage with their players and continue to support a game it would be the HOI4 team at Paradox.
