I have 1,300 hours on this game, and yet despite that, I would say you shouldn't get this game. Like other paradox games, the base game is pretty much garbage and not worth it unless on a good sale, and the DLC that make the game good are costly. It is $121 currently for all of the DLC. The game, with all the DLC, is not worth $121. Multiplayer is toxic, singleplayer is repetitive. Every game as Germany you do the exact same thing, it isn't fun after a few playthroughs. The one reason I could see someone getting this game (with all of the DLCs) is for the modding, which is excellent, some of the best on Steam. So unless you want to play TNO or Kaiserreich, I would recommend not getting this game. Not much strategy, just spam 20 width divisions or 40 width divisions and try to make as many tanks as you can. The game itself is 7.8/10. Too much water.

Well, after five enjoyable years playing this game, I can safely say that it is one of the greatest grand strategy (or map-painting) games I have ever played, and I've played a lot! Although I was skeptical of the automated battle plans as opposed to the much more manual nature of military plans in Hearts of Iron III, I have come to appreciate them for being both easy to learn and more fun (haha arrow go brrrr). In general, I would say that Paradox really succeeded at making a game that was neither too easy and watered down or too obtuse and difficult; I have taught some of my friends how to play the game, and they were all able to pick up the game rather quickly. The modding community for the game is also incredible; I especially recommend Kaiserreich if you want to experience something different - it's very well made and provides a great alternate experience to Vanilla. I admit that I have spent way too much of my time on this game, but the time I've spent on it has always been both relaxing and fun. There's nothing like being rewarded with an hour of HOI4 after finishing all of my work for the day, and the experiences I've had playing this game, both by myself and with others online, have been amazing (except when it comes to the toxicity of some servers). Overall, I'm very happy with the game, and look forward to the 1.11 update along with the No Step Back expansion for further improvements, especially supply (give me my railroads and trains!). P.S. It would be very irresponsible of me to not mention that this game is pretty addicting and can lead to a rapid drop in one's social skills. Luckily, I never really had them to begin with, but please remember to take breaks if you get tired and to go outside.

The only game that makes me feel like "Grand" belongs in Grand Strategy . From 1936 onwards, you have complete strategic freedom, a kind that truly feels global. The game asks you to step into the shoes not just of a nation's leader, but of history, ideology, nationhood itself. For all its faults, for all its nickel-and-diming DLC, for all the little inaccuracies, this is one of the most detailed geopolitical simulations of all time (certainly the most detailed when considering the 20th century), and the only one to attempt both the political economy and combat of WWII. To appreciate it, you have to be the kind of person that can withstand its brutal and intensely steep initial learning curve--but once surmounted, it is unbelievably gratifying to successfully hold the Eastern Front, launch the D-Day invasion, complete the Blitzkrieg, or make an alternate history Operation Sea Lion. Winning the Chinese Civil War successfully captures the grueling year-after-year attrition of that conflict, and coming out on top (as whichever side) feels sufficiently accomplished. One note: this is more of an afterthought, but while the game does skirt around issues of state violence and war crimes by allowing the player to employ repressive police & labor discipline regimes in occupied territories, the broader questions surrounding the crimes committed during WWII are never brought into the foreground. Obviously, Paradox wants this to be a palatable consumer product, and I understand their decision. On the other hand, I think anybody about to spend a serious amount of time essentially roleplaying the most violent conflict in human history should be prepared to wrangle with the ethical implications, and we should at least mention the fact that this game does not ask players to do that. Does that make it a worse or less fun game? Not at all--but maybe there's more to it than that.

Best strategic game currently on the market. Allows vast customization to any chosen nation that was around in 1936. You can either follow the course of history in WWII, or you can choose your own path and even achieve world domination. Some examples of the variety of choices are; making the USA a communist nation, ruling the world as the USSR, firing atomic bombs on London, and much, much more. Games end when you lose your nation or when you choose to leave. Some one could even reach the year 2000 and still be able to continue onward. The game itself atempts to be realistic, with one of the only exceptions being the changing of our current world history. This game does require patience, and games can take up to an average of over 100+ hours, but a convenient save system allows you to play your game according to your schedule. It includes both a single player and a multiplayer mode but I haven't had the chance to try the latter just yet. I would highly recommend this game to people who enjoy strategy games, history, entertainment, and even sometimes someone who wants to try something new. Thanks!

Where to even start with this game... I have played this game for many, many hours, and yet still not nearly as many as some, and there are still so many things I haven't explored at all. Some of the main things this game has going for it are its depth, its freedom, and the feeling of satisfaction it provides its players. The game places you the player in charge of a country going into World War Two, and from there you can take it in many different direction. You can transform them politically (to an extent). You build their industry and decide what military equipment to produce for your growing military, including Navy and Air Forces. Later on you can decide which countries to attack and who to make friends with, although there are limits to what you can do. For example you can't exactly make great friends with someone whose land you've annexed, or has historical reasons to hate you. The basic vanilla game is pretty good. The pieces are put together in a way that probably won't make much sense to the player the first time they pick it up, yet is still interesting and cool enough to keep them coming back. I remember being overwhelmed the first time I played a game, which wasn't helped by the fact I played as the Soviet Union, one of the largest countries in the game with the largest starting number of divisions. And yet I came back for another few hundred hours of gameplay because it's so fascinating how the game lets you explore so many possible courses of history. However, the base game is rather limited. Many countries do not have their own "focus trees" - the branching path of decisions that strengthen your country in various ways and give it a path going forward, but only have generic ones instead. Because of this I only played the base game for a fraction of the total time I've spent playing the game as a whole. Once I discovered the depth and scope of the mods scene for this game I ended up sinking so many nights and days off into this game, fully immersed in the level of commitment and work some people have put into the mods for this game. Kaiserreich, End of a New Beginning, Fuhrerreich, Millennium Dawn, Old World Blues, even Lord of the Rings and Avatar mods are all new things to explore and although each has its own flaws and bugs and problems I find myself coming back to them over and over again as someone who likes grand strategy games. But no game is without its flaws, of course, and focus shouldn't be solely on how much certain people like this game. To be certain, there are going to be people who will see parts of this game and throw up their hands in resignation. For example, the "division designer" system still makes almost no sense to me even after hundreds of hours of playing this game. There are about 20 different statistics one must understand when designing a good setup for their military units, and some are much easier to understand than others. In addition the Naval system makes little sense to me and I generally end up losing my whole Navy within a few months of the start of a war. The faction system is deeply irritating to me, as are the literally dozens of popups that will come up onto the screen all at once when something major happens, accompanied by a freeze in gameplay so long it makes you think your whole computer has crashed. Speaking of which, twice now I have experienced a problem after closing my laptop where after reopening it I had to forcibly shut down the computer and restart, one time crashing so badly I had to reinstall windows. I don't entirely blame Hearts of Iron 4 for that, because I don't actually know what caused it, but I think from a technical perspective the game does have some bugs and optimization issues.

This game has taken more than 1000 hours of my life from me, and counting. Overall, HOI4 provides a variety of great gameplay experiences and is a MUST buy for anyone with an interest in WW2 grand strategy games - 9/10 HOI4 has a high level of replayability, which has kept me entertained and playing ever since it was first released five years ago. The world Paradox has built offers you a wealth of different gameplay opportunities across every theater of war, with every nation being playable and each of the major country having a unique feel and range of decisions to make which impact your playthrough. Most major countries have both historical and ahistorical paths available to you. However, my only criticism of HOI4 is that it isn't as complex as its predecessor, although I look forward to future DLC which promises to add more depth to the game, such as with a more developed supply system and logistical network. Definitely play the game with the BLACK ICE mod installed as it adds much more depth, such as and increases the historical nature of your game.

The game mechanics are easy to understand and incredible. Eventually you'll be in a war, maybe sooner or later than you expect. Anything could happen. The game is very detailed especially with regards to having to keep your armies, navies and air forces supplied if you want them to fight, managing the home front to keep support, building factories to keep your war machine going. The AI can be unpredictable and that makes for better gameplay with events that never happened in history, or historical events that never happen.  I use several mods for better, deeper gameplay. This game lets you write you own history, and its very easy to learn how to use it.

While it does not seem like Paradox is actually producing good content for this game, it is fun. I would say the modders are really carrying the entire experience at this point, and it makes me not want to recommend HOI4, but it's just too much fun. For beginners, this is a nightmare(at least it was for me) but once your friend explains the entire thing to you, and you play for a bit, you get the hang of it. That does not excuse the game for being in my opinion, very over-complicated and unnecessarily intricate. I still honestly don't know what half the buttons do, but that's not entirely a bad thing. I appreciate games that go very in- depth on the strategy and freedom, but it is so in- depth, that I can imagine it being difficult for new players to understand. Games can take a very long time, and you can progress very far throughout and gain mass power. By the end of it you are god and the world is one. Its satisfying and very open ended in terms of how you come to your success. Now, I don't have too much experience in the game so I won't pretend like I know everything. From my playthroughs so far, it is good. The game is good. Whether its the community that holds it tight or Paradox making supposedly ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• DLC, I am having fun. I do recommend. Especially to people who can have someone else tell them how to play, because the tutorial is very unexplanatory.

Product refunded Fun game, but if you have a low-end CPU there's no way to reach 1943 unless you are willing to wait 1 minute for a day to pass at speeds 4-5. Paradox doesn't care enough to optimize their games for multi-core processors and that doesn't seem likely to change. So yeah, I don't care how many cool features you add to all those DLC's you want me to buy cause even if I wanted to spend 100+ euros for the game, it wouldn't matter, since it would become unplayable after 1942. Pros : Good interface A lot of replayability Planning land and air warfare is pretty fun Kaiserreich Cons : Becomes unplayable after a certain point Organizing naval units is too tiring Research has no reason being limited as it is Diplomacy sucks (your allies can and will drag you into random wars that quickly become global conflicts with random countries on every side) Focus trees seem fun but they end up limiting gameplay cause there's no way to change them later on. If you decide you want to attack china as japan, you can no longer use focuses to attack the soviets and vice versa Honestly, just play Darkest Hour or Darkest Hour: Kaiserreich cause this ain't worth 100+ euros

Review to be updated.. Issues: Impossible to play without the taxing 3D models. Want to know in what direction a unit is moving? No way to tell without 3D models, why not just add indicators like in HOI3? Want to know where there are things like bunkers and factories on the map without having to click every single province? No simple icons, only 3D models... Inconsistent and conflicting game design. Example could be freedom of choice versus restricting mechanics not coherent. Gameplay is a tedious grind having to fight against the very ui and the aspects you command. Arcade simulation. Don't go into this expecting realistic game features as was always the case in this series. Lackluster features, even if implemented then very poorly done, like the oversimplified espionage and air combat. Atrocious AI..

HOI4 is a great, fun and expansive game, letting you create your own experiences whether that be by yourself on with friends. There's also loads of easy and difficult achievements, which in turn comes with achievement hunters. As I mentioned earlier, you can play with friends, meaning multiplayer, its basically solo just with other players, there are roleplay communities along with communities who use HOI4 as a sport. If you're new to games like HOI4, there are useful tutorials and hints that pop up if you're playing for the first time (or don't have them turned off). So, overall, HOI4 is probably one of the best games in its genre, and in my eyes, the best Paradox game I've ever played (granted I've only played HOI4, Stellaris and CK1). So, yes, I recommend this to everyone who likes (or are just trying out) games like HOI4.

Positive - Most in depth WW2 simulator - Tons of amazing mods (some mods are bigger than the game itself) - A lot of directions you can take your country for example you can be communist America or facist France. But there isn't really any special content for these alternative paths in the base game Negative - Tons of dlc's - A lot of achievement are behind the dlc's - Some important/basic features are behind the dlc's - Lack of a good tutorial - Russia and Italy have very little content even tho they are a couple of the most important countries in WW2 (probably will be changed eventually) - The base game is boring without the dlc's or mods

this is a review of the game WITHOUT any dlc. Combat: - Without DLC, it's really basic and actually kind of boring after a while. + In contrast to other PDX games, there's way less random chance in HOI4's combat. However, it's in dire need of change considering that there is one and only one way to guarantee that your units will win. Build 'space marines' (a division template that basically always wins). + You can design your own ground divisions. + You can design planes and ships - Plane and ship design is really barebones. It's just making a certain stat value higher instead of adding a component to a vehicle. Non-combat: - National Focus: pretty cool feature, however without DLC all the focus trees are really boring and go only one way, the historical way (except for France and Poland). All other nations like Finland, Romania, India, China, ... get a copy-pasted tree. Which is ironically better than the Italian focus tree. - Research: Nice, however after like 10 games (which is a lot of hours) it becomes boring really fast, you'll just be autoclicking - Industry: Very nice, no remarks. DLC-Policy: - Not as bad as PDX's older games (e.g. Crusader Kings 2, EU4) but it's still pretty bad. You'll find a lot of reviews about the game's DLC stating that "this should be in the base game", and justifiably so. Modding - The game's modding community is VERY MUCH ALIVE. While this game might be really barebones without the DLC, it's the modding community that drives this game forward by adding new mechanics and focus trees. Most of my gameplay came from playing mods like Kaiserreich: Legacy of the Weltkrieg and Road to 56. Total: 7/10. Verdict: good game, but the DLC policy alone can be enough to some to stay away from this game alltogher

This is a hard game for someone just starting out (I can barely micro-manage, a term used to describe managing units on a small amount of tiles, and I can't understand Navy, reliability, logistics, supply areas, combat width, anything). However, once you get down the basics (enough to outsmart the AI in some cases), you have a lot of pathways to try out, and complete hilarious scenarios (such as beating the US as Bhutan and having Chad invade Japan). It can get even better with mods, which bring whole new stories to the game, from the alt-history funniness of Kaiserredux to the somber and downright depressing stories of The New Order. The devs constantly try and shake things up, fix bugs, and while DLC prices can stack up, they always add a fun addition or two to this amazing game. I would recommend to anyone willing to invest some time and learn.

Hoi4 is a good strategy game, consisting of historical events and non-historical events to change the gameplay. Want to bring back Austo-Hungarian Empire? Well you're in luck, cause you can! Just the aspect of building up your forces to invade your neighboring country without the USA, USSR, Germany, or UK getting on your butt is exciting. You get to experience game changing events, a single country joining your side can completely change the course of the war. Want to play as Germany and take over all of Europe? Well you can, but if you want to go with the good guys and let the Soviets start the war? It is your right. This game is full of many experiences, and DLC just make it better! Singleplayer isnt lonely, and Multiplayer is good for testing out your skills as a strategist against other players.

Good concept and great execution. AI is advanced enough to be acceptable, but it's not groundbreaking nor revolutionary. Gameplay is pretty nice, but takes some hours getting into. The game is taxing for lower end systems and if you want a good experience you should have more high-end specs.. The recommendation for system specs on the store page is the recommended specs for having the game running at 2 hours per second instead of 2 days per second of in-game time at the mid-game, basically making the game so slow that it's essentially unplayable if you don't have the patience of a superhuman. (Specs calculated using a GTX 1050 Ti graphics card and an Intel i3 processor. I have a terrible computer.) Would recommend, but the price is slightly inflated.

ORC REVIEW HEARTS OF IRON IV is a tatically realistic grand strategy game. Compared to other games of its type I find it to be easier to understand, as it focuses more on combat rather than nation-building. The game itself is essentially a computerized version of those super complicated irl WW2 games that would take hours to set up and play, but of course all of the calculations are done in the game. The game supports single player and mutiplayer (although mutiplayer is a bit laggy) and games can be expected to take at least the majority of a day, however, it can be saved at any time, even in the mutiplayer. The game has great mod support, and you can find custom maps, skins, and many others that will potentially enhance the experience. The only downside is DLC which locks out some influential features, but the game is still fun without it. I, General Orc, recommend Hearts of Iron IV as a good combat-focused grand strategy in the WW2 era. If you like very long games pertaining to WW2, you will like this game. That is the review, Farewell.

I currently only have just over five hours in HoI IV compared to 179 for HoI III on Steam (probably another hundred more on my old CD copy), and I just want to address a few highlights, as someone who bought it, tried it and instantly hated it, refunded it, only to buy it again to give it a proper go. As someone who's spent years playing III, with it's little divisional boxes representing a very abstract view of battle, and red and grey arrows depicting the ongoing assaults and retreats of shattered units, I initially looked down on IV's use of 3D avatars of forces as making it look a lot more cartoony. It doesn't, and the fact that I'm happy to play CKII and EUIV with the same kind of 3D avatars makes me realise that was a daft take. Graphically, the map looks so much more alive watching these avatars walking/driving/flying/sailing around it. Another thing that got me was the differences in production between the two. III had resources, and military/industrial/civilian production all bundled into one menu, with the latter three all being abstracted as 'industrial capacity', whereas IV focuses on different kinds of factories. At the same time, it seems easier, but also more complicated now, since I have to set production for different types of equipment (which appeals to the hardcore logistics nerd in me). In III, as long as I had the IC for it, divisional production would just steam ahead, based on which one was first in the list, whereas in IV, if I have two divisions waiting to be trained, only one of which needs artillery, which I haven't produced any at all, then the other division isn't impacted by this, and can just carry on without me needing to do any readjustments. I also like the focuses we're now getting on some of the smaller nations as well, compared to III where if you weren't playing a major power, you would probably end up playing second string to them. On the other hand, I've started a game as Yuogoslavia for the first time, and I'm trying to unite the Balkans against the forces of Germany and the Soviets, precisely because of these interesting focuses. In summary, my mistake was thinking that IV would be III. It's not, it is a very different game, and anyone buying it from having III should be prepared for that. So, to sum up, my review may not be very informative, or very helpful, but I wanted to put my thoughts down. I've just bought most of the DLC's as well, so I'm going to give them a whirl later on today and see how the game plays.

This is a very deep strategy game but it might not appear so from the surface. It is quite an asymmetrical gameplay experience. While the game does allow flexibility in playstyle, the range of this varies wildly between the playable countries. The soundtrack is quite good, but i wasn't blown away by it. Still a good solid soundtrack that does it's job. The graphics and the character animations are decent. Gameplay has a lot of depth and it in a way feels a bit like a board game. I have to applaud the way the game manages to capture the global nature of the conflict this game covers. I would definitely recommend this game to players fond of war gaming but have to mention that the content pack dlcs seem to be quite essential to the full experience while the cosmetic dlcs seem like they could have been part of the base game.

HOI4 is a Paradox game, and as such it is huge, complex, and takes forever to play. If that is your thing, you‚Äôll love it.  I have over 100 hours in game, and I feel like I am only scratching the surface of figuring out how to play the game. When getting started, the complexity of the game this can be overwhelming, and the in-game tutorial does very little to help you get started. The HOI4 Wiki is not very helpful to the beginner because it doesn‚Äôt provide a roadmap to learning the game. There is no possible way for you to know everything you need to know to play well in your first game or two.  You can watch videos, and read game guides, but the best way to learn is to try things and make mistakes. If this does not appeal to you, I would recommend not wasting your time and money.

The best grand strategy WW2 game out there, period. AI is stupid if you know how to exploit its weaknesses, but only a veteran of the game would have that knowledge. If you're brand new and within your first 200-300 hours (yes, 200-300 hours) you are going to love it, because its depiction of WW2 is spot on (for the most part, this game is not HOI3 and would railroad everything to make everything turn out like how it really did) Although, I will say this: if you play this game long enough, you will eventually come to realize vanilla HOI4 with no mods is extremely unbalanced. Countries that produced all sorts of things in real life will now produce 12ish things and throw 200 of their 300 or so military factories on 2 items, fighter planes and heavy tanks. Now that's extremely unrealistic but that's just the meta in vanilla, medium tanks are trash compared to heavies. But play with some balancing mods or overhaul mods and you can achieve the perfect WW2 simulator.

its a good game, especially if you like ww2 history related stuff in order to play the game and truly experience it you need to get the dlcs, however i dont recommend getting them when not on sale because they are too overpriced for the content they offer (mostly). a really good thing that devs included into multiplayer is that if the host hosts a multiplayer game AND owns any dlc at all, you will play that game with all the dlcs that the host has, effectively meaning that if you play multiplayer on games where the host has all the dlcs, you dont miss out on anything the game offers which is GREAT. the game offers a wide range of viable strategies and tactics to defeat your enemies with, which means that the best player, or the best player faction usually wins a multiplayer game (if there are rules and/or mods in place that balance the game of course) when it comes to singleplayer, the AI is pretty dumb sometimes but is really fun especially if you are just starting out with the game. trying out all the most powerful countries and experimenting in singleplayer is awesome and fun. probably the best thing about the game is it's mod support, it is fairly easy to create mods and make something of your own. there are many interesting already established singleplayer and multiplayer mods so when you are done playing the vanilla game you can jump into any of the bigger and popular mods and enjoy the content that the mod offers, which usually expands even further on the vanilla mechanics and in general makes this game a tonne more fun. however, the worst thing about the game is it's optimization. it is almost terrible to the point that sometimes rendering the game in late late game unplayable because of how slow it is, which makes world conquests in this game hard if you are taking your time. most of the time it is not something you gotta worry about if you are looking for a "average length" game that will last from '36, the starting year towards '45 for example. thankfully there are mods that optimize the game further and allow for more quality gameplay. if you are going to get this game expect a shallow learning curve for the first 50+ hours, and after that everything that you gotta do is figure out the meta and experiment with all the countries in the game. the gameplay of this game is pretty unique. many countries have their unique so-called "national focus trees" which allow you to do some stuff specific to that country alone, developing it in a historical or ahistorical way, or getting some pretty interesting political events and such (unique to the country you are playing). apart from that, during gameplay you improve your industry which eventaully translates into better military, to more wars in your favor, to more territory, to more industry, and so on in a circle. combat in the game is really special as you can customize your combat divisions, choose from different ships or airplanes as you like, adapting to any situation that is to come in wars. all in all i definitely recommend the game especially if you are into ww2 history or grand strategy games

Man, this game. It's good, but it's good in a strange, kinda masochistic way. If you buy this it will steal so many hours from your life. You will start with the tutorial, or rather the lack of it. HOI4 is a complex game, with many mechanics that are not fully explained, like Combat Width, Naval Combat, using Paratroopers and Marines, how to set up your units to be optimal, Logistics ecc ecc. Unless you watch some tutorials on Youtube or have some friend to explain it you will not understand some parts of the game, and this is OK. This will take your first 50/100 hours, only learning the game. After this "Learning Phase" you will know, let's say, 60/70% of the game mechanics. Now you will play every nation with a worth enough focus tree: you will play historical games and overrun Moscow with some tigers, or mann the Maginot and defend France from the Germans for the second time. After some historical games you will start to play some wacky unhistorical games bringing back the Kaiser or making a communist Union of Britain. At this point your skills will be enough to challenge the AI on par, but after many games you will eventually think "this is starting to look easy". After some easy steamroll games you will inevitably want to step up the challenge, and ther're 2 ways: one is mods and the other is archievements. Some players may become bored rather quickly of the historical and unhistorical settings, and some may want a more in-depth look into the game, kinda like HOI3, and the answer is modding. There are A LOT of mods for this game: some are Alternate history (wooo dude, what if Germany won WW1/WW2/noone won...), some are very in-depth in making the game more challenging for the historical settings (BLACK ICE, Toal War), some are set in the cold war or in the modern era and some...some are just memes. With mods this game become eternal. I have almost 1400 hours in this game and I'm sure more than a 1000 are with mods. After you become bored with a mod you can just go on the Workshop and get another, and another, and another, until you see the developers of the first mod has released a new update for his work and the cicle restarts. One big incentive in using mods is that after you try some mods with some new cool mechanics, when you look back at vanilla it just seems lacking in details and boring, so you will only be playing mods forever. If you, for some reasons, dont like mods you can always put the game in Ironman mode and try to get all the archievements, so you can post it on Reddit and get that juicy karma. It can be fun but repeating certain games multiple times to get an archievement is too much for me. One big problem you may see after this phase is DLC-locked content. I'd say all the big DLCs are worth their price (on Steam disconts) but I can understand that spending more than 50$ for some focus tree and a new wacky and unaccurate shipbuilding mechanics may be too much. If you play multiplayer you can circumvent this problem by letting your rich friend host the game, in Paradox games all the host's DLCs are usable for everyone in the game. Speaking of multiplayer, it's a lot of fun when you play with your friends, it's a little less fun if you hop on a random server with strangers: the community tends to be...rather diverse and not really friendly. You can find the unironical fascist on germany or the super min-maxer IPlayOnlyMetaAndWillShoutIfYouDontDoTheSame and the memers who will go deliberately for fascist France in a historical Role-Play server just to piss you off. Overall this game is bonkers, props to Paradox for creating this, but most importantly props to moddders for letting me stay after I became burnt-out from vanilla.

After playing about 140 hours of this game over a long amount of time, i can say that i absolutely love this game. It might seem very hard to get in to at the beginning but after about a day of trying out and watching some tutorial videos (the tutorial in the game doesn't help much) I have memorized the mechanics and the game is really fun! You can play as literally any Nation that has existed in 1936 and with mods you can play as even more! (I personally recommend Road to 56 on the steam workshop). For any fan of Alternate History or History in general and Strategy games, this game is an absolute blast! If you decide to buy this game youre in for days and weeks of pure fun! I have a fairly good PC, i got an older 1050ti but the game isn't really heavy on graphics anyway. Nonetheless, i came to notice that in late-game, the frames start to drop a bit, so i needed to reduce the quality, but theres also mods on the workshop that "simplify" the Map, so that it doesn't eat all your FPS. All in all, a solid 9/10 from me!

I really, really want to like this game, and I do, but they don't make it easy. They don't make it easy. Every failure of design that makes a game unnecessarily confusing and/or irritating, it has. And then some. You'll need to do many hours of research before playing, because the developers don't bother to explain even the core mechanics. The tutorial is at best woefully incomplete, and at worst actively misleading. You'll need ~30hrs playtime before you start to get what's going on. Over that time, you'll get used to all the ways the game is needlessly unfriendly to the user. That doesn't mean they aren't classic examples of terrible game design, but you'll learn to look past them. It's a good - and enjoyable - game, despite Paradox's best efforts to the contrary. I'm playing with almost all DLC loaded. It isn't worth what they're charging, but if you're not price-sensitive, or can get it on sale; buy it. It does add good and meaningful mechanics.

If you're new to strategy games such as this, then it will take a few days for you to get fully acquainted with all of the concepts and little details that you'll need to keep up with. However, when you get past this learning curve and get into the game, you'll be on the road to success. It's quite possibly the best game out there for anyone who has ever wondered to themselves what it would be like to have been in the shoes of famous world leaders like FDR, Stalin, or Churchill during WWII. It's super fun and one of my favorite games of all time.

The base game is pretty good allowing you to take control of any of the participating countries during WWII. The DLC builds upon the game and adds some new depth to just about everything but isnt necessary due to the workshop compatibility which leads to endless new scenarios. If you like history, grand strategy games, or both than this is the game for you.

Mainly if you install mods though. Talking of unstable. Currently writing this review as im completely uninstalling and reinstalling the game. Conclusion - Get ready to spend some time on this game. Want to make the 1000 year Reich a glorious aryan reality? Go for it mein fuhrer. Want to spread the workers revolution around the world for the good of the proletariat? We are are behind you comrade. Want to bring freedom and democracy around the world? (Eagle screeches in the distance) Want a Communist America? Go for it! Fascist America? Mmm, Hard coded civil war, go bleep yourself. Want the glory or Luxemburg to be realized and claim its rightful place as the world superpower? I mean...if you can. Want a useful South America? Sir, we deal in reality here. Want the game to chug and become unplayable late game because of trademark paradox lag and an outdated engine? (Blushes Sheepishly) You can sink a lot of time into this game, there are a metric tonne of mods that increase replayability, and there are plenty of overpriced DLC that will milk you for all your money. It's a paradox game. It's the best at what it does, especially since it's one of the only ones in the field. It's much better than when it first came out as all Paradox games get better with time. Honestly wait for a sale before you try and get it, don't pay full price for it and all its DLC.

While it certainly has it's faults, I absolutely love this game. Me and my friends have played it for hours and you can honestly make your own fun out of it. If you aren't one for combat, division design, and keeping with the meta (like me) then you can still easily have fun. There's a massive modding community that can supplement your experience and keep it fresh for however long you need it to, and if you really do want to buy the dlc then buy it. It typically goes on sale quite often and you WILL get at least an hour of fun for every dollar you spend. I personally recommend buying Waking the Tiger for base game as it simply adds so much that I personally believe should be base game, and I would also recommend the mod Road to 56. Watch some YouTube, play with friends, and eventually join random online games. I assure you you can find something for you once you understand the base game mechanics.

Neither thumbs up or down The game is not bad by itself but dosen't feel as polished as it could have been, some of reasons I can think about now: * I found the vanilla game to be extremely basic, if you want to play as a smaller country it's near impossible to have a significant impact on the war (some smaller nations have their own focus tree, but that's usually behind a DLC paywall). * Some of the DLCs are not worth and should have been included as free updates. * Aces feel like they have no impact in air combat * It's not clear what is going on during naval combat, this is a critique that repeats itself since HOI2 * I think the war economy aspect could be a bit more deep (distance between factories dosen't affect production for example), and on this note , you also have no civil aspect of the economy, just the very vague "civil factory", there is a whole new level o depth the game dosen't even try to explore. * I also wish you could make supply depots, you could make whole strategies around capturing enemy gear instead of making your own. All in all you can fix some of those issues with mods (most my games are on the Kaiserreich mod for example) , but still everytime I play I always get the impression the game could be better. Maybe they just expect me to buy DLC to find out.

Hearts of Iron IV started off relatively simple, however, as time passed and patches were dropped, alot of features were added to the game. A warning regarding these, alot of them are behind the DLCs which can be somewhat frustrating, but are in my opinion at least so far, are worth it, although probably go for those that focus nations you're interested in. The game is also great for multiplayer sessions as the timeframe is also  smaller than other PDX games. Unlike other HoI games, HoI4 does not completely stop you from playing minor nations, you can also participate as a minor nation although you probably won't have as much impact as the great powers. There are some fun alternative history routes one can play, but if it's not something you're looking for (although I heavily recommend trying, as forming another faction in the great scheme things just escalates the chaos), you can always just start a game with historical focus on and you get an historical outcome. The game also has alot of interesting mods/total conversions which are great to try out, such as Road to 56, Kaiserreich and Old World Blues. (Do check these, highly recommend)

Like WW2 History? Are you an armchair general? Then you should give this game a try. While others may disagree, this is my favorite game from this developer. As with all Paradox games, there is a bit of a learning curve. Learning curves can be mitigated somewhat by the online community of players and guides. It doesn't tax your system too much and it has some cool features for multiplayer that I really like. For example, you can allow players to hot join. this means you can start a game session on time if someone is running late or allow players to rejoin if they lose connection all without having to restart the game. It feels really polished in that regard. I always end up enjoying myself playing this game and frequently return to it when I go on a WW2 kick. Also, unlike other Paradox games, this game isn't just a demo that requires the DLC to be a full game. You can get the full game play from the base game and the DLC packs really add something different that was not necessary.

Gameplay: You will feel frustration, anger, confusion when playing this game. It is very difficult to get into, and even more difficult to master. Even with this many hours I'm still learning new strategies and things about the game. There's so much you need to take into account. Equipment, division templates, factories, navy, battle plans, and so much more ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• to take into consideration when planning your next moves. But, once you do make that amazing plan that wins you the war, it'll feel amazing. You'll feel like you truly won something, like you actually accomplished something. Overall, the gameplay is difficult to get into, but very rewarding and fun once understood. However, even with the great gameplay loops, the game will start to get boring relatively quickly. That's where mods come in. The modding community is massive for this game. There's practically a mod for everything. You should start out with road to 56 or kaisserreich as those are some of the most fun out of them all and good for entry into the modding scene. It's a lot like skyrim, where it's weird if a person hasn't played with at least one mod on this game once. The mods make the game infinitely more fun, and will make you spend even more time on this game. Graphics: It's an overhead grand strategy game, so I dont think the graphics matter too much. However, I will criticize one thing: The Optimization. The optimization is pretty damn bad. Even with super powerful pcs with i9 processors and the like, the game will start lagging around early 1940s no matter what. It's likely because by that point there is so much going on and so many units and such, that it can lag the game. However, this has been a problem since the beginning, and paradox has done very little to fix it. Music: Music is great. From the epic soviet theme, to the calm and valiant Japan "Empire of the sun" theme, it's all here. The soundtrack is very nice and captures this era of history nicely through the music. What's also very interesting is that different areas will have different music entirely, and they won't play music from another area. For example, some music that plays in Europe doesn't play when playing in Asia. Instead, Asia has its own soundtrack which makes it distinct and helps differentiate itself to the European soundtrack. Overall, this game is very fun, and I would highly recommend it. It will be hard at first, but once you learn it, you will end up loving it (hopefully). I'd also highly recommend to look up tutorials and/or gameplay videos so you can learn the basic mechanics and learn some strategies for certain nations. There's tons of guides on the mechanics of the game, and strategies for playing individual nations. It's all there. It may seem daunting, but please, give it a try. You may find this game to be amazing. Oh yeah, and definitely try playing with mods. Mods make the game infinitely more fun, and one of the reasons I'm still playing.

I am just starting to get good at it (on some aspects). I've always loved map games, world conquest, ww2 history while I do not like turn based games so this is the best combination of these 3 ever. I really like that it is fairly easy to start with. I mean you will most likely lose your first games, but the high level mechanics are easy to understand and accessible: Make more factories, build more weapons and ships, train troops, draw a frontline and attack. But there is still a lot of depths to each mechanics. Sometimes it's a bit much, with all the modifiers, template designer, ships etc... But if you don't to go too deep, no one's forcing you to. I also really like that you can finish a game in a weekend, compared to other paradox games that will take me weeks to finish. The late game gets laggy, which makes the game less enjoyable at that point. Still, 8.5/10

This is a FIVE star game but due to the continuous expansions without fixing major glitches this is currently a 3 star game. It is still fun to play despite the glitches and I find myself playing new campaign after campaign. The support for mods is great, and the stream of expansions keep things interesting. It does have a slight learning curve for new players due to the tutorial being basic.  The example game diminishing glitches/poor coding are as follows: 1: Decisions that create puppets glitching and returning the lands to the original enemy owners of the related territories 2: Some major AI issues in abandoning fronts and ports, or transporting divisions through enemy heavily patrolled areas (suicide), or not building and protecting supply lines. I recommend this game despite those items, and if Paradox steps up on it's debugging then it is hands down a 5 star game.

Been playing this piece of art out of steam since 2018 and every time i opened the game to have some fun, i discovered something cool and never got disappointed. HOI4 helped me to figure out my favorite strategy game genre and finally brought something new to the boring world of strategy games. I just like how Paradox looks at great potentials of different scenarios in the history of mankind. The game itself may look weird or show itself like it has nothing to offer comparing to thousands of other WW2-Themed games on steam. But more you move to the depth of the game and the more you learn, and the more you get addicted to writing the history of the earth through the World War. And I just recently discovered the modding community in this specific game has got plenty to offer the player and the improvements they came with just blew my mind. It may be a time-killing game and probably you gonna struggle for the first 6-7 hours of playing to figure out what's up, but trust me, it DOES worth it.

The primary focus of this game is war, and it does that far better than any other Paradox Grand Strategy game to date. However, play before and post war is somewhat lacking. The peace conferences post war could use work, and the lack of a true economy and the use of factories as such leaves a lot to be desired. One could realistically set this game up and build a massive army with little to no consequences so long as a you had the factories to support the size of your military. Personally I would love to see an economy feature introduced in a future DLC so that you cannot just mass produce everything, and so that you are actually required to balance the number of military vs. Civilian factories and it would provide for more complex long term planning to ensure that you didn't run the risk of staying in a protracted war that you could not financially support even if you did have the manpower and equipment to spare.

I've heard time and time again from friends trying to learn this game saying that it is un-necessarily complex and boring. That theres nothing to do and theres a lack of content. Although the part about lack of content may be somewhat true, as Paradox tends to release a half finished game and then go ahead and make $80 worth of dlc thats adds core feature in the years following release, and I certainly can see that point of view having played for as long as i have. But I would argue that the modding community, along with the sandbox nature of this game are huge redeeming qualities of this game. Dont want to buy dlc? there's likely a mod that does something similar for free (even though some mods need dlc to work but not many). If im being honest, the only dlc that is truly worth buying would be together for victory, as it allows puppet nations to break free, which is really important at least to me. The core mechanics of the game may seem way overly complicated, but its actually relatively simple compared to other games in its genre, and there are a plethora of tutorials on the internet you can find. The game has its own tutorial, but i would not recommend this, as it explains very little. However recently they have added all sorts of videos into the game that instruct you how to do each thing, for example one shows how to assign troops, one shows how to naval invade etc. I would definitely suggest using these as they explain the mechanics quite well. Additionally, the complexity of the game though daunting at first, truly give the game a level of depth once you get the hang of it, as you can mold your country in all sorts of ways, for example you can play as britain and become communist to ally with the soviet union to take on Germany. This brings me to my next point, which is the alternate history element of the game. You can choose whether to have a game go exactly as ww2 did in real life, or you can change history and do scenarios such as if Germany managed to invade the us, or the soviet union took over Europe after Germany was defeated, things like that allow for so many different scenarios and options for you to play around with, giving this game lots of replay ability. Even though the game is build around being a strategic sandbox, it is mostly made towards invading other countries and growing your empire, not necessarily running the country during peacetime. However, there are some really well made mods out there that add many new features to make the game not focused on war all the time, a good example being millennium dawn. Lastly, this game can be a blast when playing with other people especially friends. The sandbox environment allows for so many funny moments such as one time when my friend went through all the effort of invading Yugoslavia at Italy, and at the peace conference he accidentally hit the done button too early, so he gained no land and had to invade again. To wrap it up, Hearts of Iron 4 definitely has its issues being developed by Paradox and all, but these are overshadowed and fixed by the games many fun game play loops of conquering and expanding your nation along with the plethora of mods that are easily available on the steam workshop (one thing to note is that the launcher lets you make "play sets" which are essentially mod packs you can put different mods into so you don't have to individually pick them out each time) So yeah, if you like games about leading a country and winning wars through """"strategy"""" then i would definitely recommend this game.

This game will suck your soul out of your cold, dead body. I love it. Actual review starts here: Overview: This is a Paradox grand strategy game that focuses around WW2. You can take command of any nation on the world map (major nations are significantly stronger than minor ones) and the Vanilla game consists of two possible start dates, 1936 or 1939. You have control over many aspects of your nation from industry, research, politics, infrastructure and your various different military groups (army, air force, navy). You progress through the game mainly through your National Focus Tree, which is a list of various different decisions you can enact to progress through the game. The most important nations (Germany, Italy, UK, France, US, Japan, USSR and a few others) have unique ones in the base game, and DLC adds many more for minor nations as well as some crazy alt-history scenarios which are tons of fun (Restoring Qing China as Manchukuo or reforming Austria-Hungary are some of my favourites). There is a LOT to learn about this game, so I recommend watching a few how-to guides on YouTube to get started. It is well worth it. Some of the most important aspects of the game I recommend getting used to early are: - How to organise your armies/navies/air wings - How to give orders to your armies/navies/air wings - How to modify division templates - What each division stat does (these have mouse-over descriptions in game also) - How the supply system works - What world tension is and how it affects the game - How different terrain affects combat - How to abuse the living ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• out of Ground Support planes Pros: - You can play as any nation you like (Liberia world conquest ftw) - Game can be set for the AI to follow historical path or not - Games span many years of in-game time (default is 1936 -> 1948 but can go on indefinitely) - DLC adds many more cool features (espionage, modifying ship designs, differing levels of puppet autonomy, etc.) - One of the most mod-friendly games out there, with some awesome ones to choose from (Kaiserreich, TNO to name a few) - Bonkers alt-history offerings Cons: - Steep learning curve - DLC is quite expensive for what is offered. Try to get them on sale if possible - Italy and USSR have quite out-of-date focus trees. There is a new patch named 'Barbarossa' coming soon though so this may change - You will be branded a virgin for life for playing My personal note: Don't just stick to playing big major nations with their historical focuses. There is so much fun to be had with minor nations and the alt-history trees as mentioned above.

Definitely one of the most addictive games I've ever played. Can be very fun for people who enjoy strategy games although can be hard for new players to figure out at first. The abundant use of fairly pricey DLC to add mechanics and focus trees that should be in the base game for free is a bit scummy in my opinion, but I suppose that's just how the video game industry war machine has grown. Mods are truly where this game shines however, I personally recommend Iron Curtain or Kaiserreich: Legacy of the Weltzkrieg, they breathe fresh air into the game and Kaiserreich brings an all new story that isn't actual history. If you buy at least two DLCs (I would recommend Man the Guns and Waking the Tiger) the base game could probably give you 200 hours of fun, I only had to play 50 hours to form an opinion on this game and Its definitely overwhelmingly positive. I would recommend for anyone looking to have an hour crunching experience simulating WWII and not being fans of First Person Shooters.

This is my most played game on steam at the time of me writing this.  I have 650 hours on this thing. I like this game a lot but it has plenty of flaws. It's incredibly expensive to get all the good dlc which make the game work right and naval combat is still a mystery to me so I just throw some destroyers and big ships together and hope. If you can only afford the base game that's perfectly fine. You can still do many interesting things especially if you add one or two mods.  If you like spending a couple hours on building a dnd character sheet then carefully adjust your plans you will love this. You need a great deal of patience and it can be incredibly frustrating but there's a reason I put so many hours into this. Adjusting strategies to fit certain things, conducting diplomacy carefully is incredibly fun for someone like me but it's not for everyone. The thing that makes this different from eu4 or another one of paradox's grand strategy games is war. In this game you control every little thing about your forces and war is everything compared to eu4 where diplomacy is much more important. Personally I've been having a great time with eu4 but that game has an even worse time when it comes to the dlcs. In this game all you really need is man the guns so you don't get confused about naval stuff but everything else adds interesting things. I had tons of fun with waking the tiger and death or dishonor but you don't need to get it. In summary if it seems like your sort of game you can play this thing for hundreds or even thousands of hours but it might have a high price tag. Personally I think that it's better to have paradox do it this way that way I slowly get new content even if it's a little expensive. The game doesn't stop getting major content updates because of these dlcs so it's worth it for some people.

The tutorial for the game is horrendous (basically throwing someone who doesn't know how to swim into the deep end and saying: "good luck!"), but once you get past that and watch a YouTube tutorial or something to understand, this game becomes addicting and really fun.

I don't know who needs a review for this game still, unless it's on some kind of steam sale. HOIV is really it's own thing. Yes it's Paradox, yes it's grand strategy, and yes you can spend hours and hours playing it. This is the only game in the series though that deeply goes into the tactical side of battles. You have a front line, how you form your unit templates matters, too many tanks and it moves slow, to many infantry and it gets bogged down, etc.  There are some other minor mechanics like spy game, but to me it's pretty meager.  This is the best modern WW2 strategy simulator out there in my humble opinion.  Yes some national trees take almost fantasy like liberty, but if stick to playing it on rails, it stays on rails.

Big time. This is a great game, and you can lose yourself for hours in it. It's especially fascinating if you are interested in the political landscape of the 1930s-40s; you can learn a lot about the forgotten annals of history through the base game and certain mods like Kaiserreich (pure fantasy based in possibility). It is more constrained and focused compared to other Paradox grand strategy games, but suffers from same-ism like the rest of them. Still, when you pull something off flawlessly, the feeling of mastery you get is quite immense.

While this game improves a lot over its predecessor and has many thrilling ideas put in. Like industry and improving your war gear vs keeping factory efficiency. Making battle plans and choosing when to take the efficiency hit by overriding or trusting your generals to pull it off.. The joy of this series was on opportunities to make clever plans. But, to be honest, it has lost it's soul with Focus Trees. Its no longer the sandbox where you figure out clever geopolitical plans and try to execute them through any means, hold your breath if you can actually pull it off.. now it does not matter much what you do, just every 70 days every nation chooses a magic action to radically change the situation outside game mechanics, and to push you back to those few (ok, maybe several) prepared paths. DO give it a try, though..

Ive loved so many Paradox games so much, but this is just a bad game. Its absolutely insain on my part that Ive kept trying, over and over again, to give this game a chance. You need to watch hours of Youtube tutorials (and I have) to get each different mechanic in the game (I.e. Naval invasions, combat, formations, ect). But after all that, if you don't have everything juuuust right, maybe you forgot one technology that needed to be researched, your units wont do anything or your just hopelessly over run instantly or what have ya. I LOVE complex grand strategy games and have hundreds of hours clocked in on many of them, including Paradox titles like stellaris (one of my favorite games of all time!) but this game just makes me so frustrated at its potential for interesting political and state experimentation around ww2 and its failure to deliver on that by creating stifling mechanics that make it a very difficult game to interact with at all. For me personally, after 20 hours, its unplayable.

You really should never underestimate poor timing of events in this game, and always plan far more carefully than I did trying to rush for the "En Svensk Tiger" achievement. There is a death spiral that can happen quickly if you are not careful, and one that not even "30 Minutes of Hel" could bring down on me. This is a story then, of sheer bad luck, stupidity, and timing so poor it makes a bad demolitionist seem like they're on the clock in more ways than one. (I will say now that this story is an over-dramatized version of an extremely bad f--k up.) It is the onset of the Winter of 1937. Sweden's Civil War was a Pyrrhic Victory in every sense of the phrase. The Army has been decimated, The Navy completely wiped out, and the already small Air Force completely demolished. There remains a single combat ready division of soldiers ready to defend the realm, and their supplies are minimal. There are few weapons to be fired, and even fewer bullets to fire from the weapons. The few factories producing anything are focusing solely on rebuilding infrastructure, and even then dissident groups and low government support cause further damages. The new regime is collapsing, not even a month after it seized power. There is no hope. There is no salvation. Not for poor little Sweden. That is until the Germans offered their help. They offered food for our people, weapons for our troops, and steel for our factories. They helped, over the course of three months, rebuild the nation. But there were those that were unmistakably angered by the situation in Scandinavia. The United Kingdom and France both demanded of poor little Sweden to cease all trade with Germany. It refused, and found itself at war. Callously, the Germans who had helped the Swedes left as fast as they came. The April 1st Invasion of Sweden was not a joke, and the United Kingdom led invasion had rolled cleanly and effortlessly to Stockholm by April 4th. Thus ends the SHORTEST F-----G GAME I'VE EVER PLAYED, AND YES, I'M HAPPY WITH IT.

This is one of my favorite games on steam, especially being a history nerd. IT is one of the best strategy games, and ww2 simulation games out there. The only problems are 1. There is no tutorial. Vanilla game is god awful with few features and repetitive gameplay. Fork over between 60-80 dollars off discounts for dlc and you get few cool features and new focus trees, but honestly not worth it if its not on discount. But with dlc, and the multiple amazing mods made by outstanding creators who i cant thank enough for making my gaming experience so great with their awesome mods, and have allowed me and my friends many laughs and good times, doing stupid stuff and changing history. A wonderful game, if you have mods. If the developers would tone down on dlc, and add more free features, it would truly be a amazing game. But with all that said, i still give the game 10/10, lots of fun had and i stil enjoy playing it.

If you possess a brilliant mind like me you will also find HOI4, like many other Paradox Interactive games to be exceptionally stimulating AND entertaining. However, anyone who has played this game will be no stranger to mental breakdowns when something doesn't work, make sense, or happen as it should. Yes, I'm talking about things like The United Kingdom declaring on pretty much everyone and driving them away to the axis, or allies doing absolutely nothing to help you, what so ever. Pros: -Good visuals -Good audio effects/tracks -Hundreds of hours of gameplay -Great workshop community -Fun with friends -Historical/Educational content Cons: -Multiple DLC required for best experience -Somewhat large learning curve to be considered "decent" (watch tutorials) -Bhutan lacks a focus tree of their own

Let's get to the point. This game is breathtaking. Not graphically, but by the historical accuracy and the sandbox and control you can do in this game. You can be any country in WW2, and do an infinite amount of things, and change history as we know. The mod support is also excellent. I got the Millennium Dawn mod, which puts HOI4 in the 21st century, great mod. HOWEVER, and this is big, this game will take a while to master. I suck at this game at the time of this review. There is so much to do, and it can be overwhelming. You need to be prepared and invest time to understand and master the game. Overall, I rate it a 8/10. I would buy the game on sale for ~$10, $44 CAD seems to much for this game, but if its on sale get it.

Sorry if my spelling is weird and sometimes can be "ramble"- type of text, but hope this doesn't come as i am saying the itself game is badly made. Because it isn't, I guess it is just not for me. It comes down to how the game plays out. It is really complex game and i like it's gameplay. just can't and don't want to play it anymore because of the reason i am gonna tell in this review. I have tried all of the superpowers, and noticed that like Soviet union the most and I have learned to play this game ~65 hours of playing. (I know 50-70% of the game). This game does not feel like I have a progression, when world tension is higher than 25% Britain (and his allies with him) guarantee independence to any country that i declare war with. (I am interested in history and know why they do that, but just because it is historical/accurate it doesn't make it fun to play, at least to me) So basically when i capture a whatever country the world tension is above 25% so then if i declare war on any country, Britain and his buddies guarantee. I can't take the small countries and make my country more bigger and wealthier to take down the giants. It's first the biggest guys on the planet and then it is a walk in the park. So basically there is no progression. So it's the same as starting any game from the end of it. Taking the final boss down and then it's basically just clicking "declare war" and walking to the country and walking there. I have tried to win or something at least 25-35 times and then the AI (Germany) just finds always a way to capture me. At first i just thought that i need to get good at the game and then it will be fun (still not "good" but know how to play). But i would need to beat the games end boss (aka the hardest enemy) and then it is basically what i would like to do. But then there isn't a big enough enemy to be a challenge. Tried to find a solution to my problem, couldn't find any other than drain Britain's political power by declaring war on some country to just cancel it. But it doesn't work that well to be worth the effort. Gonna play it prob again if i fin someday find a solution to it.

If you want to be apart of history or completely flip it on its head then this is the game for you. There are even mods for different eras (the base game is set before and during the Second World War). The game has two start dates 1936 with the build up to WWII or September 1st, 1939 where the war has just begun. Personally I go with the 1936 start date just to give me more time. There are so many choices to make in the game. You want to have Germany or Russia be more like their modern day versions? You can do that. You want to make the USA a global empire and take over the world? Yep, you can do that and so much more!

Truly an overpriced game, especially with the DLCs. It's basically an Excel Sheet Simulator with a pretty map... with only 1-3 real mapmode. I'd have really liked ethnicity, religion and political affiliation represented by actual pops(like in Vic2) Somehow convincing me that a pie chart is my political landscape, without any information about it... really feels disingenuine for it to be there. Altough, this is a War Simulator, so let me answer you how good it is. The best nation to play in base game(so, without mods) is Japan. Japan is very flexible, can go against the Soviet Union, China or the US. They can use any kind of strategy from Battlefield Support, only Tactical Bombers, 20 widht arti. You can opt for an early war against the US, in which naval warfare is the most important. Any Japan route is satisfying and somewhat hard-ish. Now in contrast to this, playing ahistorical as Germany is just isn't that fun. If you go full naval warfare, you can Sealion Britain in 1 year and from that, the game becomes boring. If you go full medium tank and anti air, you'll capitulate the Soviet Union in 2 years. If you go standard build 40 width arty, you'll lose. My advice to anyone who experiences these feeling should play Kaiserredux. KRX is far more unforgiving to the player, and much more branches in the political climate is open. I do recommend the base game if you're new to HOI4, but after 1000 hours(I played cracked since 2019) it becomes stale.

Hearts of Iron 4 (or for short HOI4) is a strategy game based on WW2. With close to 180 hours on record, I recommend this game. The base game of HOI4 is very fun, with lots of countries to choose from and lots of ways to achieve world dominance. While the base game is fun at first, you‚Äôll soon find out that it gets a bit repetitive and most countries have a basic country focus tree. And that‚Äôs where the DLC‚Äôs come in. There is a lot of them, and they make your game better, if it‚Äôs adding new features or new focus trees. But some people may not have cash for DLC‚Äôs. With unlimited modding potential, you can play mods ranging from The Road to 56 (my personal favourite) to the Fallout-based Old World Blues. This game can be very addictive. 7/10, the base game might get boring and repetitive and modding the game with multiple mods may cause glitches, bugs and crashes.

All in all it's a wonderful game that I stuck to for quite a while. However the potential is limited because of the bad optimization. Without helping mods the game will slow down immensely after 1941 which makes it pretty much not enjoyable to me at that point. In addition to that the fighting system is so complex that even after 500+ hours I need to watch youtube tutorials or discord threads to get an idea of what went wrong in my save game because in-game there is no in depth tutorial or explanation on which stats are relevant in which scenario. I am looking forward to HOI 5 with huge expactations since the major flaws are very obvious and should be easy to tackle for the developers. This might become the perfect WW2 sandbox game.

Great game, had a lot of fun with it. The only major drawback I can see is the combination of time required and silly inconsistency. For instance I played as the USSR twice in a row, built myself up virtually the same way each time. The first time the Germans put up a really good fight. Moved and attacked in a reasonable way, had a lot of military strength etc. The second play through was a COMPLETELY different story. Germany simply wasn't playing in a competent manner and wasn't anywhere near as strong as it was the game before (and definitely not as strong as it *should* have been). I was able to push them back quite easily because they had very weak military strength and I reached Berlin by late 1942. So I put in a lot of hours only to be disappointed and bored. If it had been a hard struggle and an early end that would have been fine, but the AI was doing so poorly that it just wasn't satisfying at all and felt like a complete waste of time. There's no reason it should be this way. The game has its pros and cons like anything else and you can talk about them all day, but as far as potentially game breaking flaws that is the biggest one I could find (and you've probably heard all the pros 999999 times lol). I don't want the AI to be totally predictable of course, but there should be some consistency and minimum quality to it so that it doesn't act totally crappy and silly like I've seen it do. Technology can definitely allow devs to do this nowadays. Great game though overall, not even close to giving it a thumbs down, just be prepared for some serious let downs and frustration between the awesomeness lol

I have not played a Hearts of Iron game in a long time. I decided to purchase Hearts of Iron IV, given the sale on Paradox's website to see if I would enjoy the new game in the series. I only have 43 hours so far, but am thoroughly enjoying it. I love all of the mechanics allowing me to manage my nation as I see fit and choose various government types. I am currently playing as Iran for example and have created a fascist government model where I joined the Axis. This has allowed me to convert to the New Persian Empire and I have expanded into Saudi Arabia and Southern China. I am currently working on a push into the Soviet Union. Overall I would recommend the game, but beware it can be addicting especially once your nation gets rolling!

Introduction Hearts of Iron IV is one of my favourite games and I constantly find myself coming back to this game. You are able to choose any country of the world from the late 1930s and play into World War II changing the course of history as you go. You can play as the Third Reich and conquer all of Europe or attempt to defeat them Axis powers. Hearts of Iron IV is one of the rare games where there is almost infinite replayability especially with mods. This game has one of the largest modding communities where you can well in the past or far in the future making the game so much more fun than vanilla. They make the focus trees more in depth and some add onto the base games trees to help those without the DLC which totals to around $200 AUD, one such mod is The Road to 56 which I can definitely recommend. https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2467380510 Gameplay Hearts of Iron IV has incredible gameplay, whether it be the immersive sound track, controlling your armies in an invasion or the strategic thinking behind each idea. The sound track to this game is very immersive and the music player allows you to change the song to whatever you want and depending on what country you play different music will play with it. One of the best things about this game is the thinking behind every plan. Without a proper idea as to how you are going to conquer your enemy, you are bound to fail. Setting one offensive order can and sometimes will do the job but it can take much longer than hatching a plan, Its when your in a world war that the grand strategy really starts to kick. Positives The grand strategy aspect of this game is very entertaining and the fact that it is infinitely replayable makes for countless hours. Something else about this game is the modding community, the base game (without dlc) gets somewhat boring after some time so modding really saves the game, there are thousands of mods and a few of them really stand out like the Great War Redux, Kaiserreich and The Road to 56. These mods are some of my favourites that i keep coming back to when i platy this game and honestly i can't remember the last time I played Vanilla. https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2530196735 Negatives Although this game is very fun there are still some negatives like the completely ridiculous prices of the DLC and the base game for that matter. The base game and the DLC together cost approximately $200 AUD. This price is seriously absurd for a few focus trees for only a select few countries. Mods do the job just fine and have more effort put into them than some of the DLC. Something else about this game is the really ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• tutorials that the game has to offer. The game offers a series of videos on how to solve each of the problems like unassigned divisions, no resources and no current research, Etc. These were honestly no help at all and I found myself using the wiki and asking one of my friends how some of the things in the game worked and found more success than watching some 20 second video on how to click my mouse on an icon. Conclusion Hearts of iron IV is one of my favourite games and I constantly find myself coming back to it whenever I don't  know what to play. I couldn't recommend this game enough and I absolutely recommend that you buy this game on sale and play mods instead of buying all of the DLC. 9/10.
