Basically unplayable past the first 100 hours without mods, how far the base game has been dumbed down from HOI3 is honestly somewhat of a travesty. TLDR you can tell Paradox is planning on milking HOI4 with DLCs into the future to fix things that should have been implemented day one (you made 3 previous games). Design Companies should be adapted the way Kaiserreich has them working, production screen needs some quality of life improvements, namely re-adding the ability to send something straight to the top of the queue, as opposed to spending 10 years dragging something past 20 stacks of ships. Land warfare needs a serious rework, specifically when it comes to balancing doctrines, because Superior Firepower (SF) is the best by far and there's no reason to choose any other doctrine (even when using tanks). Essentially meaning that any other doctrine other than SF is useless against other players, but is still the best to use against AI as well. Another caveat would be the ability to tell AI puppet or allied nations to ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• off and stop choking up your supply lines with their ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• troops that dont even conform to a 10/20/40 width template and causing you massive headaches. Land production in the way of ground vehicles needs more design options in addition to the design company making them, as well as additional variants of said vehicles (engineer tanks for example). Naval combat is miles better than it was at release, although the scale of naval production needs to be improved to be more nuanced and at least allow more options to increase dockyard output (carriers take way too long to build even for the US, which IRL laid down and launched tier IV carriers in a year and a half). Air combat needs a serious rework (I smell a DLC), close air support missions should be free flowing and allowed to attack enemy units not in active combat (actually giving a purpose to the camouflage expert perk) albeit at a reduced efficiency or damage to simulate the absence of friendly spotters/air control parties and adjusted to the enemy level of entrenchment. Scout planes need to be more useful than they currently are and provide unit buffs to artillery and CAS missions that they are spotting for. Fighters need to be much more nuanced than "I have more and higher agility than you" and actually make the tech and production tree somewhat interesting (plane designer similar to ship designer). Strategic bombers need the ability to target stuff specifically within a region (ports, bunkers, infrastructure, industry) in order to make them more useful than just wrecking everything slower than the enemy can rebuild. Espionage is useless outside of cryptology, what is needed is the ability to queue up multiple agency upgrades so the player isnt constantly having to pause the game to start another upgrade and potentially missing out on a timeline because they are busy elsewhere. I'm sure I've missed stuff, but these are the most glaring issues to me as of the moment. I'm honestly dumbfounded as to how modmakers continue to develop much better and more complex systems in an incredibly limiting game for free at a rate faster than which the devs get paid to do.

Played the game a lot, it has a lot of pros and a few cons. If you enjoy history from the geopolitical point of view, probably this game is for you. It's not too much in to detail so you won't have to go crazy to win wars, just manage a simplified economy and war supplies. Pros: - replayability, even the same country with the same focus or path can be played in multiple ways of you choosing which type of warfare to adopt, + if you change focuses you can really play one nation and have much different scenarios - multiplayer, this games thrives on multiplayer: it's kind of fun alone, more to enjoy, but really gets you to think and be ready for everything if played with you friends, be sure to garrison your ports! - community, the community is really the backbone of the game, with incredible mods coming out weekly and people  updating your favourite ones constantly, if you wanted something to change in history, someone has imagined that (or you could do the scenario yourself! The game is ez to mod, I even tried myself) Cons: - paradox's DLC policy: the game is not complete, the dlcs cost lots, and yatta yatta yatta. Just see the playthrough of one of them on YT or see the devs play it and find out if you will like it or not. {A big game changer is that if one of your friends or you have it, even one in 10 people, if he hosts the multiplayer game, everyone will be able to play with the dlc} To sums it up: the game is a little hard to learn at first, everyone that started on his own lost to Ethiopia on the first try [never played the tutorial], but once you learned the basics it's just practice. If you like map games or just the "frontline wars" like ww1 and ww2 you will come to like this one. 7.5/10 without the community 9/10 with the community

Like war games?  Welcome to one of the most advanced, intense, and complex war simulations ever created.  You have the helm of your chosen nation, any nation in existence in 1936, and the freedom to steer it on any course you choose.  Want the Confederacy to return to drag the US out of the Great Depression?  Want to defy Hitler and bring back the Kaiser?  Want to show the world that France could have single-handedly taken out the Nazi war machine? All this and so very much more awaits you in this game.  The DLCs do nothing but add more facets to the game, from dealing with your nation's fuel supplies to being able to make your ships exactly as you want them to cloak and dagger stuff, the devs for this game seem bent on making it the best war sim ever. I don't think they've missed.  You don't even need anything close to the best of computers to run it.  I will say, though, having played both the windows and linux versions on what can only be called a 'good value' sort of computer, the linux version does run much better. I cannot recommend this game enough to any fan of history or war or strategy in general.  It is well worth the asking price when not on sale.  I do sound one warning:  This game is very complex and has one heck of a learning curve. Be prepared to get your butt kicked unless you make it absurdly easy at first.

It's really fun, only downside I can think of is the reliance on DLC that Paradox constantly markets. Challenging and fun to play, also turning off historical focuses is so fun cause it's tosses the game up. For example, I revived the British Monarchy (which caused me to lose my Dominions with Canada, Australia, NZ, and South Africa), joined the axis, and further colonized Africa. I then formed 20+ collaboration governments with numerous countries (my holdings in the Americas, like Jamaica and the Bahamas, my many holdings in the Middle East and Africa, and Asian holdings). And then helped the Germans and Italians win in France which Germany actually lost all of its land until the Land division conference happened with France, and we're currently struggling against a very powerful Soviet Union due to the Reich falling and being revived in a weak state. The game can be played in a historically correct capacity, where unless you're playing a key allied power poorly or in a historically incorrect manner, Axis will almost always lose. DLC is sadly worth it, Paradox releases a mostly finished game then finishes it with DLC which is kinda cringe, but the DLC is great. But the game is still playable and fun without it, so don't feel like you have to. 7.5/10 game base, 9.5/10 with DLC and I still don't have the newest expansion Bosporus or whatever.

This game has seemingly endless re-play ability. There's a plethora of scenarios and ways to play just about any nation. It's also really fun to gather up friends and play online Moreover the modding community is fantastic and honestly makes this game that much better with a multitude of different eras, scenarios, alternative timelines etc. (for example the iconic Kaiserreich mod all the way to Cold War or even some with modern day scenarios) Honestly i'm 500+ hrs in and i feel like i'm still learning some new things about the games mechanics to this day. I will say that the learning curve is far from friendly to new players and the "tutorial" is an effing joke. The whole process is really just trial and error. ( Or in my case screwing up divisions and accidentally losing a million men in the Netherlands :| ) Beyond that i'd actually recommend against getting this game if you don't plan on getting most of the major DLC as some pivotal mechanics are tucked behind that paywall. Regardless, the bottom line is that this game is definitely amongst some of the greatest grand strategy games ever released. Flaws and all i'd say it still easily stands as my favourite strategy game and i'll keep on playing it. If i had to rate it i'd say it's a 9/10, The cons: DLC is needed for the true experience game gets dramatically slower after about 6-8 years of in game time regardless of how good your pc is tutorial isn't friendly to new players late game nations spam out a horrific amount of divisions, wars can become a slog some DLC is overpriced and i'd say wait to get it on sale pros: incredible value, re-play ability tons of variety continued support from devs and modders alike solid online play (even with mods) A delight for anyone who's a fan of alt history (or history in general) There's really too many good things i have to say about this game that i've sunk decent hours into (and will continue to sink in many more), so before buying please also consult opposing reviews to construe an opinion in case i missed out on any cons. Lastly i'd like to say:  i have yet to see even a hint of this game feeling stale. In my opinion, this is a must buy for any strategy gamer.
Great strategy game that will test both your patience and ability to micromanage. My favorite thing to do in HOI4 is to create an alternate timeline, compared to actual historical events.

After hundreds of hours I think I can safely say this is my favorite Paradox game. It's deep and complex enough to keep you completely engrossed throughout a playthrough, and fast-paced enough to keep you on the edge of your seat for days on end. While the AI is strategically no match for a human mind, you will be challenged to use every trick at your disposal to overcome the opposition. A fantastic modding community keeps the experience fresh for years. No strategy collection is complete without Hearts of Iron IV!

Game has improved dramatically since launch, but what I've stayed for is the awesome Modding community. Red World, The New Order, and especially Kaiserreich are all fantastic fun - I've sunk more time into Kaiserreich than the base game itself. Granted, the game is not extraordinarily deep, but like I said if you want an introduction before jumping into games like Victoria or EU4, then look no further.

I've got over 40 hours into this game and I still don't understand it.  But I'm having fun!  Half the fun I think is steep learning curve.  Plus, it's so detailed and there's so many factors that go into your decisions and so many ways to "win".  Speaking of, you never really win.  At some point, the fighting just kind of stops and you can continue with new goals, or just quit and be satisfied because you had fun. It can or can't be historically accurate (as far as who attacks who), depending on how you set it up in the beginning. It features lots of real-life leaders, military figures, events, etc. so you learn a lot about history while you're at it. So in summary, don't give up right away because it's an extremely steep learning curve and if you accept the fact that making mistakes, losing over and over, and figuring out the game itself is part of the challenge, you'll have a good time.
The game is cool, but I would recommend to get all dlc to get a full expirience! I would recommend it!

Played as Nepal... Rushed Nuclear Research... Stayed under the radar till 1946... (Took over Tibet early on during that time) Soviets taking over the world... So I spam 'Improve relations' with them/Give them my ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• weapons (lend lease)... Switched to Communism to appease... Crisis averted until... World teams up against Soviets... Soviets wiped off the map... I'm now surrounded by the world in Kathmandu... (Literally) I have a heavilyy fortified city, maxed mountaineers, maxed heavy tanks, maxed bombers & Fighters that were stationed to the North in Tibet. Have 2 Nuclear Bombs at this point... Every attack they lay on me is 90-100% fended off. Defense is incredible.. Finally have air superiority in Northern India. Drop atom-bomb on Delhi.. Attacks stop momentarily as the world is in awe of Nepal's capabilities... Then the attacks continue on my fortress... (Thinking I only have one bomb) Drop another bomb on Patna... I'm wiped off the map shortly after... 9/10 Gameplay. Would be 10 but very difficult to learn when first starting off... also incredibly addicting... Girlfriend hates me rn.

Good, but flawed. I love the complex layers and freedom. Still learning new things 150 hrs in. But find the real enjoyment comes from the build up to way not the actual war itself. It lacks any satisfying feedback to major engagements and hopes of dramatic recreations of key WW2 moments were dashed.  That one decisive naval engagement is easily lost in the spam of 1 convoy ship sunk engagements. And when that moment finally comes it can be so very underwhelming after spending so much time building and designing a fleet to receive no real feel for what happened. The series has come along way but so much room for improvement.....

In my opinion, the best game of all time. The game is very well made and highly detailed. While the base focus trees could be better, the massive amounts of alternate history mods in the workshop makes up for this deficit. The countless paths you can take and ways your game will go make it a game which will last for years.

I really enjoy this game. Like most other Paradox games, you've got a ton of replay-ability here that will get you pouring an unseemly number of hours into the game. Unfortunately, like all Paradox games, you really do need at least a few of the DLCs to really get a full, complex experience. However, the large workshop community does give you a ton of a variety if you don't want to spend more money. If you're interested in WWII and have enjoyed other Paradox games, this is definitely the game for you.

Hearts of Iron IV...where to begin? Well for starters, I have been playing this game since 2018, which is where I made my debut into the world of grand strategy. As of this moment, I have about 1,200 hours in game, mostly singleplayer. I must say, much like heroin, I am addicted to this game. I cannot even begin to describe the rush of dopamine I feel when German Panzers cruise down the Champs-√âlys√©es or as American paratroopers rush through Moscow. Let me tell you a story. In 2017, I used to think toilet humor was funny. Now, in 2021, I find myself sitting below a bookshelf full of books by Rommel, Guderian, Sun Tzu, and countless other generals as an Austro-Hungarian flag and the Union Jack flutter behind me on my closet doors. It has been 4 years later and a total of 50 days (24 hrs each) in game since HOI4 first graced my Steam Library. Am I a better man for it? Hard to say. Am I a better tactician and military strategist? No doubt in my mind. Prepare yourself, future Field Marshal, for this game will change you. If it is for the better...well, that is for you to decide.

The base game of Hearts of Iron 4 is already a great game, plenty of possibilities and even today I am figuring out new strategies and approaches. What shoots this game up to master level is the modding community, you have almost a dozen fan projects that totally change the game, adding fresh mechanics and entire maps and settings. Its honestly amazing how much depth is put into some of these modes. Kaiserreich, New Order, Old World Blues and Equestria at War (yes, really) are all so deep in terms of setting and gameplay that they actually eclipse the base game.

Hoi 4 is my most played game and I'm still questioning or not whether I like or dislike it. I have bough the game and 3 DLCs and played so much of the DLCs, Hoi is one of those games that you can play for 12 hours straight and then something bad happens and you rage and have to start again because someone like Japan joins your world war with Germany meaning you have to find a path across the world to start fighting them, there are so many different focuses that your country can do and there's all of the main ideologies like communism, facism, democratic and neutrality, I'd recommend the game if you want a game where you can flip world war 2 around and have the soviet union as the major enemy of the allies or play as communist China and spread Communism across the globe, and if you think that some of the stuff that the base game lacks and doesn't go far enough and you want more and better arms, I'd recommend the free mod road to 56 as the tech in base game goes to like the 40s, road to 56 adds still up to 1956, including improved focus trees where you can turn germany communist or turn russia facist and turn everyone's ideologies backwords. Overall Hoi 4 is a game that I'd definitely Recommend.

This game is amazing. Really the best grand strategy game I have ever played. Because I played it quite a bit, and enjoyed it very much, I feel like I want to leave a relatively detailed review: General Important Information The game has a very steep learning curve. For new users, especially new to this genre, I highly recommend watching video tutorials online. It's the most detailed and complex WW2 strategy game I have every played. There are lots of things to do in different aspects, such as diplomacy, politics, economy, army composition, strategy, air, amazing options for navy and of course tactically managing battle plans. There are some great mods out there. Start with vanilla and then try a few mods, such as road to 56 and more. The Good Lots of options, and lots of choices. This leads to great replayability to the game. I return to the game every few months for a session of fun and joy. Navy (with MTG) is super fun. Designing ships and setting plans is complex but very rewarding. A history lesson disguised in a game. Graphics are really good. Honestly, I feel like they aged very well considering this game is 5 years old. Future sequels (HOI5 if there will be) should mainly improve other stuff. Very high level of detaisl, ranging from historic weapons, to provinces, to rivers, etc... A history lesson disguised in a game. Mod support is great. There are great mods out there. I really recommend "Road to 56". The Bad (and what they should improve in HOI5) Game tends to run very slow towards the end, when armies are beginning to be very big. Really, I'm talking about a a very FPS. They should improve performance. Battle plan control sometimes don't work as expected. Especially on fragmented islands, but not all. There are a few bugs here and there, even after 5 years with a game still selling plenty. Mainly UI bugs but also game bugs. Most of them are not game breaking though. Garrison game is weak. I believe "La Resistance" improved that, but it should be more interesting in vanilla. Paradox's DLC curse didn't miss this game. There are many and they cost some money. I do feel though that it's not that bad, but for now, for example, I'm not buying "La Resistance". Late game sometime gets tedious when you know you are going to win. This is the same in other grand strategy games (or 4X like in CIV). They should improve that with extended research IMO. Conclusion I really recommend this game. It's amazing. "The Bad" doesn't really affects "The Good". The people which will enjoy it the best are grand strategy lovers and WW2 lovers. It's not an easy "first strategy game" though.

Having played a few paradox games now, i am somewhat familiar with they style and mechanics that are often present in these large scale strategy games. I am always very impressed how, with numerous, relatively simple mechanics, Paradox create a complex system that does a good job emulating a population or a nations production etc. Hearts of Iron is another example of this very clever method being put into practise brilliantly. It can be overwhelming for someone who has never played a Paradox game or even if you have played only a little, but the reward is well worth the effort of learning. If you are an avid history fan then you will immediately be drawn to the excellently researched scenarios. I have only played a little myself and am thoroughly enjoying it.

Base game is meh, barely worth the full price tag as it lacks lots of thing. The reason I recommend this game is the vast modding community and the quality is shows, Mods like Road to 56 (R56) is a DLC sized mod that is completely free. It makes the game feel complete if you have no DLC. If you can fork out the extra cash to pick up all the DLC like during a sale then this game is definitely worth it. I have nearly 700 hours and I am still having tons of fun with various concepts and scenarios and some of the mods are amazing. Overall, expensive but worth it if you can buy the whole deal.

Without DLCs 8/10 With DLCs 10/10 I played this game a lot put about 150 hours and I still have the feeling that I haven't even scratched the surface of the game. There are Historical paths for all countries, but you can always make small choices that can alter your path. And there are Alternative history paths that can range from new war goals to deposing of Hitler or making some western countries into communism or fascism. And the best example is Spains focus on a tree where you can get lost in options. If those things get boring there are always mods raging from modern-day tech trees and focus trees to total ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• of mod where you can create your Furry fascist empire. But it's not a perfect game it tailors for the specific niche of gaymers that are ready to may more for this kind of game. And the biggest fault with this game is the learning curve it takes hours of gameplay or youtube tutorials to learn the fundamentals of the game.

have you ever wanted to be a leader of a ww2 country? have you ever wondered what the world would be if america went fascist? wanted to resurrect the ottoman empire? look no further as hearts of iron 4 has it all, this is what you call a grand strategy game, everything in this game revolves around fighting wars with other countries and managing every aspect of it, from the supply lines to the generals, the fallback lines the offensive lines, production etc u name it. there is ofcourse insane replayability by choosing different countries and ideologies and this is without factoring in amazing mods like road to 56 or kaisserreich. yes the game has mod support and it has some wild stuff, every saw man in the high castle and wanted to see how it went forwards after the tv shows ending? wanted to squash isis before they gained any foothold? how about u just want the cold war to have started? its all there. and then you have the multiplayer and oh boy is it something : beware that in order to play most multiplayer games u need quite some playing time on this game, we are talking about 300-500+ hours to fully understand everything about this game and its metas. the downside is that this is a game from paradox interactive wich means that a lot of features that couldve been part of the main game have been added in as payed dlc and these dlc can be quite hefty considering how many there are wich is quite unfortunate however the base game itself has plenty of content and replayability so even tough u dont need the dlc it can be a more fun experience.

A great game for those who can't help but ask : "what if ?" In Heart of iron 4, all of you're fantasy of alternate history  can take place : do you want a second American civil war with MacArthur at the head of the Confederate ? you can. Do you want the return of the Japanese shogunate ? you can. Do you want that Puyi break free of Japan and with Manchuria reconquer the empire of China ? you can. Do you want the return of the Napoleons and the empire of France ? you can. Do you want to create a zealous crusader state in Mexico ? you can. Do you want that Troski assassinate Stalin and take the control of the USSR ? you can. Do you want to conquer the world with the Spanish anarchist ? YOU CAN. In terms of gameplay, it breaks a lot with Heart of iron 3 and....that's good. Since Heart of iron 3 pushback the none-initiated while  HO4 with it simplified  gameplay permit to everyone to enjoy the game a their level. In terms of DLC i find them "reasonably" priced for their content....well...more that others games of Paradox.(puff..puff...EU4) To put it simply, HO4 is like a good wine... it get better with time.

HOI4 includes everything you need to rule a country.  It doesn't leave anything out which is why I think it's so great since they spend so much time making the game perfect.  I don't think the devs get enough appreciation for this.

Although there are not many strategy games about war of this time period, it is the best war "simulator" I've ever played. While most games focus solely on resources, unit production and fighting, this game is so complex (as managing a war would be in real life in that time) that before you grasp the basics your head will be spinning from all the things. Many complex mechanics are interwoven together with politics which, admittedly very difficult to get into at the beginning, can be very rewarding once you understand it. The game itself does not do a good job of explaining you at least the basics (or at least back in the time when I started playing it did not), so be prepared to read guides and seek additional information because while there are many ways how you can play the game to have fun, there are only a few to be victorious (if world domination is your objective, that is). In my opinion, a BIG plus of the game is its soudtrack. Frankly, there are not many games which would have such a captivating soundtrack that, just by listening to it, would make me want to play the game instantly. When I first listened to the soundtrack, I remember thinking "hey, what a strange choice of music for a game of this genre" but quickly I came to love it. Sabaton all the way! Like it or not, the game does teach you something about history (and quite a lot if you let it) which is another thing that I love about it. It does not really matter if you did not know about all the major events of World War II prior to playing the game, in the first couple of games you may be lost as to what will be happening but eventually you will get used (to some extent) to the unpredictability of the game. This is, in my opinion, another big plus of the game. In a real war, you never know how the situation will unfold itself and despite your best intentions and meticulous planning, all can go very quickly to hell if, say, some country starts justifying against you when you have already a war with someone else going or even because of other "details" such as when you forget to deselect your troops from training before declaring war or when you overlook an enemy naval invasion in the heat of battle (well, it can be tedious sometimes to look over your shoulder, especially if you fight on multiple fronts spanning the entire planet). And when you can play the game enough to win as any of the major nations, then... it is time to uncheck the "historical focus" mode and try some real madness :)

highly, highly recommended. But keep in mind these games aren't for everybody,  If you're like me and are missing more than your fair share of brain-cells, learning these games can be a chore but if you are into the idea of an alternate history sandbox strategy game thats just about infinitely repayable even without the mods and DLC, which almost always receive more criticism than they deserve, This is usually because there is always a percentage of the player-base who are butt hurt that their save or current strategy were up ended by the implementation of new mechanics or ... there are the rest who are crying about the paradox grand strategy game business model. Typically this complaint is that all the dlc they release should be included in the base game and it's some sort of flagrant cash grab that completely fails to comprehend the idea of value>cost. For a game where the average player who actually take the time to learn to play has usually something between a few hundred to a few thousand or more hours in the game, shelling out $10-$20 every other year or so to support the further development of an obviously worthwhile endeavor is a better deal then spending $60 on a game that will likely give you even a fraction of the time or lacks the depth and complexity that bring all the nerds to the yard and will be discarded into the depths of the ass end of their steam library in short time.

A grand strategy game for all the strategy enthusiasts. Though slow at times, the buildup is exciting in its own way. A grand arms race that determines whether your country sinks to the depths of history, or prevails to make it. The actual fighting is important too. You can either have an army that can steamroll through the enemy country side wit the click of one button, or an inferior force that depends on terrain, situational buffs, and defeat in detail strategies to weakly clasp onto their freedom and autonomy. Though beware, the game mechanics are a bit overwhelming for newbies; so I wouldn't recommend it for people starting out grand strategy games. Final Score: 8/10

Pros -WW2 -All world leaders and countries also gets better with dlcs. -You can mod fantasy maps like lotr and got or real maps like present day. -Relatively different war system by comparison for other titles. Cons -Game stucks after 1945 and will turn into world domination, so you cant live in peace after the war. -Game lags and loses fps too much as much you get closer to end of the war, low end pcs cant handle this game. -War system has problems and it will force you to micromanage and use pocket tactic in every situation. -You cant overwhelm a country unless there are too much difference between 2 countries in tech. -Some government types has faults and some cant get involved directly to the war. -Probably you wont finish a campaign and will start again because of where war goes and fps problem.

This is easily the best WW2 game of all time, and among the best Grand Strategy titles of all time.  This from a company known for making great grand strategy games. I really can't say much more than that, but if you liked any Hearts of Iron game before this one, you'll probably enjoy this.  Its the same basic gameplay, while playing somewhat differently than HOI 3.  One major difference is the battle plans system, where the ai will carry out your planned invasions somewhat effectively, though not perfectly. Also another major change, is that factories go up in efficiency the longer you leave them producing a single item without changing. Example: If you are producing a 1936 light tank, if you leave that factory producing a light tank uninterrupted, production will get faster and faster over time, to a maximum cap, which can be increased with research.

I wanted to like the game and to its credit it's pretty moreish, I found myself spending longer playing than I meant to but in the end I got sick of how the game doesn't explain anything. The built in tutorial covers barely anything, no political, naval, air etc. There isn't even an official explanation of the mechanics, their solution is to just link to a Wiki from within the game. I kept getting into positions where I'd feel like I'd be best of starting again because I'd wasted all resources building tanks or spending political power on pointless actions. The final straw for me though was the fact that the vanilla game UI tells you to send air supply missions to your troops when they're cut off (personally I think the AI that manages your armies for you should do more to stop itself being cut off but honestly I can live with that). Obviously, air supply missions are not explained anywhere in game, but searching reddit threads says you need transport planes. So I build some, and try and run an air supply mission. And you can't because apparently it's only a feature in the DLC, yet is displayed as an option in the vanilla game (presumably this was a feature they gutted out of the base game to sell DLC). Ultimately my frustration with the game outweighed the enjoyment I was getting out of it. I imagine it's more fun once you learn all the ins and outs but the fact that the game expects you to learn all that through trial and error (and that each trial takes 10s of hours) and intentionally misleads you about what you can do in the game means I can't recommend it.

A fantastic game that has a lot of depth, especially in military gameplay. It's relatively approachable for a Paradox game, which makes it a good choice regardless of your experience with grand strategy (it was my first game in the genre and I understood like 80% of the mechanics by 20 hours). Multiplayer, if you can get a good group, is great. Out of the Paradox games, this one is the least DLC-dependent because of how many amazing mods there are that cover most of the content. The main issue with the game is that it can get boring sooner than some other games, since you're basically repeating a 12 year period over and over and many of the developments happen pretty consistently, but this a. only occurred after like 250 hours for me, and b. is largely solved by mods, multi-player, and using smaller countries.
